headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Casey, and I will be your conference operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to turn the conference ove
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Casey, and I will be your conference operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to turn the conference over to Maria Quillard. Thank you. Ms. Quillard, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter then we'll open the call for questions. Let me remind everyone that during our conferenc
componenttext: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter then we'll open the call for questions. Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. We refer you to the documents the company filed with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website. Now let me turn the call over to Jon Olson.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria. During today's commentary, I will review our business results for the December quarter. I will conclude my remarks by providing guidance for the March quarter.December quarter sales increased 24% sequentially to $513.3 million and an inc
componenttext: Thank you, Maria. During today's commentary, I will review our business results for the December quarter. I will conclude my remarks by providing guidance for the March quarter.December quarter sales increased 24% sequentially to $513.3 million and an incremental increase of nearly $100 million and a new sales record for Xilinx. Sales strength during the quarter was driven by all end markets and all geographies. Sales from our top 50 customers and sales from the broad base of our smaller customers both increased in line with total sales. Operating income of $136.6 million increased 66% sequentially, representing a record level since the adoption of stock-based compensation expense. We achieved a couple of major product milestones during the quarter. First and foremost, Virtex-5 sales continued to post exceptional sales growth, easily surpassing $100 million in sales and becoming the largest FPGA family in history, a distinction achieved only twice before by Xilinx's Virtex-II and Virtex-E families. Spartan-3 sales also reached record sales during the quarter, driven primarily by strength in wireline communications, automotive and data processing applications. Sales of Spartan-3 devices currently represents 16% of total sales. New product sales increased 32% sequentially with significant increases from all product families. Mainstream and base products demonstrated atypically strong increases during the quarter, as many customers in these categories replenished exceptionally lean inventories.All geographies increased sequentially during the quarter, with Asia-Pacific and North America posting the strongest growth of 27% and 25%, sequentially, respectively. Strength in Asia-Pacific was driven by a broad base of applications with exceptional strength coming from Wired Communications. Asia-Pacific is our largest geography representing 36% of total sales, up from 33% in the same quarter a year ago. Strength in North America was also broad-based with the largest incremental sales gains coming from communications and industrial and other.North American sales now represent 35% of total sales, up from 34% a year ago. European sales increased 19% sequentially during the quarter, driven by strength from communications, audio/video broadcast and automotive. European sales represented 20% of total sales in the December quarter, down from 22% a year ago. Sales from Japan increased 17% sequentially, driven primarily by strength in the industrial and other market. Japan currently represents 9% of total sales, down from 11% sales a year ago.All of our end markets posted strong growth during the quarter. The largest incremental dollar increases came from communications, which increased 23%, sequentially, and industrial and other, which increased 29%, sequentially. Within communications, sales to wireline customers were particularly strong while sales to wireless customers were up slightly.All sub-segments within the industrial category including defense, industrial, scientific and medical and Test & Measurement increased significantly. Sales from the consumer and automotive and data processing categories were also strong, increasing 15% and 25%, sequentially.During the quarter, consumer sales were driven primarily by growth within audio/video broadcast and automotive subsegments. Data processing sales were driven by strengths from computing, as well as storage and servers. For the quarter, communications represents 46% of total sales, up from 44% a year ago. Industrial and other represents 32%, down from 33% a year ago. Consumer and automotive sales now represent 15% of total sales, down from 16% a year ago and data processing sales were flat at 7% in total, compared to the same quarter a year ago.Gross margin for the quarter was 64.1%, up from last quarter's gross margin of 61.9%, and in line with the revised guidance we provided on December 8. Gross margin primarily benefit from the strong growth in our mainstream and base products, as well as continued yield improvement and higher sales.Operating expenses were $192 million, including $6 million in restructuring charges. Total operating spending was 6 million higher than forecasted due to the higher variable spending associated with higher sales and profits.Restructuring charges were higher than previously forecasted by $2.5 million and are related to additional realignment actions taken by the company during the quarter. Operating margin increased to 27% for the quarter, up from 20% in the prior quarter and the highest we've reported in four years. Net income during the quarter was $107 million or $0.38 per diluted share, including the $6 million or approximately $0.02 per diluted share for restructuring charges. Operating cash flow for December quarter was $185 million before $9 million in CapEx. We paid $44 million in cash dividends and spent $25 million on stock buyback during the quarter. During the calendar year, Xilinx generated $511 million in operating cash flow, a testament to the resilience of our business model during periods of economic uncertainty. The tax rate in the December quarter was 20%, slightly higher than forecasted due to geographical mix but in line with our long-term model.Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments increased $123 million during the quarter to approximately $2 billion. We have approximately $690 million in convertible debt and our net cash position is approximately $1.3 billion.Days sales outstanding decreased six days in the December quarter to 44 days. Combined inventory days in the December quarter were 85, up from 75 days in the prior quarter, but slightly below our corporate target of 90 to 100 days. We have improved our inventory levels by also shifting record levels of our product.Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the March quarter for fiscal year '10. Our backlog heading into the quarter is up. However, we moved back to a 13-week accounting quarter in March and therefore, lost the benefit of an additional week of turns business. We are expecting to see continued strength from Virtex-5, as well as strong growth from our new Virtex-6 and Spartan-6 families. We believe growth for the mainstream and base families will abate as customers inventories are replenished. From an end market perspective, we're expecting sales from communications to be up slightly, consumer and automotive to be down slightly and industrial and other and data processing to be flat. As a result, we are expecting sales to be up 3% to down 1%, sequentially, in the March quarter, with sales from Europe increasing and sales from all other geographies to be flattish sequentially. The midpoint of our sales guidance is predicated on a turns rate of approximately 55%, down from 58% in the December quarter.Gross margin is expected to be approximately 64% to 65%. Operating expenses in the March quarter will decrease by approximately $12 million to approximately $180 million, including $3 million in restructuring charges. Other income and expenses is expected to be a net expense of approximately $2 million. The share count is expected to be $275 million shares and the tax rate is expected to be approximately 20%. Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and good afternoon to you all. We are extremely pleased with our overall performance this quarter. The magnitude of the sequential revenue increase is absolutely a great achievement.We began to see the recovery in our business in the Sept
componenttext: Thank you, John, and good afternoon to you all. We are extremely pleased with our overall performance this quarter. The magnitude of the sequential revenue increase is absolutely a great achievement.We began to see the recovery in our business in the September quarter, with broad-based strength across all major end market categories. We then entered the December quarter with a solid backlog, but we're relatively cautious, given the economic uncertainty, the fact that our lead times had stretched out due to V5 supply constraints in the past June quarter.The recovery, continued throughout our third fiscal quarter, have experienced much stronger than expected bookings across all end markets. With the exception of wireless and consumer, all subcategories were up over 20% sequentially. And some end markets like Wired Comms and Test & Measurement were up approximately 40%. Even with these incredibly strong revenue numbers, six of our 10 secondary end markets have still not reached the same levels they were back at our previous revenue peak of $488 million. This prior peak was during the June 2008 quarter. We expect all the secondary end markets to recover above the June 2008 levels over the next year.Much has been said about lead times within the semiconductor industry. In our case, our lead times have declined this quarter, as we expected. But the vast majority of these within a normal four to six-week range, customers can place orders with us close to their demand requirements. In the December quarter, Virtex-5 surpassed $100 million in revenue very handily. This revenue level, we estimate our share of the high end 65-nm market to be over 80%. As the industry's largest revenue-generating FPGA family shipping today, demand for Virtex-5 remains extremely robust. We expect Virtex-5 to continue to be a primary sales driver throughout our next fiscal year. I'm convinced that the strength of our 65-nm sales provides compelling evidence that programmable imperative is indeed upon us. The next node will continue to extend the inexorable March programmable logic placing ASICs and over time selective ASSP solution. We have built upon our Virtex-5 success to deliver this next-generation of FPGA product, Virtex-6 and Spartan-6. Earlier today, we announced that Virtex-6 has achieved full production qualification and is now shipping in volume production. Reaching this production milestone signifies that we have stable and predicative signing with Virtex-6 expect to have their end product shipping in full [Audio Gap] volume in the first half of 2010. Earlier this month, we announced the first shipments and availability of the industry's largest FPGA, 40-nm Virtex-6 LX760, which is ideal for the most advanced prototyping platform in the ASIC emulation market. In parallel, Spartan-6 is the industry's only 45-nm high-volume FPGA market and the only high-volume FPGA market with embedded transceiver technology. This is a key technology for Xilinx because it makes far more competitive in the high-volume arena. The lowest cost and lowest power volume FPGA solution on the market design wins of Spartan-6 are very healthy. Spartan-6 LXT devices are currently being designed into our customers next-generation product with design win strength coming from communication, industrial, defense and automotive.In summary, I'm extremely pleased with our performance this quarter and the compelling execution on all fronts. Our 65-nm leadership is virtually uncontested design win momentum and 45-nm products is exceptionally strong. In the financial front, I'm extremely pleased with our increased profitability. As John mentioned earlier, our operating margin is the highest it's been in four years and is nearing our corporate target. This is a testament to the continued efforts across the company to control expenses and operate more efficiently. Notwithstanding that turn in the business, I want to show you that we will continue to, as we've done over the past two years, remain prudent about cost control. Now let me turn the call back to the operator to open it up for the Q&A session.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Jon, can you expand a bit on the communications  commentary around wireline being strong, kind of, is that service provider-related enterprise, networking-related and maybe give us a little bit of detail by geography? And also in terms of your outlook whe
componenttext: Jon, can you expand a bit on the communications  commentary around wireline being strong, kind of, is that service provider-related enterprise, networking-related and maybe give us a little bit of detail by geography? And also in terms of your outlook when you talk about communications being up a bit, if you could expand and, kind of, which geographies you're seeing strength from.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: The strength from this quarter and wireline was actually fairly broad-based. While the network enterprise piece was up quite a bit, we also had broad-based improvement across a variety of wireline applications. On the telecom side and in equipment, custom
componenttext: The strength from this quarter and wireline was actually fairly broad-based. While the network enterprise piece was up quite a bit, we also had broad-based improvement across a variety of wireline applications. On the telecom side and in equipment, customers focused on that as well as some of the access side, as well. So I actually don't have a percentage split of which one might have gone up more than the other because actually all were pretty good. So this is one of the other reasons we feel pretty good about, our overall business strength and moving forward. It's just because we have a lot of broad-based strength across the wireline area. On top of the historic strength we've had in the wireless piece. So we're feeling pretty good right now about communications infrastructure. With respect to geographies, I think we generally would say that as we've said, Asia in total was up as well as Europe and North America and we focused that Japan's strength was in another area. So I think it's pretty broad-based again, geographically speaking. On the forward-looking communications, I think, we do believe both wireline and wireless would be up some. The up part, we said everything  ex-comm was going to be up slightly, other things are going to be more on the flat side. Now that as compared to our 14-week period, and so now we have a 13-week period, it takes -- we have fewer days to ship, so to speak, and fewer turns opportunities there. So I think we do believe that there's a stronger set of business coming out of Europe in this next period. And so I think that's also true from our communications customers as well as some other areas. So we see stronger European focus on communications, as well as Asia, should do somewhat better there as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you comfortable with your inventory level at this point, or do you see yourself growing inventories going to the March quarter?
componenttext: Are you comfortable with your inventory level at this point, or do you see yourself growing inventories going to the March quarter?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: We sat here quarter ago talking about this and then after the call, people were kind of astonished that we were going to get our inventory back up to 90 days and the implication and how many dollars that would mean and could we really have that many wafer
componenttext: We sat here quarter ago talking about this and then after the call, people were kind of astonished that we were going to get our inventory back up to 90 days and the implication and how many dollars that would mean and could we really have that many wafers coming out, et cetera. What we really did, we didn't get it up to 90 days, we did it at $28 million, which was almost 30% growth in our inventory dollars while shipping well over even our revised guidance at 24%. So we do think we're still a little lean in some areas and it would be good to get a little bit more in a few areas, but generally, we're okay and satisfied. That doesn't mean that we're going to be continuously operating at this level in the high 70s, low to mid-80s, but I think we have enough to satisfy what we feel is demand for our customers for the next quarter or two.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

componenttext: Our next question will come from Brendan Furlong.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Your comment on the mainstream and base being a little bit lower for this coming quarter with a strong inventory fill in the quarter just completed. Do you think that the inventory fill is largely done or there's more inventory to be done by those mainstr
componenttext: Your comment on the mainstream and base being a little bit lower for this coming quarter with a strong inventory fill in the quarter just completed. Do you think that the inventory fill is largely done or there's more inventory to be done by those mainstream and base customers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's pretty difficult for us to dissect exactly of our growth, what was just replenishment versus not. I think the one thing that we can say about this, Brendan, is if you look at our new product growth, it was extremely healthy. It was $40
componenttext: Well, I think it's pretty difficult for us to dissect exactly of our growth, what was just replenishment versus not. I think the one thing that we can say about this, Brendan, is if you look at our new product growth, it was extremely healthy. It was $40 million close to 40% of our total growth for the company. So that would imply that wouldn't be a lot of inventory replenishment because those are usually new designs and going new places. So that also gives a good feeling about the future quarters, about building our business. I think that some of our end markets there's probably still some inventory fill coming back. As Moshe pointed out there, several of our sub-markets where we're not back to our record, and I think some of those customers are still feeling out the economy. So I would guess there could be a little bit inventory replenishment left in a few of those markets, but I'd say the highest percentage of that activity would work out this quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: On the gross margins, did the nice bump that you got this quarter, would it be safe to assume that it was largely or a big part of that was coming from the better truth [ph] on the Virtex-5 problems that you had in the last several quarters?
componenttext: On the gross margins, did the nice bump that you got this quarter, would it be safe to assume that it was largely or a big part of that was coming from the better truth [ph] on the Virtex-5 problems that you had in the last several quarters?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Not really. I don't think the fact that we were behind in December and producing it and now all of a sudden, we're getting much better cost profile. I think we're just getting a better overall cost profile because A, we have higher volumes so whether the
componenttext: Not really. I don't think the fact that we were behind in December and producing it and now all of a sudden, we're getting much better cost profile. I think we're just getting a better overall cost profile because A, we have higher volumes so whether the fixed cost we do have are amortized over more dollars, but moreover, we are very much focused on improving yields even on products that we've had out in the market for many, many years. It's been a renewed focus for the company, it's starting to see some of the things come through from those efforts from our last two generations of Virtex in particular. And we just feel that it's a different attitude and commitment to the company about focusing on cost of some of our historic product families.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Uche Orji.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Uche Orji.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Moshe, let me just talk to you about the 49-nm yield trend in UMC. There's been all kinds of whether trends steel are improving the insanity to use them but can you just talk to us about what the yield trends at UMC? There's been all kinds of pressure to
componenttext: Moshe, let me just talk to you about the 49-nm yield trend in UMC. There's been all kinds of whether trends steel are improving the insanity to use them but can you just talk to us about what the yield trends at UMC? There's been all kinds of pressure to whether trends, yields are improving in general at CMSC, I know you don't use them, but can you just talk to us about what the yield trends are at UMC? And also along those lines, if you can also explain given that Altera would have to have the time to market, with 45-nm, how have you able to retain your top customers given their need for more advanced technologies?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: We used two foundries, two different ones. One is UMC for the 40-nm and the second is Samsung at the 45-nm. And based on the press release, you've seen today in my previous comments, we feel very comfortable with where we are on UMC. And the yields are go
componenttext: We used two foundries, two different ones. One is UMC for the 40-nm and the second is Samsung at the 45-nm. And based on the press release, you've seen today in my previous comments, we feel very comfortable with where we are on UMC. And the yields are going in the right direction, and we've opened orders up in a big way. So we're very confident that all of the learning we have done plus all of the learning and the proven success on Virtex-5 will enable us to provide, to meet our customer requirements. In parallel, we are on track for by the end of this year, it is our financial year to move the Spartan-6 into full production, too. So we feel very good about those two product lines, the capacity and yield at this point to meet our customer requirements. With regards to competition, we have a very broad product offering with the incumbent on the high end, and that helps us through. And again, we feel that our offering and incumbent position provides us with a good position there. So it looks really good. And we believe that if the 40 nm node, the overall market is expanding and expanding significantly for FPGAs in particular, vis-à-vis ASICs but also vis-a-vis some select ASSP markets and that drives growth for everyone who's capable of participating in this trend.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And just on a different note, let me just ask you a wireless infrastructure. Wireline was very strong particularly this quarter, not so much from wireless, so much as they made as to when the next phase of Chinese GT deployment will kick in. Also in some
componenttext: And just on a different note, let me just ask you a wireless infrastructure. Wireline was very strong particularly this quarter, not so much from wireless, so much as they made as to when the next phase of Chinese GT deployment will kick in. Also in some expectation as to India treaty licensing. Can you give us any updates you have on both key markets and what your expectation is for wireless infrastructure deployment through the second half of 2010.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: It's still not clear when the ramp for this next phase will begin. I mean, we are currently shipping products into the manufacturers. They were doing some prototyping work, I assume they're going to be in the competition for both China and India. So there
componenttext: It's still not clear when the ramp for this next phase will begin. I mean, we are currently shipping products into the manufacturers. They were doing some prototyping work, I assume they're going to be in the competition for both China and India. So there are some early shipments going on now. But in terms of the volume shipments for the rollout of either the next phase in China for the TD rollout in India, that remains to be seen. Our thinking on China is still that the ramp is going to start somewhere in the April, May, June timeframe. But again, this is just on our long-term forecast that we're getting, the hard orders haven't come yet. So that's always the proof in the whole situation. We'll also say that some of our strength from wireless for next quarter is going to be related to wide-band CDMA shipments in China. So it isn't just watching the TD side of things, it's also the wide-band CDMA so that's also another -- a strength that we'll have next quarter that, I'll say is not really tied to this fourth phase situation in China.

componenttext: Jon, I had a question on the extra week I think going into the quarter, you didn't think it would necessarily contribute too much since it was a holiday week. Would you say that as you do an apples-to-apples comparison here in calendar Q1 versus calendar Q4 that, that full extra week did contribute about 7% of revenues?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I mean our estimates are that the last two weeks of our 24% growth, approximately five percentage points of that, five points of that 24 is related to the last two weeks. And primarily, in the last two weeks had embedded both the holidays from country
componenttext: No, I mean our estimates are that the last two weeks of our 24% growth, approximately five percentage points of that, five points of that 24 is related to the last two weeks. And primarily, in the last two weeks had embedded both the holidays from country holidays and Christmas and New Year. And our best estimate is based on the turns patterns we had in the last two weeks and try to figure out what the one week was worth, and our best estimate on that is in the neighborhood of five points of the total of 24.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So our fiscal year isn't over until March, and we really haven't finished our budgeting process yet, so we're not going to project anything about next year. We'll talk more about that on our Analyst Day which is in February and give you some more color ab
componenttext: So our fiscal year isn't over until March, and we really haven't finished our budgeting process yet, so we're not going to project anything about next year. We'll talk more about that on our Analyst Day which is in February and give you some more color about what we're thinking there. I mean, mass costs are tied to what were our product introduction on the roadmap et cetera, and they will start to decline. But there's some other factors going on as well, so we'll explain that more in February 22.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Hans Mosesmann.  [Raymond James]
componenttext: Our next question will come from Hans Mosesmann.  [Raymond James]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Moshe, can you give us a little more detail about the evidence that you may have regarding the success of your next nodes, the 40-nm, 45-nm in displacing ASICs. Maybe there's some anecdotes you could share with us regarding that? And then, I have a follow
componenttext: Moshe, can you give us a little more detail about the evidence that you may have regarding the success of your next nodes, the 40-nm, 45-nm in displacing ASICs. Maybe there's some anecdotes you could share with us regarding that? And then, I have a follow-up.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, well, again, we'll be providing more detail in February. But as we go through the design wins with the sales force, we continuously see ASICs being displaced in a big way and, in some cases, ASSPs. And these are things like network processes, things
componenttext: Okay, well, again, we'll be providing more detail in February. But as we go through the design wins with the sales force, we continuously see ASICs being displaced in a big way and, in some cases, ASSPs. And these are things like network processes, things of that sort, that had their moments of sun in the earlier part of the decade and those huge flowery of investment, and a lot of those product do not have a roadmap going forward. And the customers are now recognizing that, in some cases, they would rather have the flexibility of using FPGAs to replace those products. So we'll show quite a few examples of that, and this isn't limited to communications. Definitely, it's broad-based in A&D, it's happening in other markets like Medical, too, and there's a whole host of examples that we'll show. But this trend clearly is happening, and it will accelerate at 40-nm. It will definitely benefit from having the high-volume product which broadens the market reach. And with each generation, we see that actually moving more and more in our favor and becoming less and less possible to justify in ASICs, and a lot of these smaller and medium-sized semiconductor companies are going to find it very difficult to invest these areas. So it's incumbent upon us to show you more examples. We have lots of them, and we'll try and share those in February.

componenttext: As a follow-up, on the 40-nm, or in terms of process node roadmaps, can you share with us what's the next node? Do you have that in terms of timing? And who would be your partner there, if you can share that with us.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Looking on the investor side, you've mentioned something about Test & Measurement inquiry of 40%. Can you give us an idea of the defense side that you were very cautious last time, and it looks like you did better than that. So what was the driver for tha
componenttext: Looking on the investor side, you've mentioned something about Test & Measurement inquiry of 40%. Can you give us an idea of the defense side that you were very cautious last time, and it looks like you did better than that. So what was the driver for that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So on the industrial side, Tests & Measurements specifically, I think the biggest driver, I would say, would be the return to more classical Test & Measurement applications, just instrumentation et cetera. The [Audio Gap] at this point in time. So I would
componenttext: So on the industrial side, Tests & Measurements specifically, I think the biggest driver, I would say, would be the return to more classical Test & Measurement applications, just instrumentation et cetera. The [Audio Gap] at this point in time. So I would say the more classic, instrumentation side, is probably the biggest strength during that time period. Now on defense, we were cautious because we did have one of our orders on a specific project come in a quarter earlier than we had anticipated, and so we knew that would repeat itself. So we were cautious, and we're pleasantly surprised that we're up a little bit more than we said. We said we'd be up some but not necessarily up a lot. We were up but not as much as some of our other end markets were either, so very strong growth, calendar year on calendar year, quarter-over-quarter kinds of things. We still see that as one of our strongest markets as it has been for us and will continue to be for us.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And quickly on the gross margin side, the 50-basis-point improvement, is that mostly coming from cost reduction or product mix?
componenttext: And quickly on the gross margin side, the 50-basis-point improvement, is that mostly coming from cost reduction or product mix?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Cost reduction, primarily. And as we mix more to new products, I mean, we talked about base and mainstream not growing as much next quarter as it had and new products still being very, very strong, the new products do have a different margin profile for t
componenttext: Cost reduction, primarily. And as we mix more to new products, I mean, we talked about base and mainstream not growing as much next quarter as it had and new products still being very, very strong, the new products do have a different margin profile for the fact that we're getting stronger on the new products and also raising margin guidance. I mean, that's a sign that we are very serious in making progress and headway in terms of our improving costs at the company of our products.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Chris Danely. [JPMorgan].
componenttext: Our next question will come from Chris Danely. [JPMorgan].

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I know you're going to say the specifics for the Analyst Meeting, but can we expect the gross margins to, I guess, bounce around this 64.5% range going forward? And also, can we expect the OpEx to drift down on a percentage basis going forward?
componenttext: I know you're going to say the specifics for the Analyst Meeting, but can we expect the gross margins to, I guess, bounce around this 64.5% range going forward? And also, can we expect the OpEx to drift down on a percentage basis going forward?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Jon. Our gross margin range is 62% to 65%. We are operating towards the high end of it. There's no boundary necessarily on the high-end, but there's obviously the practicality of introducing a whole new generation of products and the potent
componenttext: Chris, this is Jon. Our gross margin range is 62% to 65%. We are operating towards the high end of it. There's no boundary necessarily on the high-end, but there's obviously the practicality of introducing a whole new generation of products and the potential impacts on that. We'll talk more about our business model in February, but I think that we can, at a minimum, continue to operate towards the high end of this range for a while longer, and we're certainly working on trying to get higher than that. I'm not going to make any specific commitment. In OpEx, we're just not going to talk about the OpEx and R&D profile with any granularity at this point in time. We'll talk about it in a few weeks.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then as my follow-up question on the manufacturing, so is everything, I guess, back to normal now from a delivery/delinquency standpoint?
componenttext: And then as my follow-up question on the manufacturing, so is everything, I guess, back to normal now from a delivery/delinquency standpoint?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're in pretty decent shape on our delivery status. And then, also the lead times are starting to move more in line with our historic desire and model. That is not to say that we're still with full foundries while we're getting what we need
componenttext: Yes, I think we're in pretty decent shape on our delivery status. And then, also the lead times are starting to move more in line with our historic desire and model. That is not to say that we're still with full foundries while we're getting what we need to meet customers. There's always spot issues in terms of any sort of spikes, I mean, along the way. So there are still a few product lines where we're a little hand to mouth. But by and large, we're in much better situation than we were last quarter and certainly the quarter before that. So we've improved to a level that we can operate pretty well at this level, I think.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from James Schneider. [Goldman Sachs]
componenttext: Our next question will come from James Schneider. [Goldman Sachs]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, first of all, to return to the gross margin side for a second, in the past, you've talked about gross margins for new products being a little bit of a drag on the overall corporate profile. Has that gone to a point where Virtex-5, for example, wo
componenttext: I guess, first of all, to return to the gross margin side for a second, in the past, you've talked about gross margins for new products being a little bit of a drag on the overall corporate profile. Has that gone to a point where Virtex-5, for example, would be at corporate levels? And do you expect any marginal improvement there given the size of that business?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So the Virtex-5 margins are relatively close to corporate model. Obviously, there's mix issues that can impact at any given quarter or any given customer, but we still see headway in margin improvement. And acknowledging that this is the largest family in
componenttext: So the Virtex-5 margins are relatively close to corporate model. Obviously, there's mix issues that can impact at any given quarter or any given customer, but we still see headway in margin improvement. And acknowledging that this is the largest family in the history of the FPGA industry and will have the largest total revenue of any family, and we are still driving forward to higher numbers, it's not a loss in it that has an opportunity to be a continued large profit generator. So the focus on gross margin, I would say, gross margin improvement in that particular family is intense. We are extremely focused on improving that in order to deliver more profitability to the company.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, I think you talked about Spartan-6 shipping by March time frame, and you've already introduced Virtex-6 and talked about some substantial wireless design wins in the first half of this year. Can you give us a sense of where those two p
componenttext: And as a follow-up, I think you talked about Spartan-6 shipping by March time frame, and you've already introduced Virtex-6 and talked about some substantial wireless design wins in the first half of this year. Can you give us a sense of where those two product categories could be -- when they could be material, let's say 3% or 4% of revenues?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think, usually, it takes about four quarters before it starts really having much of an impact. I'm not going to say at what percentage level, but it will take a few quarters. Now Moshe did point out that the Wireless Communications custome
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think, usually, it takes about four quarters before it starts really having much of an impact. I'm not going to say at what percentage level, but it will take a few quarters. Now Moshe did point out that the Wireless Communications customers are very focused on introducing that, and this is also why, I think, this particular pattern may be more aggressive growth in both revenue and design wins than even Virtex-5 in the early part of its life cycle. And so it could become a little more significant, more rapidly than Virtex-5. And I think a lot of that depends on the wireless base station rollout that I was speaking of earlier. While we're still a broad-based design wins, certainly the early shipment levels are away towards the comps base pretty largely.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from David Wu. [GC Research]
componenttext: Our next question will come from David Wu. [GC Research]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I have two things. First thing is, on the Virtex-6 rollout, if I didn't read to your press release this morning correctly, all the family of the Virtex-6 will be shipping at least simply by the end of the second calendar quarter of the year. And Spar
componenttext: Yes, I have two things. First thing is, on the Virtex-6 rollout, if I didn't read to your press release this morning correctly, all the family of the Virtex-6 will be shipping at least simply by the end of the second calendar quarter of the year. And Spartan-6, I guess, will be rolled out by June of this year also?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: The base family, Virtex-6, that factor, there are some derivative families that won't be production-worthy within a quarter or within two quarters at that point. But by and large, the sweet spot of things will be, that's for [ph] focus I'm getting. And Sp
componenttext: The base family, Virtex-6, that factor, there are some derivative families that won't be production-worthy within a quarter or within two quarters at that point. But by and large, the sweet spot of things will be, that's for [ph] focus I'm getting. And Spartan-6 will follow very shortly after that. I mean, there's not going to be that much space in between having pretty much the full family available mid-year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, the other question I have is when do you think the Series 6 family will take over as the leading design winners for you in new design wins? When should we wait? Do we need 12 months or could it be earlier than that?
componenttext: Okay, the other question I have is when do you think the Series 6 family will take over as the leading design winners for you in new design wins? When should we wait? Do we need 12 months or could it be earlier than that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if we're talking about a high-volume family as the target versus any FPGA family because, obviously, our high end is the biggest thing we have going. But Spartan-6 design, opportunity design win activity, is probably already equal or bigger than our
componenttext: Well, if we're talking about a high-volume family as the target versus any FPGA family because, obviously, our high end is the biggest thing we have going. But Spartan-6 design, opportunity design win activity, is probably already equal or bigger than our Spartan-3 Series, but I'd have to go -- we have many derivatives on Spartan-3 so, I guess, to tell you, dissect the Spartan-3 family just to get that. I mean, we are heavily focused on the design wins, converting opportunities and design wins on that family. We still have them on some of the older families, but we're largely focused on having those pile up now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And what about the transition between Virtex-6 and Virtex-5 in terms of new design wins?
componenttext: And what about the transition between Virtex-6 and Virtex-5 in terms of new design wins?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think from that perspective, Virtex-5 has been such a highly popular product family for us. We're still getting quite a few design wins on Virtex-5 and which then help us speaks [ph] to the longevity and the strength of this revenue curve over the
componenttext: Well, I think from that perspective, Virtex-5 has been such a highly popular product family for us. We're still getting quite a few design wins on Virtex-5 and which then help us speaks [ph] to the longevity and the strength of this revenue curve over the life cycle. So I actually don't have the numbers at my fingertips on the crossover quarter on Virtex-5 versus Virtex-6 though we've quoted and converted some very large Virtex-6 design wins on lifetime revenues, so it's a pretty big numbers.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Glen Yeung. [Citigroup]
componenttext: Our next question will come from Glen Yeung. [Citigroup]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: You guys have set revenue record revenues this quarter, but we're relatively early into an economic cycle. And I wonder, as you look forward longer term, or even look backwards to some extent, was there something structural in your business that let you g
componenttext: You guys have set revenue record revenues this quarter, but we're relatively early into an economic cycle. And I wonder, as you look forward longer term, or even look backwards to some extent, was there something structural in your business that let you get to record revenues this early that can impact us going forward or do you really think that even from these levels, you can continue to grow with the overall economy?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd like to have more space between your record revenue in but, okay, Glen, because we like to feel pretty good about where we are and where we're forecasting for next quarter before we get to all our bets of trying to figure out what best thing cou
componenttext: Well, I'd like to have more space between your record revenue in but, okay, Glen, because we like to feel pretty good about where we are and where we're forecasting for next quarter before we get to all our bets of trying to figure out what best thing could happen to us now. But quite frankly, this notion that this is some sort of a one quarter flash and the world's going to turn bad on us is really not how we're thinking right now. Will there be some volatility ahead of us? Sure. Will there be some slower quarters and others ahead of us? Sure. But as we've communicated, Virtex-5 has kicked in a huge way. Corporate Communications is strong. Corporate profits are up. The corporations are trying to spend more money on IT. But we've talked about set-top box as being very bridged throughout the summer and fall which typically leads to more head in telecom equipment being purchased. All those things are happening. So send some sort of another nuclear economic issue, we feel like infrastructures has got a lot of legs in it. And if you look back, the biggest thing looking back on the perspective is the fact that we've been so successful on 65-nm and the fact that we have thought about our financial discipline of the company, and we're delivering operating margin growth well in excess of revenue growth. I mean, these are things that we've been talking about and they're happening now, and we're hoping everybody sees that, that these are incredible proof points about the strength of our company. Now we're just getting started.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up to that, you make it a point that you are more normal in terms of lead times today, but at the same time, recognized that the foundries are relatively tight. Will you look farther forward, I think, second half of this year or even into next
componenttext: As a follow-up to that, you make it a point that you are more normal in terms of lead times today, but at the same time, recognized that the foundries are relatively tight. Will you look farther forward, I think, second half of this year or even into next year. Given where capital spending is and what you see for capacity growth, are you concerned, I guess, about the availability of the supply as revenues do start to grow from these levels?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as the CFO, I'm always concerned about it because I feel those same signs that deal on the capital investment level have been pretty weak, although now they're starting to come up quite a bit and so maybe we'll be okay. We have long-term dialogues w
componenttext: Well, as the CFO, I'm always concerned about it because I feel those same signs that deal on the capital investment level have been pretty weak, although now they're starting to come up quite a bit and so maybe we'll be okay. We have long-term dialogues with our foundry partners about capacity and talked to them about our needs and do scenario planning. And we do scenario planning with them in order to get what we need. And one of the advantages is, I'm sure and I know you know this, of the FPGA, it's a great lead vehicle for foundries for their process. And so in exchange for working with them very closely, we have typically been able to get to have a strong bond with them and it allows us to get the number of wafers that we need. And obviously, there was exceptions to that as depending on how filled they are. But while I'm concerned as a CFO, we have a very positive relationship with these suppliers of ours. And everything that we can tell right now is that we're going to get what we need.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from John Pitzer. [Crédit Suisse]
componenttext: Our next question will come from John Pitzer. [Crédit Suisse]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: John, revisiting the inventory, I understand there was intent this quarter to build, and quite frankly, you're still operating below your days target. But, I guess, I'm struggling a little bit with trying to reconcile your comments around lead times being
componenttext: John, revisiting the inventory, I understand there was intent this quarter to build, and quite frankly, you're still operating below your days target. But, I guess, I'm struggling a little bit with trying to reconcile your comments around lead times being relatively stable and manageable revenue expectations for the March quarter being kind of flattish and yet growing inventories 28% sequentially. Can you help me understand why you feel like you have to get back to that 90 days right here, right now?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, John. Our business is typified by, in many different combinations of products and low-volume, high mix on a relative basis to typically like you would think of profits or manufacturers or cell phone chipset manufacturers or et cetera. So we req
componenttext: Yes, sure, John. Our business is typified by, in many different combinations of products and low-volume, high mix on a relative basis to typically like you would think of profits or manufacturers or cell phone chipset manufacturers or et cetera. So we require lots of inventory on a relative basis in order to make sure we can full safety stock and can meet customers' needs as rapidly as we can. So we knew we were severely behind on our safety stock which is why we made such a commitment to try to build the inventory this last quarter. We were relatively successful, and not as successful as I had forecasted and like to be, but successful enough that the highest volume products and the ones that are the most important products through our customers, we feel we are in a reasonable safety stock position. And that doesn't mean that across the board, we feel comfortable that all our parts are at the right level of safety stock. But we are ahead of where the long-term forecast say we need from our customers, so we have adequate supply. We just haven't built safety stock back on everything. That being said, being between 85 days and 90, it's really not that many days because I see us operating in consistently in 85 days versus 90 and 95. It's possible. It's just that there's a few things that we'd like to have a little bit more of. So I think it all kind of fits together. I mean, next quarter, days are going to be that down some, but dollars will be flat to up a little bit. So we'll be fine.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: In your prepared comments, you said you expect Europe to grow sequentially in the March quarter. Just kind of curious what's driving that?
componenttext: In your prepared comments, you said you expect Europe to grow sequentially in the March quarter. Just kind of curious what's driving that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: It's both Comps and Industrial segments. So Europe has kind of lagged on the recovery, and that's helping us with also the broader base of customers and so distribution got stronger this quarter. It's going to continue to be solid next quarter and Industr
componenttext: It's both Comps and Industrial segments. So Europe has kind of lagged on the recovery, and that's helping us with also the broader base of customers and so distribution got stronger this quarter. It's going to continue to be solid next quarter and Industrial customers are starting to come back in Europe, so that's helping us quite a bit. And then, over the top of that is the very strong communications focus. And in addition to the China focus, there's also shipments of LTE products into the U.S. and Europe and particularly the Verizon in the U.S. and some prep for India going on. So those are the kinds of things that's getting some focus there. The wireline part in Europe is also showing some strength in some of those key customers as well, so it'll be a big communication focus and Industrial improvement in Europe for next quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Luke Tim. [Barclays Capital]
componenttext: Our next question will come from Luke Tim. [Barclays Capital]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: It's Tim Luke. So Jon, just in terms of your color going forward -- but for a while you've been for some years in the sort of bouncing around the $480 million in revenue. Now you break it free to sort of $513 million, $514 million, and yet you're guiding
componenttext: It's Tim Luke. So Jon, just in terms of your color going forward -- but for a while you've been for some years in the sort of bouncing around the $480 million in revenue. Now you break it free to sort of $513 million, $514 million, and yet you're guiding up again in the March period. Can you just clarify what the turns are for that, and then it sounded like in thinking about the year, you're saying that communications is going to be strong. Is it also infrastructure that makes you feel reasonably positive about the full year? Or what are the other sort of major contributors, and then also you sounded like you were thinking that China ramps again in April, May, June. After these sort of stronger quarters, should we expect some moderation in the overall revenue picture in June? Or how are you beginning to think about that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did say our backlog was up going into the quarter, so we do have, what I would say, a pretty strong backlog again. We are forecasting a turns rate of mid-50s at 55% in that range which is lower than our actual turns for the last quarter. And some
componenttext: Yes, we did say our backlog was up going into the quarter, so we do have, what I would say, a pretty strong backlog again. We are forecasting a turns rate of mid-50s at 55% in that range which is lower than our actual turns for the last quarter. And some of that is just related to what we think were booked on and what customers and booked ahead on, et cetera. So maybe that could be called a little bit of a conservative play or not. I mean, we think that turns numbers will be a little lower in this peak for a quarter going forward. So the strength of the business is truly for next quarter, it's going to be communications. And even though the next phase of the TD rollout in China won't be necessarily happening in a big way next quarter, there is still wireless strength, we believe. And there's still [Audio Gap] I mean, it's totally over. And so those builds continue, but we're also getting strong Wireline business out of China as well. So as those companies start to take more share on a worldwide basis and stretch out, that is also a good customer base for us. So by and large, next quarter, we'll be comps-based, both wireline and wireless, on a worldwide basis. The wireline side is tied heavily, I think, to the infrastructure part of the enterprise networking part. If that continues to be strong, the corporate profits being up are typically true signals of people buy IT equipment. If that continues to be strong in the first half of the calendar year, that bodes well for us for communications. And do I think there'll be some bumpiness throughout the year? Sure, there probably will, and comps will probably take a breather or the growth will update sometime during the year and flat now, probably will. But all the signs that we see right now shows us to be a year of very strong infrastructure play for a lot of companies.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So for just clarifications, the interest expense is negative two-ish, is that how you should think about it going forward, and the tax rate is $0.20, is that what we should think about going forward?
componenttext: So for just clarifications, the interest expense is negative two-ish, is that how you should think about it going forward, and the tax rate is $0.20, is that what we should think about going forward?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the net expense is driven by the fact that interest rates are so low, and the convertible debt expense that we have more than offsets that. And so depending on your position on what's going to happen, the interest rates this year, I guess, we
componenttext: Yes, I think the net expense is driven by the fact that interest rates are so low, and the convertible debt expense that we have more than offsets that. And so depending on your position on what's going to happen, the interest rates this year, I guess, we think they're going to be pretty low. I would say that that's a probably pretty reasonable forward-looking forecast on that. And the tax rate, as we've said in the past, we probably would be 20%, 21% going forward, so that's pretty reasonable as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Srini Pajjuri. [Calyon Securities]
componenttext: Our next question will come from Srini Pajjuri. [Calyon Securities]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Jon, just a clarification to the previous question, you said you require turns of about 55% which is lower than the last quarter. I'm just wondering why, I mean, given that you built some inventory, I would've expected turns requirement to be a little bit
componenttext: Jon, just a clarification to the previous question, you said you require turns of about 55% which is lower than the last quarter. I'm just wondering why, I mean, given that you built some inventory, I would've expected turns requirement to be a little bit higher than last quarter. I mean, are you seeing anything in your forecast from your customer that makes you a little cautious here, or are you just being conservative?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if you start off with the higher backlog number, that's really the key in this, so we have a higher backlog number in the turns. The percentages sometimes are deceiving. We've had such a strong growth pattern last quarter or two quarters ago. And la
componenttext: Well, if you start off with the higher backlog number, that's really the key in this, so we have a higher backlog number in the turns. The percentages sometimes are deceiving. We've had such a strong growth pattern last quarter or two quarters ago. And last quarter, the dollar turns per week, associated with these percentages, are starting to be a pretty large dollar on a dollar basis. So we are concerned that there is some concern that possibly, the other dollars are going to look unreasonable of what we could expect for the turns. If you take this midpoint 55% turns and dollarize it, it's about the same dollar turns that we had on a weekly basis last quarter in approximation. And that was a very high run rate for us from a historical perspective. So that being conservative, I don't know is it being realistic. I think it's probably being more realistic, more than it's being conservative.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, just to add the one for Moshe. Moshe, you said that some of the segments are still below your peak levels. Could you give a bit more color as to which segments you're talking about here and also given that your expectation that these segments will a
componenttext: Okay, just to add the one for Moshe. Moshe, you said that some of the segments are still below your peak levels. Could you give a bit more color as to which segments you're talking about here and also given that your expectation that these segments will also come back to the peak level in the next few quarters?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Even though we had a blowout record revenue quarter, six of the 10 segments that we follow are not at the level that they were when we hit the previous peak, which was $488 million, now which about $25 million less than this past quarter. And we expe
componenttext: Yes. Even though we had a blowout record revenue quarter, six of the 10 segments that we follow are not at the level that they were when we hit the previous peak, which was $488 million, now which about $25 million less than this past quarter. And we expect those segments over the next year, not necessarily only new [indiscernible], and there will be fluctuations. But we see room for growth based on looking at the end market. So the ones which we have, which hit the peaks are -- okay, the LO [Local Output] ones, okay, sorry. So wired, ISM [Industrial/Scientific/Medical], Test & Measurement, AVB, computing and storage have not yet hit the past peak, right. And those opportunities present to grow and hit that, and we see circular trends that can justify that. As Jon talks about Test & Measurement, we see a recovery in that area, and I hear it consistently from CEOs from those companies. They're seeing secular trends that are driving those requirements and their orders are starting to build out and after a very challenging period, and that's just one example. Jon talked about wireless, too. Industrial is sort of a grab bag for a whole host of smaller applications and that too, we see having the potential to grow and hit those peaks. So the bottom line there was we see opportunity of growth in these additional markets, and we expect that to happen over the next year for them to hit, hopefully even exceed their previous peaks, as they're transitioning to higher content in FPGA solutions...

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-20-2010

componenttext: Yes, for the most part, engineering samples are used for the testing process to verify everything. And so anything that we produce in engineering samples that we think are salable would've been valued in inventory already, so it's kind of a mixture of what happens in engineering samples.

componenttext: Okay, well thank you, all for joining us today. We have a playback of this call beginning at 5:00 p.m. Pacific, 8:00 p.m. Eastern today. For a copy of our earnings release, please visit our IR website. We will not be providing a scheduled mid-quarter update for the March ending quarter. This quarter, we'll be presenting at the Goldman Sachs and CLSA conferences in San Francisco. We will also be holding an Analyst Meeting on February 22. This completes our call. Thank you, all for your participation.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Casey, and I will be your conference operator today.
