headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Jon, when you say you're getting more way for allocation, are you suggesting that you're getting more way for allocation relative to other people who are acquiring those wafers or that net wafer supply is going up?
componenttext: Jon, when you say you're getting more way for allocation, are you suggesting that you're getting more way for allocation relative to other people who are acquiring those wafers or that net wafer supply is going up?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: For us, it's net wafer supply is going up. I can't really speak to how our foundries are allocating among their customers, but I think that more wafer capacity starts to come online towards the end, as the second half of the calendar year. And that's wher
componenttext: For us, it's net wafer supply is going up. I can't really speak to how our foundries are allocating among their customers, but I think that more wafer capacity starts to come online towards the end, as the second half of the calendar year. And that's where we're able to get commitments for relief on some of our issues that we have are short term right now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And it kind of seem that there's no meaningful change in wafer pricing that you see? And maybe the same question with respect to you, to your customers, any meaningful change in pricing?
componenttext: And it kind of seem that there's no meaningful change in wafer pricing that you see? And maybe the same question with respect to you, to your customers, any meaningful change in pricing?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: On the pricing front, we're not seeing any substantial increases in wafer costs across the board. But quite frankly, we're not seeing the decreases that we have planned on in our long-term roadmaps and have typically been able to negotiate. So it's for ho
componenttext: On the pricing front, we're not seeing any substantial increases in wafer costs across the board. But quite frankly, we're not seeing the decreases that we have planned on in our long-term roadmaps and have typically been able to negotiate. So it's for how we clear the foundries are trying to both surprise us to some degree, but we're not getting increases.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And do you pass the lack of decrease to your customers as well?
componenttext: And do you pass the lack of decrease to your customers as well?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Typically, not, and the reason, Glen, is, is that first off, a lot of our revenue is done by our top 10, top 15, top 20 customers, and they generally have volume price agreements that are negotiated anywhere from quarterly to annually. And so a fair amoun
componenttext: Typically, not, and the reason, Glen, is, is that first off, a lot of our revenue is done by our top 10, top 15, top 20 customers, and they generally have volume price agreements that are negotiated anywhere from quarterly to annually. And so a fair amount of our pricing is locked in, and so you don't typically have opportunities to pass those on until the renegotiation time. And of course, we'll do everything we can at that point to make sure we could maintain our margins. And the second point is, business is generally quoted far enough in advance more broadly that it is difficult to come in after the fact, after you've made a quote and raise it. So as new quotes are coming along, we certainly are mindful of what's going on in the environment and doing our best to hold prices up. But in terms of a radical change that you'd see in the P&L, just because we're trying to pass on "a surcharge" to all our airlines that comes immediate, that doesn't happen in our business model.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, having fallen short of your own shipment potential in the quarter, should we assume then that customers are not able to build inventory? Or do you really see some customers explicitly trying to build inventories of your parts?
componenttext: Obviously, having fallen short of your own shipment potential in the quarter, should we assume then that customers are not able to build inventory? Or do you really see some customers explicitly trying to build inventories of your parts?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: This is a question I know because semiconductor company's been asked. Our people building inventory in excess of their needs and what's your profile, et cetera. And quite frankly, from the Xilinx perspective, our growth has come from new products which ge
componenttext: This is a question I know because semiconductor company's been asked. Our people building inventory in excess of their needs and what's your profile, et cetera. And quite frankly, from the Xilinx perspective, our growth has come from new products which generally means new designs, et cetera. We've done a lot of work with our customers to try to understand whether they're really selling through or whether they're buffering inventory. And by and large, the responses coming, they're not buffering inventory and sell through is good. However, we do know of certain customers, even large customers, that we believe are buffering some inventory and are ordering farther in advance. And they don't seem -- as we've had some difficulty with lead times, they don't seem to be complaining broadly that there's lines down or whatever. So even though we can't find the data and anybody admitting to it such that inventories being built maybe in excess of their needs, it sure feels like some of what's going on is that. But on the other hand, we're selling a lot of new products, and we're pretty confident those are being sold through.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Uche Orji with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Uche Orji with UBS.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just ask you about your proposed ramp for new products as the U.S. starts to improve. What kind of impact should that have on margins as we're going through second half of the year? Are you going to be able to maintain your target range of 64% to 6
componenttext: Let me just ask you about your proposed ramp for new products as the U.S. starts to improve. What kind of impact should that have on margins as we're going through second half of the year? Are you going to be able to maintain your target range of 64% to 66% range?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Uche. I really think we're going to be able to maintain in that range of 65% for a few quarters despite some of the drag that's going on and then hopefully, improve after that. And there's a lot of different things that go on in margin relative to th
componenttext: Yes, Uche. I really think we're going to be able to maintain in that range of 65% for a few quarters despite some of the drag that's going on and then hopefully, improve after that. And there's a lot of different things that go on in margin relative to the product mix. And it's not just all about short-term cost changes based on yields, et cetera. But what we see as a very rapidly improving yield environment on 40-nm, 45-nm right now as we start building a lot of product, we think that we can maintain that range, 64% to 66%, 65-ish kind of a number going while we're going through this yields ramps, and then we'll see what happens as we get to the end of the year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: On the relative impact of your being constrained. Obviously, Altera has outgrown you this quarter and also within the guide, they seem to be outgrowing you. How much of, granted, you both have different seasonalities around some of the year, but one can't
componenttext: On the relative impact of your being constrained. Obviously, Altera has outgrown you this quarter and also within the guide, they seem to be outgrowing you. How much of, granted, you both have different seasonalities around some of the year, but one can't help but notice that it looks like you're losing market share. How much of this do you think you can regain once you've got to see capacity ease? And then just how on confident you are. I mean if one looks at UMC's CapEx spend, very high end versus CSMC [ph], is it fair to just conclude that it's inevitable you're going to lose market share?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So let me get the first part of that question. So while we are constrained, we don't think we're losing any customers or designs as a result of these short-term constraints. So I don't think that this situation that we have on these selected products has
componenttext: So let me get the first part of that question. So while we are constrained, we don't think we're losing any customers or designs as a result of these short-term constraints. So I don't think that this situation that we have on these selected products has any bearing in just the pure -- did somebody get more share, win share or lose share. So I don't think that really has anything. We had a prolonged situation that might cause customers to redesign but it's pretty costly to redesign when you're in these very sticky, complex SoC situations. And behind larger, there's a lot of other semiconductor companies scrambling to provide product to some of our same customers, and I don't believe we're on the top of the constraint list, quite frankly, for most of our large customers. And then with respect to the foundry differences and CapEx spending and capacity as to any sort of market share shift one way or the other, I don't think that has any bearing on the situation at all. I think if you look at the seasonality, it's typical that Altera has outgrown us in the front end of the year, and then we outgrow them in the back end of the year. So I don't see any huge share shift going on this year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Moshe, you're going to design into comm equipment, and this market tends to be traditionally made of PowerPC. And how do you plan to kind of drive acceptance of this? I mean, what are the relative merits of this strategy you've adopted?
componenttext: Moshe, you're going to design into comm equipment, and this market tends to be traditionally made of PowerPC. And how do you plan to kind of drive acceptance of this? I mean, what are the relative merits of this strategy you've adopted?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Uche, if you look at the list of markets that we've gone through as target, it goes well beyond comm equipment. So this a very good product offering. It is by far, the most successful embedded architecture. It continues to grow its market share. The other
componenttext: Uche, if you look at the list of markets that we've gone through as target, it goes well beyond comm equipment. So this a very good product offering. It is by far, the most successful embedded architecture. It continues to grow its market share. The other popular architectures that you've just mentioned are actually losing market share in all of the markets including communication. And so this is the beginning of an expansion beyond our traditional markets, and this facilitates our growth in the best way possible. So having a very tightly integrated, applicable ARM core, it was probably the easiest decision to make for this family, and we have tremendous expectations. It wasn't products announcement, it was a more of an architectural announcement to be made. But as we come up with the product announcement, I think you'll see that this provides unparalleled capabilities for huge range of applications. And this is one of those products that absolutely will enable us to accelerate the programmable imperative, in particular, replace ASSP. And I have gone on record on that, and I know you guys will continue to needle me on that particular point. We have data which shows that, that is happening and it's happening in space now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Jon, just I want to make sure I understand on the supply constraints. You said about $10 million to $11 million in revenue in the March quarter and you could expect to see a like amount in the June quarter, did I read that right?
componenttext: Jon, just I want to make sure I understand on the supply constraints. You said about $10 million to $11 million in revenue in the March quarter and you could expect to see a like amount in the June quarter, did I read that right?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, I think it will be that much and maybe even a little more.
componenttext: Yes, John, I think it will be that much and maybe even a little more.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And so help me understand, as we move into September, do we think about sort of phantom backlog of $25 million of catch up as your supply starts to come on, or how is that business then migrate into the back half of the year?
componenttext: And so help me understand, as we move into September, do we think about sort of phantom backlog of $25 million of catch up as your supply starts to come on, or how is that business then migrate into the back half of the year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so since we're not really forecasting what the overall profile of September. The September quarter has typically been a slower quarter for us, as generally, particularly Wireline. But generally, communications customers are awful lot in the summer an
componenttext: Yes, so since we're not really forecasting what the overall profile of September. The September quarter has typically been a slower quarter for us, as generally, particularly Wireline. But generally, communications customers are awful lot in the summer and Europe is paused and whatever. So I want to be hesitant to say that, gee, we're going to roll over 15, 20 or some amount. And that's going to be added to some run rate. I don't really want to -- I don't want you to walk away with that statement. But I do think, what I'm trying to make it is this $10 million to maybe $15 million we left this quarter we could have shipped. It's going to be that much and a little bit more, little bit more than that, potentially. It could just be that much. I doubt that we'll be fully caught up.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, Jon, I apologize if you had mentioned this, but as you look at the profile of revenue growth in the June quarter by end market, any big differences that you see out there?
componenttext: And then I guess, Jon, I apologize if you had mentioned this, but as you look at the profile of revenue growth in the June quarter by end market, any big differences that you see out there?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The biggest is going to be -- is Wireless. So we had a very strong Wireless business this last quarter, driven primarily out of our European customers. You could see that on our European revenue split. And then as we move into June, the Wireless businesse
componenttext: The biggest is going to be -- is Wireless. So we had a very strong Wireless business this last quarter, driven primarily out of our European customers. You could see that on our European revenue split. And then as we move into June, the Wireless businesses, we think is even going to increase more. And that's going to be driven both of the European customer base that's serving the world, as well as the China 3G Phase 4 business, which is starting to ramp and those customers are starting to take products in a big way basically this quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I know the design cycle is relatively long, but Altera did put up some outsize to gross margins in their quarter. Just kind of curious if that gives you a pricing umbrella to get a little bit better pricing and/or an opportunity to go out there and try to
componenttext: I know the design cycle is relatively long, but Altera did put up some outsize to gross margins in their quarter. Just kind of curious if that gives you a pricing umbrella to get a little bit better pricing and/or an opportunity to go out there and try to gain some share?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we certainly have -- we did talk about it a little bit earlier and it's really hard to have short-term pricing impact that show up on the P&L immediately. But we're aware of the environment and our supply chain and what's going on there. And while
componenttext: Yes, so we certainly have -- we did talk about it a little bit earlier and it's really hard to have short-term pricing impact that show up on the P&L immediately. But we're aware of the environment and our supply chain and what's going on there. And while we don't want to lose the business out there, we certainly are going to do everything we can to get the most value out of our products, if that means raising some prices, then we'll do that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of James Schneider with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of James Schneider with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess you as well as many of your peers have talked about increased visibility going into the back half of the year or customers placing longer-dated backlog on you. First of all, I just want to confirm that that's indeed what you're seeing. And then in
componenttext: I guess you as well as many of your peers have talked about increased visibility going into the back half of the year or customers placing longer-dated backlog on you. First of all, I just want to confirm that that's indeed what you're seeing. And then in the context of that, what are you seeing from your Asian comms [communications] customers into the back half of the year, of the calendar year, do you think that's going to continue to see the strength you're expecting in Q2 or might that tail off a little bit?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim. The backlog situation, we're definitely seeing products being booked out farther. So they're out farther within the current quarter and also more into the following quarter. And I think that's really more of a function of lead time increases on
componenttext: Sure, Jim. The backlog situation, we're definitely seeing products being booked out farther. So they're out farther within the current quarter and also more into the following quarter. And I think that's really more of a function of lead time increases on selected parts than anything else. Our overall backlog going into the quarter was up 20% over the backlog going into the previous quarter, so quite substantially. But a lot of that was our leading product families as the constraints are becoming clear to people and they're ordering out to make sure they get supply. So I view this as kind of a fleeting thing that when lead time start to move back in, that the backlog will return to normal patterns for us by and large. The second question was around our Asia communications customers in the second half of the calendar year. I really don't have much visibility on that. I know that they certainly are telling us they're going to ramp very strong this summer relative to Phase 4 business. But beyond that, we have pretty limited visibility as to whether this is going to continue or not.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could just do a follow-up on the OpEx. What should we expect in terms of the profile of spending throughout the fiscal year? And specifically, if you just exclude the effects of variable SG&A related to higher sales or lower sales?
componenttext: And if I could just do a follow-up on the OpEx. What should we expect in terms of the profile of spending throughout the fiscal year? And specifically, if you just exclude the effects of variable SG&A related to higher sales or lower sales?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: It's pretty hard to do the latter, because it is part of what we're doing. I mean, we forecasted $182 million for OpEx for next quarter. And I think you can see that is a reasonable number for the next several quarters going forward. There could be some a
componenttext: It's pretty hard to do the latter, because it is part of what we're doing. I mean, we forecasted $182 million for OpEx for next quarter. And I think you can see that is a reasonable number for the next several quarters going forward. There could be some adjustments relative to if we have sharper spikes in revenue, up or down, or profitability, up or down, that deals with those variable expenses. But I think if you're trying to draw some sort of a line for us, pretty flat this year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So no big spikes due to tape outs on your products, in the R&D line?
componenttext: So no big spikes due to tape outs on your products, in the R&D line?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: No, there is a beginning of the tape outs for the next generation, in the back half of our fiscal year more likely the fourth quarter of fiscal year, and there's some leftovers going on right now in this quarter. And in the next two quarters, there are fe
componenttext: No, there is a beginning of the tape outs for the next generation, in the back half of our fiscal year more likely the fourth quarter of fiscal year, and there's some leftovers going on right now in this quarter. And in the next two quarters, there are few other things going on to help offset that. So that's why it's kind of ends up being relatively flat.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Webster with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Webster with Macquarie.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Jon, I think you mentioned that there were some customers you weren't sure out there that may have built extra inventory. Maybe just stepping back a bit, if you can assess the end market, are there certain end markets that you feel like they're sufficient
componenttext: Jon, I think you mentioned that there were some customers you weren't sure out there that may have built extra inventory. Maybe just stepping back a bit, if you can assess the end market, are there certain end markets that you feel like they're sufficiently supplied or their inventories are normal versus others which are leaner than normal?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think I can draw any specifics around that at all. It's really different by different end market, whether certain subsegments within those end markets are really well populated or not, with inventory. So I would say, I know that communication
componenttext: Yes, I don't think I can draw any specifics around that at all. It's really different by different end market, whether certain subsegments within those end markets are really well populated or not, with inventory. So I would say, I know that communications customer to -- that it sounds like they're buffering inventory, I see some industrial customers that are doing that. So it's really kind of spreads out.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the tightness that you experienced, when -- maybe it's not exactly, but when did you start to seeing the tightness or unexpected tightness in your products over the course of the March quarter end? Could you share those -- what your m
componenttext: And then in terms of the tightness that you experienced, when -- maybe it's not exactly, but when did you start to seeing the tightness or unexpected tightness in your products over the course of the March quarter end? Could you share those -- what your mix of 40-nanometer is or was in the March quarter?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We're not segregating out individual technologies within our new products, to talk about that. But the tightness, we've been tight probably for four or five months, but because demand has been so good for Virtex-5, which is where the primary issues are th
componenttext: We're not segregating out individual technologies within our new products, to talk about that. But the tightness, we've been tight probably for four or five months, but because demand has been so good for Virtex-5, which is where the primary issues are that's where we're experiencing the tightness. It just got strong, it just got to be a bigger issue for us because the ordering patterns were so strong for V-5 [Virtex-5].

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra with Robert Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra with Robert Baird.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Is your reason for Automotive to decline in the June quarter based on difficult comparison or is there anything else happening in that end market?
componenttext: Is your reason for Automotive to decline in the June quarter based on difficult comparison or is there anything else happening in that end market?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Tristan, I didn't get which end market you're asking about. Could you repeat that?
componenttext: I'm sorry, Tristan, I didn't get which end market you're asking about. Could you repeat that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: In Automotive, I think you mentioned that you expected some decline in the June quarter.
componenttext: In Automotive, I think you mentioned that you expected some decline in the June quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Automotive has been really strong the last couple of quarters and the last three quarters actually and some of that was the snapback from just the auto industry going on. But then as things picked up, it kept getting progressively stronger, some o
componenttext: Yes, so Automotive has been really strong the last couple of quarters and the last three quarters actually and some of that was the snapback from just the auto industry going on. But then as things picked up, it kept getting progressively stronger, some of that is just a more healthy auto industry. But some of it is also us taking more share within the automobile -- inside the in car from alternative sources. Again, this is a great example of ASSPs [application-specific standard products] being supplanted by PLDs [programmable logic devices]. And some of the designs that we have been talking about over the last year or so are now starting to kick in and we're starting to see the beginning of more penetration in addition to just more autos being sold. Now the decline aspect is mostly just a little bit of a leveling off and a slight decline, not a significant decline.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then your gross margin is currently at about a five-year high and you said that you have confidence you're going to hold to those level in the second half of the calendar year. But at the same time, as pricing comes down we should also expect consumer
componenttext: And then your gross margin is currently at about a five-year high and you said that you have confidence you're going to hold to those level in the second half of the calendar year. But at the same time, as pricing comes down we should also expect consumer mix to pick up in the second half. You're also going to ramp at the 40-nanometer geometry node. Are yield improvements the only reason to offset those factors and giving you the confidence that your gross margin can hold?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly the yield improvements as we go through the next couple of quarters have pretty sharp yield improvement that does help. But also, as we get into the back half of the year, in addition to consumer growing, Aerospace and Defense also typical
componenttext: Well, certainly the yield improvements as we go through the next couple of quarters have pretty sharp yield improvement that does help. But also, as we get into the back half of the year, in addition to consumer growing, Aerospace and Defense also typically grows for us, and that's a good offset. So the end market mix, we're not necessarily believing that's going to have a huge impact on us. The headwinds on next quarter, quite frankly, of the fact that we have a lot of V-6 [Virtex-6] that we're starting to ramp up and it's being sold into Wireless, which is one of our -- of all our end markets maybe the most challenging on pricing and margin. But at the same time, we have a number of cost reduction efforts that have been kicking in and helping give us an offset. So the forecast of 65 plus or minus a point, so it could be down a point, it could be up a point. It's really dependent on how all the factors I just talked about turn out.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Danely with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Danely with JPMorgan.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess just a little bit of history on the lead time issue. I think I remember last year somewhere towards like mid, late year, we first started talking about delivery issues and lead time problems. So is this an extension of that same issue? Was it diff
componenttext: I guess just a little bit of history on the lead time issue. I think I remember last year somewhere towards like mid, late year, we first started talking about delivery issues and lead time problems. So is this an extension of that same issue? Was it different? Is it different products or is just that same problem just lasting until now?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Totally different. Chris, this is Moshe. It's totally different. Last year, if you remember and it's sort of amazing when you think back. The semiconductor industry was dead and being buried at the end of Q1 and as a result all of the foundries were shutt
componenttext: Totally different. Chris, this is Moshe. It's totally different. Last year, if you remember and it's sort of amazing when you think back. The semiconductor industry was dead and being buried at the end of Q1 and as a result all of the foundries were shutting down, all of the infrastructure for the foundry business was shutting down, and then it turns, snapped back in the most amazing way. And there were some major issues as the foundries have been closed to reopen them and to bring capacity back online. And we got impacted by that, I believe it was the second quarter or the second calendar quarter in a big way. A lot of other players got impacted by that actually, later in the year. What is happening now is just incredibly robust environment where foundries are operating at their peak capacity and they're scrambling to bring up additional capacity, in particular, in advance process nodes. So I wouldn't say it's the same, plummet for us, it hit us for one quarter, the June quarter of 2009 and once it snapped back and the capacity came online, as Jon pointed out, we've now going into -- we're in our second quarter and will go into the third quarter of challenges in terms of expanding capacity. But it's a different problem and it's predominantly at the most advanced process nodes, but not restricted to them.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And this time around, have there been any yield issues, or is it purely been demand that's been much better than you expected and the wafer supply has not ramped as much as you expected?
componenttext: And this time around, have there been any yield issues, or is it purely been demand that's been much better than you expected and the wafer supply has not ramped as much as you expected?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: It's the latter, for sure.
componenttext: It's the latter, for sure.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly 65-nanometer, we're continuing to focus on improving yields there because the leverage for us is so significant both for parts and units and margin there. The 40-nanometer process, while we are the lead customer for UMC on that process. We
componenttext: Yes, certainly 65-nanometer, we're continuing to focus on improving yields there because the leverage for us is so significant both for parts and units and margin there. The 40-nanometer process, while we are the lead customer for UMC on that process. We are on our roadmap for yields in that product family and generation. So we've not deviated from our roadmap.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Now that we're sitting on tons of cash provided the government doesn't come and take it away from you, in terms of usage of cash, between paying debt down, buying back stock, increasing dividend, can you just maybe discuss that a little bit?
componenttext: Now that we're sitting on tons of cash provided the government doesn't come and take it away from you, in terms of usage of cash, between paying debt down, buying back stock, increasing dividend, can you just maybe discuss that a little bit?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Our net cash is at $1.3 billion, which is higher than we -- than our target. We like to be below $1 billion. Buying the debt back at the current price is not a good MPV situation for us at all, because of some of the tax advantages we get out o
componenttext: Yes, sure. Our net cash is at $1.3 billion, which is higher than we -- than our target. We like to be below $1 billion. Buying the debt back at the current price is not a good MPV situation for us at all, because of some of the tax advantages we get out of that particular instrument that we did. So we did raise our dividend in this past year, a couple of quarters ago. We have continued to buyback shares in this last quarter, $125 million worth, so we are committed to both increasing dividends on a go-forward basis and taking any other cash above our targets, cash targets and doing share repurchase with that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I need some help in understanding the Wireless revenues, and if you can put it in context of the Wireless CapEx. Last year, your Wireless revenues grew, I'd say close to 30%, and you're running at a record level and looks like if you stay on this course,
componenttext: I need some help in understanding the Wireless revenues, and if you can put it in context of the Wireless CapEx. Last year, your Wireless revenues grew, I'd say close to 30%, and you're running at a record level and looks like if you stay on this course, you can grow about the same amount. Whereas, we hear in the headline number, the Wireless CapEx going to be flattish. So can you help in reconciling, is it your content increasing or how should we take the headline CapEx number and think about your Wireless revenues?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: From my perspective, Mahesh, it is true that maybe there's a reduction, but primarily on the newest protocols and the upgrading of the equipment to the -- for example, 3G in China that continues at a very fast rate and they're doing it in phases and this
componenttext: From my perspective, Mahesh, it is true that maybe there's a reduction, but primarily on the newest protocols and the upgrading of the equipment to the -- for example, 3G in China that continues at a very fast rate and they're doing it in phases and this coming phase, the fourth round is a very significant one. And we're seeing it in China, we're seeing upgrade in North America and potentially Western Europe to 4G over time. And they're still waiting for the Indian portion to pan out. But it's continuing to grow and Wireless continues to do well and best we can tell it's going to continue to be a driver going forward. It is possible that it could have been even better or it could be even better if they increase CapEx, but we don't see a slowdown on these new deployments. We rarely see that happening. If you look at what is -- everything that we're aware of is this insatiable demand for bandwidth, all of the new widgets that everyone is using now are data and video driven, and there's just huge demand. And basically, the networks, the data communication networks are having great problems and they have to be upgraded. And you've seen cases, very public cases, where some of the big carriers have actually stopped selling devices because their network can't handle the bandwidth. That's not a viable business for them to continue to stay in that model. So I'm quite bullish on Wireless and it's possible that it could have been even greater, but we see it continue at a very positive level.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And one more quick one on that $10 million and $15 million probably you will lose. So what happens to the customer which didn't get your part? Is it that they just are not able to ship those parts, or are they are going to get that late? Where does the re
componenttext: And one more quick one on that $10 million and $15 million probably you will lose. So what happens to the customer which didn't get your part? Is it that they just are not able to ship those parts, or are they are going to get that late? Where does the requirement go away? I mean, because you're saying that you might not get it back in September, necessarily. How do we reconcile that missed revenues?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I couldn't call that missed revenues. I think you misconstrued what Jon said. Some of the customers are building inventory. If we had additional product, we could help them short term. If not, these products are typically sole sourced. So as long as they
componenttext: I couldn't call that missed revenues. I think you misconstrued what Jon said. Some of the customers are building inventory. If we had additional product, we could help them short term. If not, these products are typically sole sourced. So as long as they continue to build and sell their equipment, and keep in mind that we're in an infrastructure play as opposed to consumer play. So the upgrades do happen, then we do get that business and it will hopefully build up and that's why we're scrambling to get it to those customers as soon as we can.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Any specific customer that doesn't get their parts in the last week or the second last week of the quarter will get it two weeks later. And it's a series of events that create these delinquencies over time. It isn't like the same customer won't get everyt
componenttext: Any specific customer that doesn't get their parts in the last week or the second last week of the quarter will get it two weeks later. And it's a series of events that create these delinquencies over time. It isn't like the same customer won't get everything that they want at the end of this quarter and at the end of next quarter. It's not necessarily -- it doesn't work that way. We have so many customers and such a broad focus, and we are responding with getting more parts out to meet the customers' orders. And so it could be different part packages for different customers that could be short at the end of one quarter versus another quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri with CLSA.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Jon, a couple of clarifications. On OpEx, I was that it would come down in the second half of the year. Just wondering if you're planning to spend on any additional tape outs or if this is mostly revenue related?
componenttext: Jon, a couple of clarifications. On OpEx, I was that it would come down in the second half of the year. Just wondering if you're planning to spend on any additional tape outs or if this is mostly revenue related?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So the back half of the year is -- and particularly our fourth quarter of our fiscal year is definitely impacted by 28-nanometer tape out, so the ramp for the next generation begins. So that's one of the things that's impacting it. But we are holding the
componenttext: So the back half of the year is -- and particularly our fourth quarter of our fiscal year is definitely impacted by 28-nanometer tape out, so the ramp for the next generation begins. So that's one of the things that's impacting it. But we are holding the line on our resourcing level and with that putting out more products, including the follow-on announcement that will come from our ARM relationships. So we are, I think doing a good job of not growing R&D dollars while being able to address additional markets in addition to the traditional PLD segment.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the Defense business, Jon, you said it's down sequentially, which is somewhat different from what some of your peers are reporting. Just wondering, I'm talking, I'm sorry, the Industrial business. Wondering if the Defense decline explains all
componenttext: And then on the Defense business, Jon, you said it's down sequentially, which is somewhat different from what some of your peers are reporting. Just wondering, I'm talking, I'm sorry, the Industrial business. Wondering if the Defense decline explains all of the weakness in Industrial or if this segment is somewhat also a supply constraint?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: No, the Defense is -- no, it's not supply -- generally that's not supply constraint. Defense decline does explain the drop in our Industrial and other category. The other subsegments were flat to up. So it really is just the Defense. And there is a season
componenttext: No, the Defense is -- no, it's not supply -- generally that's not supply constraint. Defense decline does explain the drop in our Industrial and other category. The other subsegments were flat to up. So it really is just the Defense. And there is a seasonal pattern to Defense that we've had pretty pronounced over the last five years as we've grown our Defense business substantially. And it's typified by a weaker March and June, and a stronger September and December, which September quarters and December quarters bracket the beginning of the government fiscal year where a lot of the purchasing activities tend to happen.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Wong with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Wong with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The ramp in 40-nanometer, 45-nanometer products, do they open up any particular new segments or new product types for you that you're selling into?
componenttext: The ramp in 40-nanometer, 45-nanometer products, do they open up any particular new segments or new product types for you that you're selling into?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: As they bring down the power, as they bring down the price, they enable us to address a whole host of new markets and actually to replace ASICs [application-specific integrated circuits] and ASSPs in more aggressive way. So it does broaden and deepen our
componenttext: As they bring down the power, as they bring down the price, they enable us to address a whole host of new markets and actually to replace ASICs [application-specific integrated circuits] and ASSPs in more aggressive way. So it does broaden and deepen our reach into the applications, we can address. Even in some of our traditional markets, for example, if you look at military or communications infrastructure, when you move into the 40-nanometer and 45-nanometer node, we can compete with ASICs and ASSPs in a more aggressive manner. So it's both new applications, but also deepening inside the existing traditional applications we have.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you point to any new types of systems you haven't been in before? Can you give us any specific examples?
componenttext: Can you point to any new types of systems you haven't been in before? Can you give us any specific examples?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you can look at examples in the high end of the consumer world, where we're seeing the next generation of a lot of the displays. That is something where I think we will expand our reach and it continues -- we had some -- there in past generations, b
componenttext: Well, you can look at examples in the high end of the consumer world, where we're seeing the next generation of a lot of the displays. That is something where I think we will expand our reach and it continues -- we had some -- there in past generations, but I believe becomes a lot more attractive when you have something like our 45-nanometer Spartan-6 product. That sort of the most cost sensitive side of the overall business. If you go with the high end of our business, actually in the military space you can address a whole host of new applications, where there are actually significant volumes of these products and those in the past were not accessible to us and in the distant past used to be served just by ASIC. So it really raises the water line for across the board in terms of the applications we conserve it.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Apurva Patel. [Ticonderoga Securities]
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Apurva Patel. [Ticonderoga Securities]

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of your ARM-based architecture, unified architecture. Do you believe you need to have additional software capability?
componenttext: In terms of your ARM-based architecture, unified architecture. Do you believe you need to have additional software capability?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, software is a lot of things. So when you look at the implementation software, which is necessary in order to design the FPGA [Field Programmable Gate Array], in of itself you do need additional capabilities because you now have very applicable high-
componenttext: Well, software is a lot of things. So when you look at the implementation software, which is necessary in order to design the FPGA [Field Programmable Gate Array], in of itself you do need additional capabilities because you now have very applicable high-performance ARM core and you want to make that accessible to the customer. And so that requires an expansion which is targeted with the embedded hardware that we have. When you go beyond that then there are layers of software which get closer and closer to the target applications. Those by and large are not provided by us, they are available through the extensive ARM ecosystem, which is unparalleled in terms of the support it has broad set of applications. So yes, there are demands but they are serviced, in some cases by us, in other cases by the ecosystem. And of course, ARM does provide quite a bit of that, too.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of your comms business, you referred that wireless, again, is driven by skew in the bandwidth and wireless side. But when did the pull commence on the wired side?
componenttext: And in terms of your comms business, you referred that wireless, again, is driven by skew in the bandwidth and wireless side. But when did the pull commence on the wired side?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So the wired side, a lot of the Wired side is related to network and infrastructure associated with Internet and that particular part of the bandwidth pipe. So that strength has been happening particularly as IT departments and companies are starting to b
componenttext: So the wired side, a lot of the Wired side is related to network and infrastructure associated with Internet and that particular part of the bandwidth pipe. So that strength has been happening particularly as IT departments and companies are starting to buy more equipment. So we're obviously very active in routers and in data switches and things like that. So that business has come back very sharply for us over the last couple of quarters, and we think that's going to continue.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And so our new products are generally based on when the product was introduced into the market, and they tend to be obviously then as a result our highest technology. So 40, 45-nanometer products, 65 nanometer products, and then the very tail end of 90-na
componenttext: And so our new products are generally based on when the product was introduced into the market, and they tend to be obviously then as a result our highest technology. So 40, 45-nanometer products, 65 nanometer products, and then the very tail end of 90-nanometer. Every two years or so, we realign those, obviously as the generations move forward. We anticipate the new products to continue to grow throughout the fiscal year, and the way things look like right now, quite strongly, and then sequential quarter growth every quarter throughout the year. The mainstream and base products are -- by definition, then are older and oldest generation, and they tend to have a different kind of profile. So the base being the oldest of them generally declines quarter after quarter after quarter, and the mainstream declines a little less quarter after quarter. And that's depending on how older designs, the long tail of PLD designs, what the pattern is for replacements out in the market or not. And so if you were drawing a set of lines, you'd say new products a very positive, sloping up to the right, mainstream generally a gentle slope down to the left, and then base products more sharp decline down to the right. Sorry, both down to the right.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: There are lots of them. There's a whole host of industrial applications where there used to be some traditional ASSP solutions, which -- and now they're at the end of the life and there's no roadmap for them. So we're actually seeing a lot of those device
componenttext: There are lots of them. There's a whole host of industrial applications where there used to be some traditional ASSP solutions, which -- and now they're at the end of the life and there's no roadmap for them. So we're actually seeing a lot of those devices -- military is even another example where that device, it could been a dedicated microcontroller, is now being implemented inside an FPGA. So this is pervasive, it's not limited to Automotive. Automotive is maybe one interesting application, but this does happen across the board pretty broadly. And it's driven by the fact that new process nodes it becomes prohibitively expensive to design an ASSP, and some of these ASSPs were designed at 130-nanometers, for example, and the companies that design them can't afford to take them forward to new aggressive nodes and the customers are stuck. And you can implement those 130 and even 90-nanometer ASSP, sometimes quite cost effectively in advanced state-of-the-art FPGAs, and that is what is happening on a broad basis.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And motor control and industrial would be one, solid-state storage, device controllers and there's examples of where people have typically used ASSPs in order to perform those functions that now needing custom algorithms to improve energy consumption and
componenttext: And motor control and industrial would be one, solid-state storage, device controllers and there's examples of where people have typically used ASSPs in order to perform those functions that now needing custom algorithms to improve energy consumption and motor control, for example, et cetera, are using FPGAs for that, not ASSPs.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you all for joining us today. We have a playback of this call beginning at 5 p.m. Pacific, 8 p.m. Eastern. For a copy of our earnings release, please visit our IR website. Our next earnings release date for the first quarter of fiscal 20
componenttext: Okay. Well, thank you all for joining us today. We have a playback of this call beginning at 5 p.m. Pacific, 8 p.m. Eastern. For a copy of our earnings release, please visit our IR website. Our next earnings release date for the first quarter of fiscal 2011 will be Wednesday, July 21, after the market closes. This quarter we'll be presenting at the JPMorgan Technology Conference in Boston and the UBS Tech Conference in New York City. This completes our call. Thank you very much for your participation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Josh, and I will be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx first quarter fiscal year 2011 earnings release conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. Af
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Josh, and I will be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx first quarter fiscal year 2011 earnings release conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers’ remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. (Operator instructions)
I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Maria Quillard. Thank you. Ms. Quillard, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everyone, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter. And then we’ll open the call up for questions.Let me remind everyone that during our co
componenttext:
Thank you, everyone, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter. And then we’ll open the call up for questions.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially.
We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs, and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.
This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Investor Relations Website.
Now, let me turn the call over to Jon Olson.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria. During today’s commentary, I will review our June quarter business results. I will conclude my remarks by providing guidance for the September quarter.The June quarter was a strong quarter setting records for both sales and operating
componenttext:
Thank you, Maria. During today’s commentary, I will review our June quarter business results. I will conclude my remarks by providing guidance for the September quarter.
The June quarter was a strong quarter setting records for both sales and operating income. With sales of $595 million, we set a record for the third consecutive quarter. Operating income reached an historic high of $208 million.
This operating income performance represents a year-over-year increase of 263%, over four times the rate of sales increase during the same period. The operating leverage was a direct result of not only the significant growth in revenue, but was greatly enhanced by the restructuring actions and cost reduction efforts driven at the company over the past two years.
June quarter sales of $595 million increased 12% sequentially, better than expected sales growth was driven primarily by strong new product growth, as well as across the board strength in the industrial and other category. Sales for the first two months of the quarter were in line with our expectations while the third month was stronger than expected.
Turns business for the quarter was 53%, down from 56% in the prior quarter. Xilinx remained supply constrained throughout the quarter and we have not experienced measurable lead time improvements.
Delinquencies exiting the quarter were in line with our expectations. However, demand has been and continues to be stronger than anticipated in both the June and September quarters. As a result, we do not expect supply constrains to be fully resolved for at least a couple of more quarters.
While we are growing wafers out quarter-by-quarter from our foundry network, the supply chain remains at full capacity. Based on the increases in wafers, we believe that delinquencies can be kept from growing further.
Gross margin at 65%, was up from 61.8% in the same quarter a year ago. In the past year gross margin has benefited from the implementation of supply chain efficiencies and greater focus on cost reduction.
Operating expenses decreased 5% sequentially, more than anticipated, due to lower R&D spending, which is a result of delayed hiring and a push out of contract engineering services to future quarters. As a result, operating income increased 33% sequentially to a record $208 million or 35% of sales. This is up from 30% in the prior quarter and up from 15% in the same quarter a year ago.
New product sales increased 23% sequentially in the June quarter to 39% of sales, driven by exceptionally strong growth from Virtex-5 as well as our newest Virtex-6 family.
Sales from our Virtex-6 and Spartan-6 families were up substantially. Mainstream products increased 9% sequentially, representing 30% of total sales and base products increased 4% sequentially to 27% of total.
Europe was our strongest geography during the quarter with sales increasing 19% sequentially. Most end markets in Europe posted strong double-digit growth with the sales from wireless communications representing the largest incremental increase.
North American sales increased 12% sequentially driven by defense, wire communications and industrial, scientific and medical applications. Asia Pacific sales increased 11% sequentially with strength from wired and wireless communications, consumer and industrial applications. Sales from Japan were essentially flat for the quarter.
From an end market perspective, Communications sales increased 12% sequentially. Both wireless and wireline communications increased during the quarter.
Industrial and other sales reached a new record, increasing 21% sequentially with double-digit sequential increases from defense, industrial, scientific, and medical and test and measurement.
Over the past five years, sales from this category have more than doubled, a strong testament to the fact that PLDs are gaining ground versus ASICs and ASSPs in these markets.
Consumer and Automotive sales increased 8% sequentially, driven by strength in audio, video, broadcast and consumer applications.
Lastly, sales from Data Processing decreased as anticipated due primarily to the timing of customer programs.
Net income during the quarter was $159 million or $0.58 per diluted share. Other income and expenses was a net expense of $5 million. This was higher than the $2 million net expense number we estimated at the beginning of the quarter, primarily due to the impact of the debt issuance and any delay in recognizing the gain on the sale of an investment.
Operating cash flow for the March quarter was $107 million before $18 million in CapEx. During the quarter, Xilinx issued $600 million in convertible senior notes. We used $433 million in proceeds from this issuance to repurchase 16.3 million shares. We also paid $44 million in cash dividends. The tax rate in the June quarter was 22%.
In total, this quarter’s strong financial performance resulted in a return on equity of 32%, up from 8% in the same quarter a year ago. Improved profitability as well as the recent issuance of convertible debt for the primary purpose of share repurchase drove the majority of this improvement.
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments increased $155 million during the quarter to approximately $2.1 billion. We now have approximately $1.3 billion in convertible debt on our balance sheet, which included the recent convertible issuance. Our net cash position is approximately $800 million.
Day sales outstanding increased nine days in the June quarter to 54 days. Combined inventory days in the June quarter were 80, up from 79 in the prior quarter.
As I mentioned earlier in my remarks, our overall supply chain remains tight. However, we have been able to meet customers’ critical needs despite the delinquency levels we are experiencing. In the September quarter we expect inventory days to be approximately flat
Let me now turn the discussion to guidance for the September quarter FY 11. Our backlog heading into the quarter is up. We are expecting to see continued strength from Virtex-5, as well as continued strong growth from our new Virtex-6 and Spartan-6 families.
From an end market perspective, we are expecting sales from communications to be up driven primarily by strength in wireless communications. Coming off of very strong quarter industrial and other sales are expected to decrease slightly primarily due to decreases from defense as well as industrial, scientific, and medical and test and measurement.
Consumer and automotive sales are expected to be up sequentially, driven by increased consumer and audio/video broadcast sales. Lastly, data processing is expected increased driven by both storage and server applications.
As a result, we are expecting total sales to be up 3% to 7% sequentially in the September quarter with sales in North America declining and sales from all other regions increasing. The mid-point of our sales guidance is predicated on turns rate of approximately 48%. This is down from the 53% in the June quarter.
Our belief is that due to the extended lead time situation we are more fully booked than in previous quarters. Gross margin is expected to be 65% plus or minus a point. Operating expenses in the September quarter are expected to be approximately $185 million.
The increase in expense is related to increased engineering hiring to support next generation programs, expenses associated with contract engineering services and higher variable in selling and compensation expenses associated with our higher revenue and profit levels.
Other income and expense is expected to be a net expense of approximately $4 million. The share count is expected to be 264 million shares as the impact of our recent accelerated share purchase is fully reflected, but offset somewhat by share issuance associated with our annual focal and review processes. The tax rate for fiscal 2011 is expected to be 22%.
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and good afternoon to you all. We are delighted to deliver our third consecutive quarter of record revenues, highlighting that the customer demand side of the business remained very healthy.Six of our end market segments increased by do
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and good afternoon to you all. We are delighted to deliver our third consecutive quarter of record revenues, highlighting that the customer demand side of the business remained very healthy.
Six of our end market segments increased by double digit sequentially, wireless, defense, industrial, test and measurement, AVB and consumer is very board based market strength resulted us easily beating the high end of our revenue guidance range for the June ending quarter.
In addition with our 3% to 7% sales growth forecast from September quarter we’re expecting better than normal summer seasonality. The reason we are feeling positive about the September quarter is that orders are already well booked and our starting backlog is up significantly.
Turning to the supply side of our business, continued to serve our consumer needs, but we remain constraint primarily by foundry capacity. Our lead times continue to be stretched out like those of many others in the semi-conductor industry.
Driving our record revenue growth during the June quarter, where our40 and 65-nanometer FPGAs along with the 90-nanometer Virtex-4 family resurgence. Sales of our latest 40-nanometer Virtex-6 products increased substantially, the primary driver of our wireless communications sequentially increase.
As we predicated, several of our 3G wireless customers took significant delivery of our Virtex-6 parts. Their designs began shipping in volume production. Our flagship 65-nanometer Virtex-5 family reached more than 25% of overall revenues this quarter establishing another new record as a highest generating revenue family in PLD history.
In the September quarter, we expect Virtex-5 revenues to increase once again. Lastly, our 90-nanometer Virtex-4 revenues increased 15% sequentially, driven in part by strength from our defense customers.
Current trends continue. Our growth rate is on pace to exceed the overall semiconductor industry in 2010, a testament to the validity of the programmable imperative, the insatiable need for more wired and wireless bandwidth driving a surge in PLD demand.
Increasingly, new programmable logic platforms are replacing ASIC and selective ASSP solutions and we expect this trend will only accelerate with the introduction of our new 28-nanometer family.
Late last month, we announced our 7 series FPGA families, which we believe will further change the game in our industry and open a bold new chapter in the history of our company. This portfolio of 28-nanometer product is built on the industry’s lowest power, the only unified architecture, which scales from low cost to the ultra high end.
When we collaborated with customers to define the 7 series FPGA families, it became abundantly clear power consumption was the key limiting factor to opening programmable logic to new applications in markets now serviced by ASICs to ASSPs by choosing the high performance, low power process from TSMC is significantly lowering overall total power consumption.
It also became very clear, when talking with customers about their next generation product needs, they’re experiencing a convergence of system level requirements across both high end and high volume FPGAs.
To address this convergence, all of 28-nanometer FPGAs are being built from a common set of system blocks allowing customers to design their systems independent of FPGA family selection.
Consequently, our unified architecture greatly improves customer productivity because once they design their IP they can use and reuse it across all families. This all important focus on power, performance, and productivity with a 7 series FPGAs will strengthen our core business as well propel us into new adjacent feats.
Our announcement last quarter of our ARM based extensible processing architecture 28-nanometer demonstrates that we are positioned to service a new class of designers outside of our traditional user base and spearheads our drive into a wide variety of embedded systems.
By employing the familiar ARM based software environment and plus the ecosystem, we can leverage open standards to extend the reach of the embedded systems providing significant incremental growth opportunities for Xilinx.
I am very excited about this broad portfolio of new product. Look forward to updating you on the progress of 28-nanometer deployment quarters to come. I am convinced that the programmable imperative is an inexorable trend and will accelerate with the introduction of these new 28-nanometer families from Xilinx, the leading provider of programmable platform.
Now, I’ll turn the call over to Jon.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Moshe. Before I move onto the question-answer period, I’d like to make a brief announcement that likely will be of interest to the analysts who cover Xilinx and our shareholders.After 18 years of service in the Investor Relations organizati
componenttext:
Thank you, Moshe. Before I move onto the question-answer period, I’d like to make a brief announcement that likely will be of interest to the analysts who cover Xilinx and our shareholders.
After 18 years of service in the Investor Relations organization at Xilinx, Maria Quillard has decided to retire. As you are all aware, Maria has been responsible for building a quality team at Xilinx that has served the needs of our stakeholders with strong leadership and uncompromising professionalism. She truly will be missed. Moshe and I would like to thank Maria for all that she has done. Maria will be with us for the next couple of months and we’ll be announcing a replacement shortly.
Now, I’ll turn the call back to the operator to begin the question-and-answer period. Operator?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) And your first question comes from the line of Glen Yeung with Citi.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) And your first question comes from the line of Glen Yeung with Citi.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Ji Hung [ph] for Glen Yeung. Your inventories were up 16% in the quarter, but the DOI was approximately flat. How comfortable are you with the inventory levels that you have currently?
componenttext: This is Ji Hung [ph] for Glen Yeung. Your inventories were up 16% in the quarter, but the DOI was approximately flat. How comfortable are you with the inventory levels that you have currently?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The fact that our revenue is up significantly and the days are flat are just merely the calculation, but what’s really happening there is that as we have increased the number of wafers out of the foundries and moved it into the backend, the areas in the
componenttext:
The fact that our revenue is up significantly and the days are flat are just merely the calculation, but what’s really happening there is that as we have increased the number of wafers out of the foundries and moved it into the backend, the areas in the inventory, were the increase really was from a quarterly basis, wasn’t in our die bank or want in the front end, it was really all in the backend.
So inventory that’s build up in assembly and test, just after it’s been assembled into finished goods, ready for shipment early in this particular quarter. So, we are pretty comfortable with that. Again, we think days are already very lean at the 80 level and as revenue goes up, inventory dollars will tend to drift up a little bit as well, but I wouldn’t expect any significant spikes in inventory dollars in the short run.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And we’ve heard chatter about TD-SCDMA builds for Phase IV starting up again, what do you think there? I know that you are expecting wireless structure to continue to be a driver next quarter.
componenttext: Thank you. And we’ve heard chatter about TD-SCDMA builds for Phase IV starting up again, what do you think there? I know that you are expecting wireless structure to continue to be a driver next quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, it’s clear that build-out is starting and we did ship Virtex-6 parts into the initial builds beyond prototyping, and that’s really what the primary impact of the China business was for us this quarter, and we do expect the ramp to begin in th
componenttext: Yes. So, it’s clear that build-out is starting and we did ship Virtex-6 parts into the initial builds beyond prototyping, and that’s really what the primary impact of the China business was for us this quarter, and we do expect the ramp to begin in the September quarter and if history repeats itself, it should continue for another couple of quarters beyond that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you.
componenttext: Great, thank you.

componenttextpreview: Can you hear me?

componenttextpreview: Yes, Uche, we can hear you.
