headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you very much. Let me just start out by asking about gross margins. In terms of what would drive it now going forward, should we expect that to be more mix driven, and as Virtex-6 ramps, what kind of impact would that also have on gross margins
componenttext: Yes, thank you very much. Let me just start out by asking about gross margins. In terms of what would drive it now going forward, should we expect that to be more mix driven, and as Virtex-6 ramps, what kind of impact would that also have on gross margins? So, I am just trying to understand whether we had done leveraging it now at 6% to 5% and subsequently it’s going to be about mix or is there another factor that will drive gross margins going forward?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, mix has a lot to do typically in our business because of all the different end markets that we sell to, but I think the biggest dynamic that’s going on is that as yields improve on Virtex-6 and the costs get better for Virtex-6 and Spar
componenttext:
Well, certainly, mix has a lot to do typically in our business because of all the different end markets that we sell to, but I think the biggest dynamic that’s going on is that as yields improve on Virtex-6 and the costs get better for Virtex-6 and Spartan-6, that’s obviously a plus, helping us along the way, but the fact that the foundries, the supply chain is really, really tight. It is actually a drag for us because as is typical in semiconductor industry, and your prices are always going down in terms of the price curve, and your cost curves are also going down.
The fact that the wafer foundries are not giving us the same level of price decreases that we have historically experienced, that ends up being a drag. We do believe we’ll be able to offset the fact that wafer costs aren’t going down nearly as fast as they have in the past with the other cost reduction efforts across the company. And then, obviously, improved yields on Virtex-6. So I characterized last quarter that the end of this year, there is a potential of seeing some uptick in gross margin. I am less confident of that now just because of the state of the supply chain overall.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Now, in terms of thinking about the impact of the supply chain, I know you’ve given guidance for September. I’m not asking you to necessarily give a full guidance for December, but how should we think about what the impact of a supply chain could have
componenttext: Now, in terms of thinking about the impact of the supply chain, I know you’ve given guidance for September. I’m not asking you to necessarily give a full guidance for December, but how should we think about what the impact of a supply chain could have followed down the line into the December quarter? Also V-6 ramps, will that also have an impact, so that how we should think about December? So apart from military, which I know it does have an impact into Q4 period, I’m just trying to understand whether the impact of supply chain could beat us to ending up with a better unseasonal December quarter. While you’re explaining that also, can you just give us more insight as to what your foundry partners are telling you about how they can improve this tightness you’re seeing right now?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You are right. The seasonality aspect of aerospace and defense is tended to be a positive for us in the December quarter, but boy, its just way too much going on right now for us to give you a great forecast. I really don’t think the supply chain, at le
componenttext:
You are right. The seasonality aspect of aerospace and defense is tended to be a positive for us in the December quarter, but boy, its just way too much going on right now for us to give you a great forecast. I really don’t think the supply chain, at least the way we see it today, is going to impede us from continuing growth if there was that risk demand from our customers in this ramp, we’ll continue into December. We do have capacity reservations for increasing wafers not just in September, but also the December quarter.
So, we have the ability to get absolutely more wafers out in December than we did in September and obviously, I just talked about getting more out in September than we had in June. So we have that capacity reservation and that capability at the foundries, but I’m not going to give you; it’s tough. It’s really hard negotiations to get what we want. There’s just a lot of semiconductor companies knocking at the door trying to get that. We’ve been treated very well by our partners and it’s working out.
I do want to point, even though we plan out that we do have delinquencies and they increased this quarter, we really have been able to help meet customers’ really critical needs. I don’t think we’ve really created a really lying down situation and those kinds of thing that you might hear about in other situations. We’ve done a good job in the communications with our customers in that particular situation. There’s a lot of companies that are shorting them. So we’ve got a pretty good reputation there.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: All right. Just one last question for Moshe. Moshe, when you were describing the dynamics between ASICs, ASSPs and FPGA, you had mentioned power as the most important factor now, the limiting factor in terms of adoption of FPGA. I probably was under the i
componenttext: All right. Just one last question for Moshe. Moshe, when you were describing the dynamics between ASICs, ASSPs and FPGA, you had mentioned power as the most important factor now, the limiting factor in terms of adoption of FPGA. I probably was under the impression it was more economic as opposed to power. Can you just shed a little bit more light as to how the economics have changed, say as we go to 28-nanometers with ASICs? I know there is no one size fits all example, but I’m a little bit surprised it always used to be economics of the power, so any sense as to how we can think about the impact of economics it would be helpful?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you need to address all three, you need to hit the right price point, you need to have the right set of features and you need to achieve a certain power envelope. More and more, the biggest challenge is in the power envelope, because as you move for
componenttext:
Well, you need to address all three, you need to hit the right price point, you need to have the right set of features and you need to achieve a certain power envelope. More and more, the biggest challenge is in the power envelope, because as you move forward, as we have aggressively to new process nodes, then you can address the cost through higher density, but the power is more difficult to achieve and that has become the biggest issue.
Now if you think back at what happened in the processor space 10 years ago around the turn is the millennium, there was a huge transition that happened, where the leading processor companies moved to multi-core solutions as opposed to just increasing the frequency.
That was all driven by power and that was precursor that then permeated the basic design flow starting about five years ago and we believe we are driving the leadership in the FPGA space because that has become the number one issue not only in terms of the CapEx requirements that our customers have, but they are now looking more and more at the OpEx, products tend to have very long lifecycle and huge portion of running their business is how much power they require. So, it’s becoming more and more front and center to the customers’ requirements in more and more applications. That doesn’t mean that the other two features and the cost of the product itself are not important, but the power has moved to the number one element in our mind.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you very much.
componenttext: All right. Thank you very much.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from Tim Luke with Barclays Capital.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, guys, this is Aniel Mahtani for Tim Luke. Could you please provide some color on how you view R&D trending over the course of the year as we ramp up new programs?
componenttext: Hi, guys, this is Aniel Mahtani for Tim Luke. Could you please provide some color on how you view R&D trending over the course of the year as we ramp up new programs?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: R&D spending has a little bit of upward bias to the second half of our year, primarily due to the beginning of 28-nanometer tape-outs and those kinds of things. We’re really experiencing one of the lower tape-out expending years overall and it starts to
componenttext:
R&D spending has a little bit of upward bias to the second half of our year, primarily due to the beginning of 28-nanometer tape-outs and those kinds of things. We’re really experiencing one of the lower tape-out expending years overall and it starts to increase a little bit in the second half, but I can kind of step it up one level higher just talk about OpEx in total in terms of our expectations.
We guided it to $185 million for next quarter, and I think even though there will be a little bit of up and down in the second to half of our fiscal year, I think somewhere in the mid $180s million is the right level to plan on a quarterly basis for OpEx. Now, if revenue significantly increases further there will be additional variable expenses for selling expenses and compensation related expenses associated with our incentive programs for employees, since that’s driven by operating margin percentage and expansion of the top line will yield expansion of the bottom line and therefore that will cost us more expenses there.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As you ramp up 40, 45-nanometer products, do they open up any particular new segment or new product areas for you that you are selling into?
componenttext: As you ramp up 40, 45-nanometer products, do they open up any particular new segment or new product areas for you that you are selling into?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, 40, 45 definitely deepens and broadens the markets which we service, and in particular, if you look at 40, it enables us to put yet another nail in the coffin of ASICs for everything except high volume applications. It’s really the higher volume m
componenttext:
Well, 40, 45 definitely deepens and broadens the markets which we service, and in particular, if you look at 40, it enables us to put yet another nail in the coffin of ASICs for everything except high volume applications. It’s really the higher volume markets, which are the expansion markets for us and that’s the Spartan-6 product offering and that’s really seeing broad acceptance in all of our traditional markets, including ones that you would assume a more Virtex-oriented.
So, for sample, communications and the higher volume military ones, there is a tremendous opportunity for Spartan-6 in the higher volume, more cost sensitive applications. And then everything else just continues to open up at that market. So even though, as a percentage of the overall FPGA space today, it’s a still smaller percentage, it’s the fastest growing part of the market and that’s why we are delighted to have the only leadership product in that market with these with the broad offering. That will facilitate growth, but we are already benefiting from that and the numbers in last quarter already had a significant portion of Spartan-6 revenue in addition to the Virtex-6 revenue.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you.
componenttext: Great, thank you.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chris Danely of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Danely of JPMorgan.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, thanks guys. Can you just maybe go over the sort of the outsourcing strategy going forward since there are some changes? And also, Jon, you remarked that, I guess, the wafer pricing is changing or that sort of the price concessions you’ve had in th
componenttext: Hey, thanks guys. Can you just maybe go over the sort of the outsourcing strategy going forward since there are some changes? And also, Jon, you remarked that, I guess, the wafer pricing is changing or that sort of the price concessions you’ve had in the past are not happening in the second half of the year. Is that a new thing? Has that never happened before? Is that unique to the cycle?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Chris, so I am not exactly sure what you mean by the additional outsourcing. Existing foundries, we’re working with all of them to try to get more capacity. The back-end is pretty much set with the same guys that haven’t changed anything there. Obviou
componenttext:
Chris, so I am not exactly sure what you mean by the additional outsourcing. Existing foundries, we’re working with all of them to try to get more capacity. The back-end is pretty much set with the same guys that haven’t changed anything there. Obviously, at the next generation 20-nanometer, we talked about going to Samsung as a lead (inaudible) as a lead foundry for that. So, there really isn’t anything changing relative to what products we are building where.
We are getting Virtex-5 parts from Toshiba and UMC as a two foundries. So, there really isn’t anything changing in the outsourcing strategy per se other than everybody is tied in. We are negotiating with everybody as best as we can.
On the wafer pricing issue, it has happened in the past, I would say, for short periods of time, because the cycles of the past have tended to be relatively short, meaning a couple of quarters in my experience where things have gotten tied and the foundries have said, I don’t think I need some help here. I’ve got to invest capital. I can’t lower the wafer pricing, et cetera. In this particular situation, I think we’ve gone through an extended period.
Now, what we can see is at least three quarters of that kind of a situation going on and it is starting to impact our cost roadmap estimates along the way. So, it’s not something that’s going to cause us to have a huge downward impact, as best as I can tell on our gross margin, but it is preventing us from expansion there. Now, my expectations are when the capacity isn’t quite as tied, then life changes again.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow up, did your lead times or delinquencies multiply or extend further during the June quarter and do you expect them to stabilize this quarter or could we see the lead times extend again?
componenttext: And then just as a follow up, did your lead times or delinquencies multiply or extend further during the June quarter and do you expect them to stabilize this quarter or could we see the lead times extend again?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Lead times have gotten a little bit longer. We talked about the average for us is 10 weeks to 12 weeks in the March quarter and they are about the same, just a little bit longer in the June quarter. From a delinquency perspective, we left last quarter, th
componenttext:
Lead times have gotten a little bit longer. We talked about the average for us is 10 weeks to 12 weeks in the March quarter and they are about the same, just a little bit longer in the June quarter. From a delinquency perspective, we left last quarter, the March quarter we had about 2% of revenue, that level of delinquency that we said we could have shipped if we would had all the product and it essentially doubled from 2% to 4% in this last quarter.
So, we could have shipped an additional mid $20 million kind of additional revenue, if we would have had the supply. We think we can hold at that level through the September quarter and not expand that number, and I think that will be a good thing.
I want to point out just one more time, we don’t have a situation where customers are so angry with us, they are shopping around for other alternatives, etc. We’ve actually done a very nice job of hitting critical needs of those customers.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks and congratulations to Maria. I’m jealous; I wish I could retire too.
componenttext: Great, thanks and congratulations to Maria. I’m jealous; I wish I could retire too.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Just following up on the delinquencies, the total through the September quarter it will be 10%, so close to $60 million, do you expect that you get that back when the capacity becomes abundant?
componenttext: Thanks. Just following up on the delinquencies, the total through the September quarter it will be 10%, so close to $60 million, do you expect that you get that back when the capacity becomes abundant?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mahesh, let me correct your statement. No, it’s not cumulative. The delinquencies, the 2% that we had at the end of March, we essentially shipped all of those delinquencies in the next month, but then throughout the quarter, we were still delinquent to
componenttext: Mahesh, let me correct your statement. No, it’s not cumulative. The delinquencies, the 2% that we had at the end of March, we essentially shipped all of those delinquencies in the next month, but then throughout the quarter, we were still delinquent to what customers needed and the number is approximately 4% of our revenue that we could have shipped. So, that amount of money again is in the mid $20 million. As capacity increases and as long as demand is increasing at the same, we won’t be able to improve that. If those dynamics change, then, yes, we’ll be able to ship all that revenue.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the foundries you said you have increasing wafer starts, does that continue through Q4? I mean, I’m assuming that you’re able to grow revenues 5% in the September quarter, because that’s the capacity available. Can you give us an idea of
componenttext: In terms of the foundries you said you have increasing wafer starts, does that continue through Q4? I mean, I’m assuming that you’re able to grow revenues 5% in the September quarter, because that’s the capacity available. Can you give us an idea of is the level of wafer start increase you’re getting from TSMC or from UMC for December quarter is in the similar increase?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So for Virtex-5 and Virtex-4, Toshiba and UMC are foundries together, and I think it’s a reasonable conclusion to say the level of that total network of those two are going up, and they go up at the same rate as our revenue is going up, it’s reasonabl
componenttext: So for Virtex-5 and Virtex-4, Toshiba and UMC are foundries together, and I think it’s a reasonable conclusion to say the level of that total network of those two are going up, and they go up at the same rate as our revenue is going up, it’s reasonable to say that’s the approximate wafer out increase.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much.
componenttext: Thank you very much.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Schneider with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Schneider with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Congratulations on strong results to team and congratulations to Maria as well. I guess to start off with on the communications side, you talked about wireline and wireless strength, I guess wireless in particular. That’s been strong for
componenttext: Good afternoon. Congratulations on strong results to team and congratulations to Maria as well. I guess to start off with on the communications side, you talked about wireline and wireless strength, I guess wireless in particular. That’s been strong for a while now and I guess one of the questions in everybody’s mind is, how sustainable is that even with some of the secular factors you mentioned going in your favor, what are customers telling you about whether that’s likely to continue into the December quarter or is the March quarter after that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Jim, we clearly have had a quite a run here in the Wireless segment. We are bullish on that over the long haul because of all the various dynamics that we’ve talked about in the past, China, the 4G LTE and other expansions in the U.S. and then Indi
componenttext:
Yes. Jim, we clearly have had a quite a run here in the Wireless segment. We are bullish on that over the long haul because of all the various dynamics that we’ve talked about in the past, China, the 4G LTE and other expansions in the U.S. and then India following that. So, this quarter, the September quarter, the China business was actually relatively flat on a dollar basis for us, and the big uptick was in our LTE and shipping into the Verizon business, and then the expansion of both backhaul and base stations for the AT&T expansion as well.
So, we’ve got significant upsides from both of those while China was relatively flat. In the September quarter, wireless is strong because of both China increasing and the Verizon and AT&T contracts being shipped into as backhaul. So that’s a very, very strong sign for us.
Beyond that, it’s less clear what’s going to happen. We do think China is probably going to continue based on the historic trends, but the rest of the world, India will start having something going on, but that’s probably still a few more quarters out. We don’t have very good visibility in December on the Verizon and AT&T activity. So, again, I think the numbers will stay pretty strong on wireless for us, but there could be some volatility coming forward; hard to tell right now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, that’s helpful. And then I think one area you didn’t mention and maybe I missed it in this quarter or the previous, the guidance was on networking, and I was wondering if you are able to give some color on what that did and you expect going fo
componenttext: Thanks, that’s helpful. And then I think one area you didn’t mention and maybe I missed it in this quarter or the previous, the guidance was on networking, and I was wondering if you are able to give some color on what that did and you expect going forward?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We didn’t say anything about, we said the strongest growth in communications is going to be wireless, but wireline specifically in networking, we do expect that to increase quarter-on-quarter. The other side of wireline that’s a little less clear
componenttext: Yes. We didn’t say anything about, we said the strongest growth in communications is going to be wireless, but wireline specifically in networking, we do expect that to increase quarter-on-quarter. The other side of wireline that’s a little less clear to us right now and that’s the part that we’re not sure of, so we didn’t really mention it. So we do think wireline is going to take up some for us and that will be on the basis of networking.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks very much.
componenttext: Great, thanks very much.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. Do you have any thoughts about efforts to create product like Altera’s HardCopy that allows you to provide your customers with cost reduction efforts through a hardware product?
componenttext: Hi. Do you have any thoughts about efforts to create product like Altera’s HardCopy that allows you to provide your customers with cost reduction efforts through a hardware product?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We’ve a very successful product that addresses those markets. The approach is different than the one selected by the competition, but it provides the customers with a very applicable solution, which can be deployed very easily and minimizes their engine
componenttext: We’ve a very successful product that addresses those markets. The approach is different than the one selected by the competition, but it provides the customers with a very applicable solution, which can be deployed very easily and minimizes their engineering investments. So we’re pleased with that solution. It’s part and parcel of our strategy going forward, and it’s available for all of our high end product offerings as a cost reduction path for the higher volume application.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Right. What’s the name of this product?
componenttext: Right. What’s the name of this product?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It’s the EasyPath product line.
componenttext: It’s the EasyPath product line.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you.
componenttext: Great, thank you.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ruben Roy of Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ruben Roy of Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Jon, I might have missed your explanation of some of the operating margin dynamics as you look forward, but I think if I remember correctly that the operating margin target longer term has been 31% to 34% and was hitting 35% here. Obviously, you h
componenttext: Thanks. Jon, I might have missed your explanation of some of the operating margin dynamics as you look forward, but I think if I remember correctly that the operating margin target longer term has been 31% to 34% and was hitting 35% here. Obviously, you have some spending coming up around at 28-nanometer, etcetera, but how are you thinking about your longer term operating margins now that you kind of eclipsed high end of your previous target range.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It’s hard to keep up with how good our business is, isn’t it? Yes, we were admiring the 35% and liking it. I know that it’s above our target and as you did point out, we are in a low between (inaudible) wafer tape-out kinds of spending to some
componenttext:
Yes. It’s hard to keep up with how good our business is, isn’t it? Yes, we were admiring the 35% and liking it. I know that it’s above our target and as you did point out, we are in a low between (inaudible) wafer tape-out kinds of spending to some degree and that starts a ramp up and that will drive some differences there.
We are clearly looking at controlling spending. In fact, we just had our kind of an update to our annual budget process and what I call the direct spending, the non-variable things that we’re, obviously, focused on R&D, sales, marketing, etc., and we are pretty much dead on our plan. We are not expanding our spending levels beyond that and with the spending increases you are seeing are just because of the variable issues, because of revenue and profits increasing.
So, we are very determined to stay on that plan and that path and because we are enjoying such a strong revenue uptick right now, it is allowing us to operate higher than our model. I am really not ready to commit to expanding our model, but we are not trying to hold ourselves back either from letting it go higher. So, we are thinking about tough spending controls, continue to look for cost reduction efforts across the company, and keep that discipline and if we get even more good news out of the revenue lines, then it is going to fall through.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then around the Communications business when you think about your sales into domestic China carriers, do you think that business for this fiscal year June through March is going to be higher than fiscal ‘10?
componenttext: And then around the Communications business when you think about your sales into domestic China carriers, do you think that business for this fiscal year June through March is going to be higher than fiscal ‘10?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our current belief is, because our penetration is higher that our fiscal year ‘11 will be higher than our fiscal year ‘10 in terms of spending in China. Now, I know we’ve all heard about pressures on CapEx and things like that there, so there is may
componenttext: Our current belief is, because our penetration is higher that our fiscal year ‘11 will be higher than our fiscal year ‘10 in terms of spending in China. Now, I know we’ve all heard about pressures on CapEx and things like that there, so there is maybe a little less confidence if you go back, go out and talk to the Chinese manufacturers. Relative to their forecast to us in terms of the number of base stations they are talking about, that would work out to a larger number for 3G in fiscal year ‘11 and fiscal year ‘10.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Finally, Jon, can you give us a rough idea of Spartan-6 plus, Virtex-6 as a percentage of your revenues actually in June?
componenttext: Finally, Jon, can you give us a rough idea of Spartan-6 plus, Virtex-6 as a percentage of your revenues actually in June?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We are not providing that number, we said it’s up substantially. We are into double-digit revenues for those two and we still believe that we’ll ship well in excess of $100 million in this fiscal year.
componenttext: We are not providing that number, we said it’s up substantially. We are into double-digit revenues for those two and we still believe that we’ll ship well in excess of $100 million in this fiscal year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks very much.
componenttext: Great, thanks very much.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ian Ing with Gleacher & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ian Ing with Gleacher & Company.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, guys, thank you. Trying to reconcile the supply constraints with why Industrial is so strong and then expected to decline, you would think the industrial customers served by Disti [ph] would be the first to be undersupplied. So, are there other end ma
componenttext: Hi, guys, thank you. Trying to reconcile the supply constraints with why Industrial is so strong and then expected to decline, you would think the industrial customers served by Disti [ph] would be the first to be undersupplied. So, are there other end markets that are getting undersupplied, I mean what are your thoughts on where the under shipment is occurring?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I’d say most of the under shipments are in the Communications side of our business, with some in aerospace and defense, but mostly in the Communications side. The reason there is that the upside kind of numbers that are being driven for us are more chal
componenttext:
I’d say most of the under shipments are in the Communications side of our business, with some in aerospace and defense, but mostly in the Communications side. The reason there is that the upside kind of numbers that are being driven for us are more challenged out of the large customers, which tend to be communications customers for us and then some aerospace and defense customers. Maybe aerospace and defense customers are on, I would say, slightly older technologies, and they’ve been doing a better job of forecasting and they are probably being able to prepare better for that. The downward tick that we have going on in industrial and others is really more because of defense.
There were a number of, I’d say, last time buys of older parts for older contracts that kind of hit us, the timing hit us this past quarter versus the September quarter. So, those aren’t going to repeat themselves and that’s really what’s driving that segment down. We do think industrial, scientific, and medical will continue to be a growth factor for us. There is lots of new medical applications going on. Surveillance was strong this last quarter and that’s going to continue. And then test and measurement, the semiconductor industry is buying more test equipments these days. So, that’s driving a need for FPGAs and we expect that to continue as a long-term trend here for the next few quarters.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, for your interest expense, how much of that is accounting for convertible debt, the non-cash interest portion and how much of an impact is that to GAAP EPS? Aren’t you unfairly penalizing GAAP EPS and creating an unfair comp versus compe
componenttext: As a follow-up, for your interest expense, how much of that is accounting for convertible debt, the non-cash interest portion and how much of an impact is that to GAAP EPS? Aren’t you unfairly penalizing GAAP EPS and creating an unfair comp versus competitors?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: While, I mean, there isn’t an impact for that and you’re right, because of the accounting treatment, the shorter the duration of your note, the more of that that goes on in terms of the bigger dollar amount that this is related that ends up in your eq
componenttext:
While, I mean, there isn’t an impact for that and you’re right, because of the accounting treatment, the shorter the duration of your note, the more of that that goes on in terms of the bigger dollar amount that this is related that ends up in your equity area. From an interest expense area, it’s approximately in the neighborhood of $3 million to $4 million a quarter of interest expense that’s part of this non-cash number.
And then, yes, that is a comparison drag. ROE is a comparison drag as well because of the accounting rules on the converts. Let’s say, you have to classify some of this as equity and then you advertise it back to debt over the life of the note and that makes our equity number go up artificially for a while. Artificially, meaning from an accounting rules, I mean, obviously, it’s GAAP. So, those are some of the dynamics that make the comparatives a little more difficult there.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We should continue with GAAP estimates then?
componenttext: We should continue with GAAP estimates then?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And congrats, Maria, and your time and enjoy your golf game.
componenttext: And congrats, Maria, and your time and enjoy your golf game.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. The constraints that you’re having, is it by process (inaudible) to find a little bit better, or is it broad based? Your competitors said yesterday that they were not seeing process node related to dynamic there. So, just wondering what you g
componenttext: Thank you. The constraints that you’re having, is it by process (inaudible) to find a little bit better, or is it broad based? Your competitors said yesterday that they were not seeing process node related to dynamic there. So, just wondering what you guys are seeing?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It’s clearly, the biggest one is 65-nanometer, then the second largest one is 90, but I would characterize it as well over 50%, probably more like 75% is in the 65 area and then maybe 20% or so in the 90-nanometer. There is some fungibility that go
componenttext: Yes. It’s clearly, the biggest one is 65-nanometer, then the second largest one is 90, but I would characterize it as well over 50%, probably more like 75% is in the 65 area and then maybe 20% or so in the 90-nanometer. There is some fungibility that goes on here, so I’m characterizing it that way and we think kind of move some things around between nodes a little bit. So you can also look at it, and say, everything is kind of short, but quite frankly, it is the more advanced nodes meaning that volume is being shipped on which is namely 65 and 90.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of follow-ups. Last quarter you indicated some customers were adding buffer inventory. Is that still happening? Is it happening at the same rate or lesser rate, commentary there would be helpful?
componenttext: A couple of follow-ups. Last quarter you indicated some customers were adding buffer inventory. Is that still happening? Is it happening at the same rate or lesser rate, commentary there would be helpful?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So, we’re not seeing anybody add increasing amounts of buffer at this time. It’s pretty stable to the handful of customers that have been doing it in the past. We have some amount of our inventory that’s in hubs that people drop things out. They are
componenttext:
So, we’re not seeing anybody add increasing amounts of buffer at this time. It’s pretty stable to the handful of customers that have been doing it in the past. We have some amount of our inventory that’s in hubs that people drop things out. They are not drawing them out just to have them sit in their warehouse; they are drawing them out in order to build products.
Now, whether the end product is sitting in warehouses and not sold through I guess we don’t have the perfect visibility on that, but we really aren’t seeing an increase by large customers or the subconts [ph] that are building for them, that are just pulling parts out and holding on to them, they are building.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And then the last one, the issue here with the Street regarding you and your competition is that you seem to be out growing your customers handily over the past several quarters. How much of this is because of market share gains or at the expen
componenttext: Thank you. And then the last one, the issue here with the Street regarding you and your competition is that you seem to be out growing your customers handily over the past several quarters. How much of this is because of market share gains or at the expense of ASSPs or ASICs just a little definition there that would be helpful? Thanks.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It also is very difficult to be precise about this, because we do have lots and lots of customers buying at all kinds of different levels, but particularly in Communications I will draw you to the fact that these large customers that we’re selling to, i
componenttext:
It also is very difficult to be precise about this, because we do have lots and lots of customers buying at all kinds of different levels, but particularly in Communications I will draw you to the fact that these large customers that we’re selling to, if you look inside the segments that they’re doing well on, that’s where we shipping the most. So, base stations, backhaul, it’s that part of their business, I believe, they have been telling you is growing faster than their average. Our penetration is also increasing in those specific areas.
So we’re getting an impact of sub-segments of their business doing very-very well and our penetration going up. In addition to that, we’re seeing more and more improvement in terms of design wins against ASICs and ASSPs we haven’t been able to bid on in the past. At the Analyst Day we showed you this list of one quarter’s worth of design wins and it was somewhere under 100, like an 87 or 90 or something in that range, and that was through the December quarter. In the March quarter the number of new design wins that we penetrated ASSPs, and, ASICs and PLDs hadn’t been in the past, it went up 50% from that number.
And then again, in this last quarter that we just announced, it went up well over 50% again. So we are seeing up into the right penetration here. Now, all those haven’t turned into revenue yet, probably very few of them have turned into revenue, but these are definitely demonstrative signs of what Moshe has been talking about relative to the 65-nanometer and 40, 45-nanometer product families are at the right cost of power density points that are proving our points that we are making headway.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. We’ll miss you, Maria.
componenttext: Thank you. We’ll miss you, Maria.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from John Pitzer with Credit Suisse.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Ashish Rao for John. Just wondering if you could update us on when you expect customer sampling and also the revenue ramp of 28-nanometer parts?
componenttext: This is Ashish Rao for John. Just wondering if you could update us on when you expect customer sampling and also the revenue ramp of 28-nanometer parts?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We’re going to be shipping customer samples in the first quarter of calendar 2011, and production will follow approximately a year later plus or minus.
componenttext: We’re going to be shipping customer samples in the first quarter of calendar 2011, and production will follow approximately a year later plus or minus.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked a lot about the power advantages of moving to 28 nanometers from 40, 45 nanometers, probably significantly better and would help you address a lot many more markets than you address currently. Just wondering, do you think this could also result
componenttext: You talked a lot about the power advantages of moving to 28 nanometers from 40, 45 nanometers, probably significantly better and would help you address a lot many more markets than you address currently. Just wondering, do you think this could also result in like better pricing and support you know kind of like a gross margin expansion?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It enables us to address more applications and to address more markets and to broaden our penetration. I don’t think you can correlate that into more profitable business. It just grows the envelope of business we can address significantly. It’s becomi
componenttext: It enables us to address more applications and to address more markets and to broaden our penetration. I don’t think you can correlate that into more profitable business. It just grows the envelope of business we can address significantly. It’s becoming more and more important in more and more applications. Clearly, in consumer battery operated ones, it’s self evident, but this goes well beyond that into (inaudible) applications and even into infrastructure, where it is becoming a big deal. So I think the major benefit is growing the market we can address significantly rather than making us more profitable.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just add to that. The lower power doesn’t mean it’s lower than ASICs or ASSPs. It means its lower and therefore we get much closer to where they are as I don’t care which means we get the right to bid on the sockets and potentially win them.
componenttext: Let me just add to that. The lower power doesn’t mean it’s lower than ASICs or ASSPs. It means its lower and therefore we get much closer to where they are as I don’t care which means we get the right to bid on the sockets and potentially win them.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Got them, but do you think is that -
componenttext: Got them, but do you think is that -

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No. I was just going to say, it’s not necessarily a value driven thing that a customer will say, I’ll pay more for it because they are just saying, "Oh! Gosh, I can use your solution and get the customization." They may pay us more because of the prog
componenttext: No. I was just going to say, it’s not necessarily a value driven thing that a customer will say, I’ll pay more for it because they are just saying, "Oh! Gosh, I can use your solution and get the customization." They may pay us more because of the programmability, but that would be in our normal margin framework that we have.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly, if I may. Any color on what percent of revenues like 40, 45-nanometers and 65-nanometers represents right now?
componenttext: Lastly, if I may. Any color on what percent of revenues like 40, 45-nanometers and 65-nanometers represents right now?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We’re not providing any very point numbers on 40, 45-nanometer. It did grow substantially this quarter and it was in the double digit range. It was clearly double digits this quarter. We still expect to ship well over $100 million of 40, 45-nanometer by
componenttext: We’re not providing any very point numbers on 40, 45-nanometer. It did grow substantially this quarter and it was in the double digit range. It was clearly double digits this quarter. We still expect to ship well over $100 million of 40, 45-nanometer by the end of the fiscal year cumulative.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. In terms of the delinquencies, you said it was 2% in March and then it grew to 4% in the June quarter. Looking back in your history, can you guys recall when it was last at that level?
componenttext: Thank you. In terms of the delinquencies, you said it was 2% in March and then it grew to 4% in the June quarter. Looking back in your history, can you guys recall when it was last at that level?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: When we were coming out of the hard shutdown of the foundries, we had, I would say, somewhere in the probably 2% or 3% for a quarter or whatever, but if I think back at least in my time, I don’t recall ever being quite as high as 4% of revenue.

I think we can keep it stable throughout the quarter. Again, we are late shipping to somebody, we ship to them three weeks or four weeks late or two weeks late, but then other companies increased their orders that we can’t fulfill so then that delinquencies kind of mount a little bit. It’s typically different customers and different devices that are delinquent at the end of one quarter versus the end of the next quarter.

componenttext: And then on the ASIC displacement theme, for those of us who are trying to kind of scope and figure out what’s happening versus end market growth versus supply chain replenishment, et cetera. You talked about it was in the high 80s, whatever, at your Analyst Day, grew 50% in margin and it was up over 50% in Q2. So, let’s say that the number, the incremental increase in the June quarter was, let’s say, 75 to 100 new design wins that were ASIC displacements. How many design wins does that represent as a percentage of the total design wins you got during the June quarter?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: I don’t have that number.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to answer that number, because so many of the design wins are smaller ones, which happen through the channel, but these are little ones that are tracked by our direct sales force and are significant. So, it’s very difficult to quantify where they a
componenttext:
Just to answer that number, because so many of the design wins are smaller ones, which happen through the channel, but these are little ones that are tracked by our direct sales force and are significant. So, it’s very difficult to quantify where they are, but I think the value is in the relative number. It is now twice what it was six months ago when you compare apples-to-apples, and it will absolutely generate tremendous growth in the future as ASICs and ASSPs shrink into very high volume applications and more and more applications are serviced by FPGAs
That is why we are so intent on driving the technology forward, because we can afford to do that and give our customers very competitive product, leading edge nodes, and now the gap between the FPGA nodes to the mainstream of the ASIC market, where most of the revenue is, is over three generations of technology. I mean they are sort of still at the 90 to 130, and we are going to be providing them 28-nanometer solution a year from now right. That will enable us to address a lot of market, hence you see the number of design wins grow, but it’s difficult to sort of compare it, plus this tend to be higher revenue design wins, hence they have a bigger wait.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I still think we’re going to be in the $50 million range plus or minus. We had a quite a bit of CapEx in the front-end of this year because of some new test equipment relative to new generations coming at us, actually cost reduced tests over time for us
componenttext: I still think we’re going to be in the $50 million range plus or minus. We had a quite a bit of CapEx in the front-end of this year because of some new test equipment relative to new generations coming at us, actually cost reduced tests over time for us as we moved to cheaper tests as well. So, there was quite a bit of capital built up. Also, there was some pop in our IT spending, because we’ve been really tight in terms of infrastructure in the IT area. So, we spent a little more in the front-end of this year. So even though with the $18 million this quarter, we still think we’ll be in the $50 million to $60 million range for the year cumulative.

componenttext: No, we’re not. So, that’s what I was emphasizing, we think we’ve been able to meet all of the customers’ critical needs. In fact, we continue to get quality and which in quality includes delivery scores, very high scores from our customers, because even though we were kind of early with the delinquencies relative to the other semiconductor companies and the other suppliers, we’ve turned out to be the bright spot in that. In most cases, we may not even be on the list that they’re worried about, quite frankly. So, we are very confident that we are not losing the business because of the supply situation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: One more for Moshe, Moshe you talked about 28 nanometers and you gave a lot of details about what are the characteristics that’s going to differentiate this platform versus other platforms, but talking to large customers, when you’re finalizing the ar
componenttext: One more for Moshe, Moshe you talked about 28 nanometers and you gave a lot of details about what are the characteristics that’s going to differentiate this platform versus other platforms, but talking to large customers, when you’re finalizing the architecture, is this something that characteristic or architecture are functioned that you’re seeing from a customer that needs to be added or did the architecture seem to be intact?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the 28-nanometer solution is a very, very broad solution. It’s credibly scalable, so it addresses a lot of markets. If you look at each of those markets and with broad brush strokes then at the high end they are looking for capacity and that’s w
componenttext:
Well, the 28-nanometer solution is a very, very broad solution. It’s credibly scalable, so it addresses a lot of markets. If you look at each of those markets and with broad brush strokes then at the high end they are looking for capacity and that’s we’re having by far the largest FPGA solution enables us to address markets that in the past could only be addressed by the more complex ASICs. So this really enables us to address that market with the $2 million logic sales that you can hit nearly all of the ASIC market, and there’s very little in terms of capacity that we can’t hit there.
And then the next issue becomes, now you have the capacity to do that, can you do this without the device becoming a frying pan and that’s why the power is so important. So that’s at the high end, the sort of power is only important at the low end, that’s categorically not true. It’s actually essential at the high end. That’s an example of markets that we can address that we’ve not been able to address before.
Now, as you move across the product offering, then you could see other markets, where it becomes a lot more attractive and when you move to the high volume side of the market just achieving or enabling the level of performance at the cost point, which is very critical at the low end, that sort of expense and will enable us to address a whole new host of applications. One market we’ve seen this is in the communications space is we can now enable our infrastructure customers to address the whole breadth of their product line with the solution and hence the scalability is very important.
So we are incredibly excited about this new product, and we see tremendous benefits there. This will enable us to expand the market and hence we’re very confident in growing the market to at least 2X what it has been, and we’ve put a stick in the ground, that we expect this to be at least a $6 billion market by 2015. If anything, it looks like it’s happening faster than it has before, and it could be a conservative estimate.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everyone, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, then we'll open the call up for questions.Let me remind everyone that during our conferen
componenttext:
Thank you, everyone, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, then we'll open the call up for questions.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements. This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Investor Relations website.
Now let me turn the call over to Jon Olson.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria. During today's commentary, I will review our June quarter business results. I will conclude my remarks by providing guidance for the September quarter. The June quarter was a strong quarter, setting records for both sales and operating
componenttext:
Thank you, Maria. During today's commentary, I will review our June quarter business results. I will conclude my remarks by providing guidance for the September quarter. 
The June quarter was a strong quarter, setting records for both sales and operating income. With sales of $595 million, we set a record for the third consecutive quarter, and operating income reached a historic high of $208 million. This operating income performance represents a year-over-year increase of 263% over 4x the rate of sales increase during the same period. The operating leverage was a direct result of not only the significant growth in revenue but was greatly enhanced by the restructuring actions and cost-reduction efforts driven at the company over the past two years. 
June quarter sales of $595 million increased 12% sequentially. Better-than-expected sales growth was driven primarily by strong new product growth as well as across-the-board strength in the Industrial & Other category. Sales for the first two months of the quarter were in line with our expectations, while the third month was stronger than expected. 
Turns business for the quarter was 53%, down from 56% in the prior quarter. Xilinx remained supply constraint throughout the quarter, and we have not experienced measurable lead time improvements. Delinquencies exiting the quarter were in line with our expectations. However, demand has been and continues to be stronger than anticipated in both the June and September quarters. As a result, we do not expect supply constraints to be fully resolved for at least a couple more quarters. While we are growing wafer outs quarter-by-quarter from our foundry network, the supply chain remains at full capacity. Based on the increases in wafers, we believe that delinquencies can be kept from growing further. 
Gross margin at 65% was up from 61.8% in the same quarter a year ago. In the past year, gross margin has benefited from the implementation of supply-chain efficiencies and greater focus on cost reduction. 
Operating expenses decreased 5% sequentially, more than anticipated, due to lower R&D spending, which is a result of delayed hiring and a push-out of contract engineering services to future quarters.  As a result, operating income increased 33% sequentially to a record $208 million or 35% of sales. This is up from 30% in the prior quarter and up from 15% in the same quarter a year ago. 
New product sales increased 23% sequentially in the June quarter to 39% of sales, driven by exceptionally strong growth from Virtex-5, as well as our newest Virtex-6 family. Sales from our Virtex-6 and Spartan-6 families were up substantially. Mainstream products increased 9% sequentially, representing 30% of total sales and base products increased 4% sequentially to 27% of total.
Europe was our strongest geography during the quarter with sales increasing 19% sequentially. Most end markets in Europe posted strong double-digit growth with the sales from Wireless Communications representing the largest incremental increase. North American sales increased 12% sequentially, driven by Defense, Wired Communications and Industrial, Scientific and Medical applications. Asia Pacific sales increased 11% sequentially with strengths from Wired and Wireless Communications, Consumer and Industrial Applications. Sales from Japan were essentially flat for the quarter. 
From an end-market perspective, Communication sales increased 12% sequentially, both Wireless and Wired Line Communications increased during the quarter. Industrial & Other sales reached a new record increasing 21% sequentially with double digit sequential increases from Defense, Industrial Scientific and Medical and Test and Measurement. Over the past five years, sales from this category have more than doubled, it's a strong testament to the fact that PLDs [programmable logic devices] are gaining ground versus ASICs [application-specific integrated circuits] and ASSPs [application-specific standard products] in these markets.
Consumer & Automotive sales increased 8% sequentially, driven by strength in Audio Video Broadcast and Consumer Applications. Lastly, sales from Data Processing decreased, as anticipated, due primarily to the timing of customer programs. 
Net income during the quarter was $159 million or $0.58 per diluted share. Other income and expense was a net expense of $5 million. This was higher than the $2 million net expense number we estimated at the beginning of the quarter, primarily due to the impact of the debt issuance and a delay in recognizing the gain on the sale of an investment. 
Operating cash flow for the March quarter was $107 million before $18 million in CapEx. During the quarter, Xilinx issued $600 million in convertible senior notes. We used $433 million in proceeds from this issuance to repurchase 16.3 million shares. We also paid $44 million in cash dividend. The tax rate in the June quarter was 22%. 
In total, this quarter's strong financial performance resulted in a return on equity of 32%, up from 8% in the same quarter a year ago. Improved profitability, as well as the recent issuance of convertible debt for the primary purpose of share repurchase, shows the majority of this improvement. 
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments increased to $155 million during the quarter to approximately $2.1 billion. We now have approximately $1.3 billion in convertible debt on our balance sheet, which included the recent convertible issuance. Our net cash position is approximately $800 million. 
Day sales outstanding increased nine days in the June quarter to 54 days. Combined inventory days in the June quarter were 80, up from 79 in the prior quarter. As I mentioned earlier in my remarks, our overall supply chain remains tight. However, we have been able to meet customers' critical needs despite the delinquency levels we are experiencing. In the September quarter, we expect inventory days to be approximately flat. 
Let me now turn the discussion to guidance for the September quarter FY '11. Our backlog heading into the quarter is up. We are expecting to see continued strength from Virtex-5 as well as continued strong growth from our new Virtex-6 and Spartan-6 families. From an end-market perspective, we are expecting sales from Communications to be up driven primarily by strength in Wireless Communications. Coming off a very strong quarter, Industrial & Other sales are expected to decrease slightly, primarily due to decreases from Defense as well as Industrial, Scientific and Medical and Test Measurement. Consumer & Automotive sales are expected to be up sequentially, driven by increased Consumer and Audio Video Broadcast sales. Lastly, Data Processing is expected to increase driven by both Storage and Server Application.
As a result, we are expecting total sales to be up 3% to 7% sequentially in the September quarter, with sales in North America declining and sales from all other regions increasing. The midpoint of our sales guidance is predicated on a turns rate of approximately 48%. This is down from the 53% in the June quarter. Our belief is that due to the extended lead time situation, we are more fully booked than in previous quarters.
Gross margin is expected to be 65%, plus or minus a point. Operating expenses in the September quarter are expected to be approximately $185 million. The increase in expenses is related to increased engineering hiring to support next-generation programs, expenses associated with contract engineering services and higher variable in selling and compensation expenses associated with our higher revenue and profit levels.
Other income and expense is expected to be a net expense of approximately $4 million. The share count is expected to be 264 million shares as the impact of our recent accelerated share purchases fully reflected, but offset somewhat by share issuance associated with our annual focal and review processes. The tax rate for fiscal 2011 is expected to be 22%. 
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. We are delighted to have delivered our third consecutive quarter of record revenue, highlighting the customer's demand side of the business remained very healthy. Six of our end market segments increased by
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. We are delighted to have delivered our third consecutive quarter of record revenue, highlighting the customer's demand side of the business remained very healthy. 
Six of our end market segments increased by double digits sequentially, Wireless, Defense, Industrial, Test and Measurement, AVB [Audio Video Bridging] and Consumer. This very broad-based market strength resulted us easily beating the high end of our revenue guidance range for the June-ending quarter.
In addition with our 3% to 7% sales growth forecast for the September quarter, we're expecting better than normal summer seasonality. The reason we are feeling positive about the September quarter is that the orders are already well booked, and our starting backlog is up significantly. 
Turning to the supply side of our business. Continue to serve our customer needs, we remained constrained primarily by foundry capacity. Our lead times continued to be stretched out like those of many others in the semiconductor industry.
Driving our record revenue growth during the June quarter were our new 40 and 65-nanometer FPGAs [field-programmable gate arrays], along with the 90-nanometer Virtex-4 family resurgence. Sales of our latest 40-nanometer Virtex-6 product increased substantially to our primary driver of our Wireless Communications sequential increase. As we predicted, several of our 3G Wireless customers took significant delivery of our Virtex-6 pads, the design to begin shipping and volume production. Our flagship, 65-nanometer Virtex-5 family reached more than 25% of overall revenues this quarter, establishing another new record as the highest generating revenue family in PLD history. In the September quarter, we expect Virtex-5 revenues to increase once again. Lastly, our 90-nanometer Virtex-4 revenues increased 15% sequentially, driven in part by strength from our Defense customers.
Current trends continue. Our growth rate is on pace to exceed the overall semiconductor industry in 2010, a testament to the validity of the programmable imperative, the insatiable need for more wired and wireless bandwidth, driving a surge in PLD demand. Increasingly, new programmable logic platforms are replacing ASIC and selective ASSP solutions, and we expect this trend will only accelerate with the introduction of our new 28-nanometer family. 
Late last month, we announced our 7 series FPGA families, which we believe will further change the game in our industry and open a bold new chapter in the history of our company. This portfolio of 28-nanometer product is built on the industry's lowest power, the only unified architecture, which scales from low cost to the ultra high end. When we collaborated with customers to define the 7 series FPGA families, it became abundantly clear our consumption was the key limiting factor to opening programmable logic to new applications and markets now serviced by ASICs, ASSPs. By choosing the high-performance, low-power process from TSMC [Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company] will significantly lower in overall total power consumption. 
It also became very clear when talking with customers about the next-generation product needs, they're experiencing a convergence of system level requirements across both high-end and high-volume FPGAs. To address this convergence, all of our 28-nanometer FPGAs are being built from a common set of system blocks, allowing customers to design their systems independent of FPGA family selection. Consequently, our unified architecture greatly improves customer productivity because once they've designed their IP, they can use and reuse it across all family. This all important focus on power, performance and productivity with our 7-series FPGAs will strengthen our core business as well as propel us into new adjacencies. 
Our announcement last quarter of our ARM-based extensible processing architecture, 28-nanometer, demonstrates that we are positioned to service a new class of designers outside of our traditional user base and spearheads our drive into a wide variety of embedded systems. By employing the familiar ARM-based software environment and fast ecosystem, we can leverage open standards, extend the reach of embedded systems, providing significant incremental growth opportunities for Xilinx. 
I'm very excited about this broad portfolio of new product. Look forward to updating you on the progress of our aggressive 28-nanometer deployment quarters to come. I'm convinced that the programmable imperative is an inexorable trend and will accelerate with the introduction of these new 28-nanometer families from Xilinx, the leading provider of programmable platform.
Now I'll turn the call over to Jon.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Moshe. Before we move on to the question-and-answer period, I'd like to make a brief announcement, likely will be of interest to the analysts who cover Xilinx and our shareholders. After 18 years of service in the investor relations organizat
componenttext:
Thank you, Moshe. Before we move on to the question-and-answer period, I'd like to make a brief announcement, likely will be of interest to the analysts who cover Xilinx and our shareholders. 
After 18 years of service in the investor relations organization at Xilinx, Maria Quillard has decided to retire. As we're all aware, Maria has been responsible for building a quality team at Xilinx that has served the needs of our stakeholders with strong leadership and uncompromising professionalism. She truly will be missed. 
Moshe and I would like to thank Maria for all that she has done. Maria will be with us for the next couple of months, and we'll be announcing a replacement shortly. 
Now I'll turn the call back to the operator to begin the question-and-answer period. Operator?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The fact that our revenue was up significantly in the days are flat or just merely the calculation. But what's really happening there is that as we've increased the number of wafers out of the foundries and move it into the back-end, the areas in the inve
componenttext: The fact that our revenue was up significantly in the days are flat or just merely the calculation. But what's really happening there is that as we've increased the number of wafers out of the foundries and move it into the back-end, the areas in the inventory where the increase really was, from a quarterly basis, wasn't in our dieback or wasn't in the front end. It was really all in the back-end. So inventory doesn't build up in assembly in Test. Just after it's been assembled and it's finished goods, ready for shipment early in this particular quarter. So we're pretty comfortable with that. Again, we think days are already very lean at the 80 level. As revenue goes up, inventory dollars will tend to drip up a little bit as well. But I wouldn't expect any significant spikes in inventory dollars in the short run.

componenttext: Yes. So the build out, it's clear the build out is starting, and we did ship Virtex-6 parts into the initial builds beyond prototyping. And that's really what the primary impact of the China business was for us this quarter. And we do expect the ramp to begin in the September quarter. And if history repeats itself, it should continue for another couple of quarters beyond that.
