headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just start on by asking about gross margins. So in terms of what was driving now going forward, should we expect that to be more mix driven? But the six ramps, what kind of impact will that also have in gross margins? I'm just trying to understand
componenttext: Let me just start on by asking about gross margins. So in terms of what was driving now going forward, should we expect that to be more mix driven? But the six ramps, what kind of impact will that also have in gross margins? I'm just trying to understand whether we had done that leveraging it now at 6% to 5% and subsequently, it's going to be about mix or is there another factor that will drive gross margins going forward?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, mix has a lot to do typically in our business because of all the different markets that we sell to. But I think the biggest dynamic that's going on is that as yields improve on Virtex-6 and the costs get better for Virtex-6 and Spartan-6, t
componenttext: Well, clearly, mix has a lot to do typically in our business because of all the different markets that we sell to. But I think the biggest dynamic that's going on is that as yields improve on Virtex-6 and the costs get better for Virtex-6 and Spartan-6, that's obviously a plus, helping us along the way. But the fact that the foundries -- the supply chain is really, really tight is actually a drag for us because it's typical in semiconductor industry. Your prices are always going down in terms of the price curve and your cost curves are also going down. And the fact that the wafer foundries are not giving us the same level of price decreases that we have historically experienced, that ends up being a drag. So we've been able to -- we do believe we'll be able to offset that, the fact that wafer costs aren't going down nearly as fast as they have in the past with other cost-reduction efforts across the company and obviously improved yields on Virtex-6. So I'd  characterized last quarter that the end of this year, we should see some -- there's a potential -- seeing some uptick in gross margin, I'm less confident that now just because of the state of the supply chain over all.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Now in terms of thinking about the impact of the supply chain. I know you've given a guidance for September, how should we, without asking you to necessarily give a full guidance for December, but how should we think about what the impact of the supply ch
componenttext: Now in terms of thinking about the impact of the supply chain. I know you've given a guidance for September, how should we, without asking you to necessarily give a full guidance for December, but how should we think about what the impact of the supply chain could have followed down the line same to the December quarter? And also as the six ramps, will that also have an impact? That's how should we think about December? So about the military, which I know does have an impact in the Q4 period, I'm just trying to understand whether the impact of supply chain could lead us to ending out with a better than seasonal December quarter? And while explaining that also, can you just give us more insight as to what your foundry partners are telling you about how they can improve the type that you're seeing right now?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, you're right, the seasonality aspect of Aerospace & Defense is tended to be a positive for us in the December quarter before. It's just way too much going on right now for us to give you a great forecast. I really don't think the supply chain
componenttext: Yes. I mean, you're right, the seasonality aspect of Aerospace & Defense is tended to be a positive for us in the December quarter before. It's just way too much going on right now for us to give you a great forecast. I really don't think the supply chain, with the way we see it today, is going to impede us from continuing growth if there's that risk demand from our customers in this ramp would continue into December. We do have capacity reservations for increasing wafers, not just in September, but also the December quarter. So we have the ability to get absolutely more wafers out in December than we did in September. And obviously, I just talked about giving more out in September than we had in June. So they have that capacity reservation and that capability at the foundries. But I'm not going to kid you, it's tough. It's really hard negotiations to get what we want. And there's a lot of semiconductor companies knocking at the door, trying to get that. And we've been treated very well by our partners and it's working out. And I do want to point out that we do have delinquencies and they increased this quarter. We really have been able to help meet customers' really critical needs. I don't think we've really created a really line-down situation, those kind of things that you might hear about in other situations. We've done a good job in the communications with our customers in that particular situation. There's a lot of companies that are shorting them. So we've got a pretty good reputation there.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Moshe, when you were describing the dynamics between ASICs, ASSP and FPGA, you've mentioned power as the most important factor now, the limiting factor in terms of adoption of FPGA. I thought it was under the impression it was more economics as opposed to
componenttext: Moshe, when you were describing the dynamics between ASICs, ASSP and FPGA, you've mentioned power as the most important factor now, the limiting factor in terms of adoption of FPGA. I thought it was under the impression it was more economics as opposed to power. Can you just shed a little bit more light as to how the economics has changed, say as we go to 28-nanometer for Virtex-6? I know that there is no one-size-fits-all example, but I'm a little bit surprised to hear power as opposed to economics, it's always used to be economics over power. So any sense as to how we can think about the impact of the economics would be helpful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you need to address all three. You need to hit the right price point, you need to have the right set of features and you need to achieve a certain power envelope. More and more, the biggest challenge is in the power envelope because as you move forw
componenttext: Well, you need to address all three. You need to hit the right price point, you need to have the right set of features and you need to achieve a certain power envelope. More and more, the biggest challenge is in the power envelope because as you move forward, as we have aggressively, to new process nodes then you can address the cost through higher density. But the power is more difficult to achieve and that has become the biggest issue. Now if you think back at what happened in the processor space 10 years ago, around the turn of the millennium, there was a huge transition that happened where the leading processor companies moved to multi-core solutions as opposed to just increasing the frequency that was all driven by power. And that was precursor that then permeated the ASIC design flow, starting from about five years ago, and we believe we are driving the leadership in the FPGA space because that has become the number one issue, not only in terms of the CapEx requirements that our customers had, but they're now looking more and more at OpEx. Products tend to have a very long life cycle, and huge portion of running their business is how much power they require. So it's becoming more and more front and sensitive to the customer's requirement in more and more applications. That doesn't mean that the other two, the features and the cost of the product sales, are not important, but the power has moved to the number one element in our mind.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tim Luke with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tim Luke with Barclays Capital.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Aniel Mahtani for Tim Luke. Could you please provide some color on how you view R&D trending over the course of the year as we ramp up new programs?
componenttext: This is Aniel Mahtani for Tim Luke. Could you please provide some color on how you view R&D trending over the course of the year as we ramp up new programs?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So R&D spending has a little bit of upward bias to the second half of our year, primarily due to the beginning of 28-nanometer tape-outs and those kinds of things. We're really experiencing one of the lower tape-outs spending years overall, and it st
componenttext: Yes. So R&D spending has a little bit of upward bias to the second half of our year, primarily due to the beginning of 28-nanometer tape-outs and those kinds of things. We're really experiencing one of the lower tape-outs spending years overall, and it starts to increase a little bit in the second half. But it kind of step it up one level higher. Just talk about OpEx in total in terms of our expectations, we guided to $185 million for next quarter. And I think even though there'll be a little bit of up and down in the second half of our fiscal year, I think somewhere in the mid-180s is the right level to plan on a quarterly basis for OpEx. Now if revenues significantly increases further, there will be additional variable expenses for selling expenses and in compensation-related expenses associated with our incentive programs for employees since that's driven by operating margin percentage. And expansion of the top line will yield expansion of the bottom line, and therefore, that will cost us more expenses there.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As you ramp up 40, 45-nanometer products, do they open up any particular new segments or new product areas for you that you're selling into?
componenttext: As you ramp up 40, 45-nanometer products, do they open up any particular new segments or new product areas for you that you're selling into?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, 40, 45 definitely deepen and broaden the markets that we service. And in particular, if you look at 40, it enables us to put -- yet another nail in the coffin of ASICs for everything except high-volume applications. But it's really the higher volume
componenttext: Well, 40, 45 definitely deepen and broaden the markets that we service. And in particular, if you look at 40, it enables us to put -- yet another nail in the coffin of ASICs for everything except high-volume applications. But it's really the higher volume markets, which are the expansion market for us, and that's the Spartan-6 product offering and that's really seeing broad acceptance in all of our traditional markets including ones that you would assume are more Virtex-oriented. So for example, Communications and the higher-volume military ones, there's a tremendous opportunity for Spartan-6 in the higher volume, more cost-sensitive applications. And then everything else just continues to open up at that market. And so even though as a percentage of the overall SPGA space today, it's still a smaller percentage. It's the fastest growing part of the market and that's why we're delighted to have the only leadership product in that market. We've served this with a broad offering, and that will facilitate growth though we already benefiting from that and the numbers in last quarter already had a significant portion of Spartan-6 revenue in addition to the Virtex-6 revenue.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Chris Danely with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Chris Danely with JPMorgan.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just maybe go over the sort of the outsourcing strategy going forward since there are some changes? And also Jon, you remarked that, I guess, the wafer pricing is changing or sort of the price concessions you've had in the past are not happening i
componenttext: Can you just maybe go over the sort of the outsourcing strategy going forward since there are some changes? And also Jon, you remarked that, I guess, the wafer pricing is changing or sort of the price concessions you've had in the past are not happening in the second half of the year. Is that a new thing? Has that never happened before? Is that unique to this cycle?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So, I mean, I'm not exactly sure what you mean by the additional outsourcing. We're certainly existing foundries. We're working with all of them to try to get more capacity. The back-end is pretty much set with the same guys. We haven't changed anything t
componenttext: So, I mean, I'm not exactly sure what you mean by the additional outsourcing. We're certainly existing foundries. We're working with all of them to try to get more capacity. The back-end is pretty much set with the same guys. We haven't changed anything there, and obviously, it's a next-generation 28-nanometer. We've talked about going to TSMC as the lead foundry for that. So there's really isn't anything changing relative to what products we're building where. We're primarily getting Virtex-5 parts from Toshiba and UMC as the two foundries. So there's really anything changing in the outsourcing strategy per se other than everybody is tied, and we're negotiating with everybody as best as we can. On the wafer pricing issue, it has happened in the past, I would say for a short period of time because cycle-to-cycle of the past have been attended to be relatively short. Meaning a couple of quarters in my experience where things have gotten tied and the foundries have said, "I don't think I need some help here, I got invested capital. I can't lower the wafer pricing et cetera." In this particular situation, I think we've gone through an extended period now of what we can see as at least three quarters of that kind of a situation going on. And it's starting to impact our cost roadmap estimates along the way. So it's not something that's going to cost us to have a huge downward impact as best as I can tell in our gross margin, but it is preventing us from expansion there. Now my expectations are when the capacity isn't quite as tight then a lot changes again.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Did your lead times or delinquencies multiply or extend further during the June quarter? And do you expect them to stabilize this quarter? Or could we see the lead times extend again?
componenttext: Did your lead times or delinquencies multiply or extend further during the June quarter? And do you expect them to stabilize this quarter? Or could we see the lead times extend again?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So lead times have gotten a little bit longer. We talked about the average for us is 10 to 12 weeks in the March quarter, and they're about the same just a little bit longer in the June quarter. From a delinquency perspective we left last quarter, the Mar
componenttext: So lead times have gotten a little bit longer. We talked about the average for us is 10 to 12 weeks in the March quarter, and they're about the same just a little bit longer in the June quarter. From a delinquency perspective we left last quarter, the March quarter, we had about 2% of revenue, that level of delinquency that we said we could have shipped if we would had all the product, and it essentially doubled from 2% to 4% in this last quarter. So we could have shipped an additional mid $20 million kind of additional revenue if we would had the supply. We think we can hold to that level through the September quarter and not expand that number. And I think that'll be a good thing. And I want to point out just one more time, we don't have a situation where customers are so angry with this. They're shopping around for other alternatives et cetera. We've actually done a very nice job of hitting critical needs of those customers.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The line up of delinquencies through the September quarter will be 10%, so close to $60 million. Do you expect that you get that back proven the capacity becomes abundant?
componenttext: The line up of delinquencies through the September quarter will be 10%, so close to $60 million. Do you expect that you get that back proven the capacity becomes abundant?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So Mahesh, let me correct your statement there. No, it's not cumulative. The delinquencies, the 2% that we had at the end of March, we essentially shipped all those delinquencies in the next month. But then throughout the quarter, we were still delinquent
componenttext: So Mahesh, let me correct your statement there. No, it's not cumulative. The delinquencies, the 2% that we had at the end of March, we essentially shipped all those delinquencies in the next month. But then throughout the quarter, we were still delinquent to what customers needed, and the number is approximately 4% of our revenue that we could have shipped. So that amount of money, again, is in the mid $20 million. As capacity increases and as long as demand is increasing at the same rate as the capacity is increasing, we won't be able to improve that. If those dynamics change, then yes, we'll be able to ship all that revenue.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the foundries, you said you have increasing wafer start, does that continue through Q4? I'm assuming that you're able to grow revenues 5% in the September quarter because that's the capacity available. Can you give us an idea, is the level of
componenttext: In terms of the foundries, you said you have increasing wafer start, does that continue through Q4? I'm assuming that you're able to grow revenues 5% in the September quarter because that's the capacity available. Can you give us an idea, is the level of wafer start increase you're getting from UMC for the December quarter is in the similar increase?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So for Virtex-5 and Virtex-4, Toshiba and UMC are foundries together. And I think it's a reasonable conclusion to say that the level of that total network of those two are going up. When they go up at the same rate as our revenue is going up, it's reasona
componenttext: So for Virtex-5 and Virtex-4, Toshiba and UMC are foundries together. And I think it's a reasonable conclusion to say that the level of that total network of those two are going up. When they go up at the same rate as our revenue is going up, it's reasonable to say that's the approximate wafer out increase.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Schneider with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Schneider with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On the Communications side, you talked about Wired and Wireless strengths. I guess Wireless, in particular, that's been strong for a while now. And I guess one of the question in everybody's mind is, how sustainable is that even with some of the secular f
componenttext: On the Communications side, you talked about Wired and Wireless strengths. I guess Wireless, in particular, that's been strong for a while now. And I guess one of the question in everybody's mind is, how sustainable is that even with some of the secular factors you mentioned to going in your favor? What are customers telling you about in whether that's likely continue into the December quarter or the March quarter after that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim, we clearly have had a quite a run here in the Wireless segment, and we are bullish on that over the long haul because of all the various dynamics that we've talked about in the past, China, the 4G LTE and other expansions in the U.S. and then In
componenttext: Yes, Jim, we clearly have had a quite a run here in the Wireless segment, and we are bullish on that over the long haul because of all the various dynamics that we've talked about in the past, China, the 4G LTE and other expansions in the U.S. and then India following that. So this quarter, the September quarter, the China business was actually relatively flat on a dollar basis for us, and a big uptick was in our LTE and shipping into the Verizon business and then the expansion of both backhaul and base stations for the AT&T expansion as well. So we've got a significant upsides from both of those, while China was relatively flat. And in the September quarter, Wireless is strong because of both China increasing and the Verizon and AT&T contracts being shipped into us as backhaul. So that's a very, very strong sign for us. Beyond that, it's less clear what's going to happen. We do think China is probably going to continue based on historic trends. But the rest of the world, India will start having something going on, but that's probably still a few more quarters out, and we don't have very good visibility in December on the Verizon and AT&T activities. So again, I think the numbers will stay pretty strong on Wireless for us, but there could be some volatility coming forward. Hard to tell right now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I think one area you didn't mention, and maybe I missed it in this quarter or the previous, the guidance was a Networking. And I was wondering if you're going to give us some color on what that did and you expect going forward?
componenttext: And then I think one area you didn't mention, and maybe I missed it in this quarter or the previous, the guidance was a Networking. And I was wondering if you're going to give us some color on what that did and you expect going forward?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we didn't say anything about it. We said the strongest growth in Communications is going to be Wireless. But Wireline, specifically Networking, we do expect that to increase quarter-on-quarter. The other side of Wireline, that's little less clear to
componenttext: Yes, we didn't say anything about it. We said the strongest growth in Communications is going to be Wireless. But Wireline, specifically Networking, we do expect that to increase quarter-on-quarter. The other side of Wireline, that's little less clear to us right now and that's the part that we're not sure of, so we didn't really, didn't mention that. So we do think Wireline is going to tick up some for us, and I'll be on the basis of Networking.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Wong with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Wong with Wells Fargo.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Do you have any thoughts about efforts to create product like Altera's HardCopy that allows you to provide your customers with cost-reduction efforts through a HardWire product?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We have a very successful product that addresses those markets. The approach is different than the one selected by the competition. But it provides the customers with very applicable solution, which can be deployed very easily and minimizes their engineer
componenttext: We have a very successful product that addresses those markets. The approach is different than the one selected by the competition. But it provides the customers with very applicable solution, which can be deployed very easily and minimizes their engineering investment. So we're pleased with that solution. It's part and parcel of our strategy going forward, and it's available for pull of our high-end product offerings as a cost-reduction part of the higher volume application.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: What's the name of this product?
componenttext: What's the name of this product?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It's the EasyPath product line.
componenttext: It's the EasyPath product line.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ruben Roy, Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ruben Roy, Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Jon, I might have missed your explanation of some of the operating margin and dynamics as you look forward, but I think if I remember correctly that the operating margin target, longer term, has been 31% to 34%. And with hitting 35% here, obviously, you h
componenttext: Jon, I might have missed your explanation of some of the operating margin and dynamics as you look forward, but I think if I remember correctly that the operating margin target, longer term, has been 31% to 34%. And with hitting 35% here, obviously, you have some spending coming up around 28-nanometer et cetera. But how are you thinking about your longer-term operating margins now that you've kind of eclipsed that high end of your previous target range?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That's hard to keep up with how good our business is, isn't it? So yes, but we're admiring the 35% and liking it, and I know that's above our target. And as you've just pointed out, we are in a low between mask and wafer tape-out kinds of spending to some
componenttext: That's hard to keep up with how good our business is, isn't it? So yes, but we're admiring the 35% and liking it, and I know that's above our target. And as you've just pointed out, we are in a low between mask and wafer tape-out kinds of spending to some degree and that starts to ramp up and that will drive some differences there. But we're clearly looking at controlling spending. In fact, we just had our kind of an update to our annual budget process and the, what I call, the direct spending, the non-variable things that were obviously focused on R&D, sales, marketing, et cetera. And we're pretty much dead on our plan and we're not expanding. Our spending levels beyond that and with the spending increases you are seeing are just because of the variable issues, because of revenue and profits increasing. So we're very, very determined to stay on that plan and that path. And because we are enjoying such a strong revenue uptick right now, it is the longest to operate higher than our model. I'm really not ready to commit to expanding our model, but we're not trying to hold ourselves back either from letting it go higher. So we are thinking about tough spending controls, continue to look for cost-reduction efforts across the company and keep that discipline. And if we get even more good news out of the revenue lines and this is going to fall through.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Around the Communications business, when you think about your China sales into domestic China carriers, do think that business for this fiscal year, June through March, is going to be higher than fiscal '10?
componenttext: Around the Communications business, when you think about your China sales into domestic China carriers, do think that business for this fiscal year, June through March, is going to be higher than fiscal '10?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our current belief is because our penetration is higher, our fiscal year '11 will be higher than our fiscal year '10 in terms of spending in China. Now I know we've all heard about pressures on CapEx and things like that, so there is maybe a little less c
componenttext: Our current belief is because our penetration is higher, our fiscal year '11 will be higher than our fiscal year '10 in terms of spending in China. Now I know we've all heard about pressures on CapEx and things like that, so there is maybe a little less confidence if you go back and talk to the Chinese manufacturers. But relative to their forecast to it in terms of the number of base stations are they talking about, that would work out to a larger number for 3G in fiscal year '11 and fiscal year '10.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, Jon, can you give us a rough idea of Spartan-6 plus Virtex-6 as a percentage of your revenues exiting June?
componenttext: And finally, Jon, can you give us a rough idea of Spartan-6 plus Virtex-6 as a percentage of your revenues exiting June?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So we're not providing that number. We said it's up substantially. We're into double-digit revenues for those two, and we'll still believe that we'll ship well in excess of $100 million in this fiscal year.
componenttext: So we're not providing that number. We said it's up substantially. We're into double-digit revenues for those two, and we'll still believe that we'll ship well in excess of $100 million in this fiscal year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ian Ing with Gleacher & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ian Ing with Gleacher & Company.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Trying to reconcile the supply constraints with why industrial is so strong then expect it to decline. You would think the industrial customers served by this, they would be the first to be under supplied. So other end markets that are getting under suppl
componenttext: Trying to reconcile the supply constraints with why industrial is so strong then expect it to decline. You would think the industrial customers served by this, they would be the first to be under supplied. So other end markets that are getting under supplied? I mean, what are your thoughts and where the under shipments are occurring?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, most of the under shipments are in the Communications side of our business, with some in Aerospace and Defense, but mostly in the Communications side. And the reason there is that the upside kind of numbers that are being driven for us are more
componenttext: Actually, most of the under shipments are in the Communications side of our business, with some in Aerospace and Defense, but mostly in the Communications side. And the reason there is that the upside kind of numbers that are being driven for us are more challenged out of the large customers, which tend to be Communications customers for us and then some Aerospace and Defense customers. Many of the Aerospace and Defense customers are on, I would say, slightly older technologies, and they've been doing a better job of forecasting and therefore we've been able to prepare better for that. The downward tick that we have going on in Industrial & Others is really more because of Defense. There were a number of, I would say, last-time buys of older parts for older contracts that kind of hit us, the timing hit us this past quarter versus the September quarter. And so we don't -- those aren't going to repeat themselves and that's really what's driving that segment down. We do think Industrial, Scientific and Medical will continue to be a growth factor for us. There's lots of new medical applications going on. Surveillance was strong this last quarter and that's going to continue. And in Test and Measurement, the semiconductor industry is buying more test equipment these days, so that's driving a need for our PGAs, and we expect that to continue as a long-term trend here for the next few quarters.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow up for your interest expense, how much of that is accounting for convertible debt, the non-cash interest portion? And how much of an impact is that to GAAP EPS? And aren't you unfairly penalizing GAAP EPS in creating unfair comp versus competi
componenttext: As a follow up for your interest expense, how much of that is accounting for convertible debt, the non-cash interest portion? And how much of an impact is that to GAAP EPS? And aren't you unfairly penalizing GAAP EPS in creating unfair comp versus competitors?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, there is an impact for that, and you're right, the recent -- because of the accounting treatment, the shorter the duration of your note, the more of that goes on. In terms of the bigger dollar amount that this is related there, that ends up
componenttext:
Well, I mean, there is an impact for that, and you're right, the recent -- because of the accounting treatment, the shorter the duration of your note, the more of that goes on. In terms of the bigger dollar amount that this is related there, that ends up in your equity area. 
From an interest expense area, it's approximately the neighborhood of $3 million to $4 million a quarter of interest expense as part of this non-cash number. And as a comparison drag, ROE is the comparison drag as well because of the accounting rules and the converts that say you have to classify some of these as equity and then you amortize it back to debt over the life of the note, and that makes our equity numbers go up artificially for awhile. Artificially, meaning from the accounting rules. I mean, obviously, it's GAAP. So those are some of the dynamics that make the comparatives a little more difficult there.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: If we should continue with GAAP estimates then?

componenttextpreview: Clearly, the biggest one is 65-nanometer and then the second largest one is 90. But I would characterize it as well over 50%, probably more like 75% is in the 65 area, and then maybe 20% or so in the 90-nanometer. There is some possibility that goes on he
componenttext: Clearly, the biggest one is 65-nanometer and then the second largest one is 90. But I would characterize it as well over 50%, probably more like 75% is in the 65 area, and then maybe 20% or so in the 90-nanometer. There is some possibility that goes on here so I'm characterizing it that way, and we can kind of move some things around between those a little bit. So you can also look at and say, everything is kind of short. But quite frankly, it is the more advanced nodes meaning that volume is being shipped on, which is namely 65 and 90.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Last quarter, you indicated some customers were adding buffer inventory. Is that still happening? Is it happening at the same rate, lesser rate? A commentary there will be helpful.
componenttext: Last quarter, you indicated some customers were adding buffer inventory. Is that still happening? Is it happening at the same rate, lesser rate? A commentary there will be helpful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're not seeing anybody at increasing amounts of buffer at this time. It's pretty stable to the handful of customers that have been doing it in the past. We have some amount of our inventory that's in hubs that people drop things out. And they're
componenttext: Yes. So we're not seeing anybody at increasing amounts of buffer at this time. It's pretty stable to the handful of customers that have been doing it in the past. We have some amount of our inventory that's in hubs that people drop things out. And they're not driving them out just to have them sit in their warehouse, they're driving them out in order to build products. So whether the end products are sitting in warehouses and that's all true, I guess that we don't have perfect visibility on that. But we really aren't seeing an increase by large customers or the subcons [subcontractors] that are building for them that are just pulling parts out and holding on to them, they are building.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The issue here with The Street regarding you and your competition is that you seem to be outgoing your customers handedly over the past several quarters. How much of this is because of market share gains or at the expense of ASSPs or ASICs? Just a little
componenttext: The issue here with The Street regarding you and your competition is that you seem to be outgoing your customers handedly over the past several quarters. How much of this is because of market share gains or at the expense of ASSPs or ASICs? Just a little definition there, that would be helpful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It also is very difficult to be precise about this because we do have lots and lots of customers buying in all kinds at different levels. But particularly in Communications, I will draw you to the fact that these large customers that we're selling to, if
componenttext: It also is very difficult to be precise about this because we do have lots and lots of customers buying in all kinds at different levels. But particularly in Communications, I will draw you to the fact that these large customers that we're selling to, if you look inside the segments that they're doing well on, that's where we're shipping the most. So base stations, backhaul, that part of their business. I believe they've been telling you it's growing faster than their average, and our penetration is also increasing in those specific areas. So we're getting an impact of sub-segments of their business doing very, very well and our penetration going up. In addition to that, we are seeing more and more improvement in terms of design wins against the ASICs and ASSPs we haven't been able to bid on in the past. At the Analyst Day, we showed you this list of one quarter's worth of design wins that it was somewhere under 100, like an 87 or 90 or something in that range, and that was through the December quarter. In the March quarter, the number of new design wins that we penetrated ASSPs and ASICs that the PLDs have been in the past went up 50% from that number. And then again in this last quarter that we just announced, it went up well over 50% again. So we are seeing up into the right penetration here. Now all those that haven't been turned into revenue yet, probably very few of them have turned into revenue, but these are definitely demonstrative signs of what Moshe has been talking about relative to the 65-nanometer and 40, 45-nanometer product families are at the right cost power density point that are proving our point that we are making headway.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And you talked a lot about the power advantages of moving to 28-nanometers from 40, 45-nanometers. How it was significantly better and would help you address a lot many more market than you address currently. Just wondering, do you think this could also r
componenttext: And you talked a lot about the power advantages of moving to 28-nanometers from 40, 45-nanometers. How it was significantly better and would help you address a lot many more market than you address currently. Just wondering, do you think this could also result in, like better pricing and support kind of like a gross margin expansion?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No. It enables us to address more applications, more markets and to broaden our penetration. I don't think you can correlate that into more profitable business. It just grows the envelope of business we can address significantly. And it's becoming more an
componenttext: No. It enables us to address more applications, more markets and to broaden our penetration. I don't think you can correlate that into more profitable business. It just grows the envelope of business we can address significantly. And it's becoming more and more important in more and more applications. Clearly in Consumer battery-operated ones, it's self-evident. But this goes well beyond that into tailored applications and even into infrastructure, where it is becoming a big deal. And so I think the major benefit is growing the market we can address significantly rather than making us more profitable.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me add to that. The lower power doesn't mean it's lower ASICs or ASSPs, it means it's lower and therefore we get much closer to where they are. And if I don't care, which means we get the right to bid on those sockets and potentially win them. It
componenttext: Yes, let me add to that. The lower power doesn't mean it's lower ASICs or ASSPs, it means it's lower and therefore we get much closer to where they are. And if I don't care, which means we get the right to bid on those sockets and potentially win them. It's not necessarily a value-driven thing that a customer will say, "Oh, I'll pay more for it" because they're just saying, "Oh, gosh, I can use your solution and get the customization." And they may pay us more because of a programmability, but I would be in our normal margin framework that we have.

componenttext: So no, we're not providing any vary point numbers on 40, 45-nanometer. They did grow substantially this quarter, and it was in the double-digit range. It was a clearly double-digits this quarter, and we still expect to ship well over $100 million of 40, 45-nanometer by the end of the fiscal year, cumulative.

componenttext: In terms of the delinquencies, you said it was 2% in March and then it grew to 4% in the June quarter. Looking back in your history, can you guys recall when it was last at that level?

componenttextpreview: Well, when we were coming out of the harsh shutdown of the foundries we had, I would say, somewhere in the probably 2% or 3% per quarter or whatever. But if I think back at least in my time here, I don't recall it ever being quite as high as 4% of revenue
componenttext: Well, when we were coming out of the harsh shutdown of the foundries we had, I would say, somewhere in the probably 2% or 3% per quarter or whatever. But if I think back at least in my time here, I don't recall it ever being quite as high as 4% of revenue.

componenttextpreview: Is it trending higher as we go into July or is it mostly stable at this point?
componenttext: Is it trending higher as we go into July or is it mostly stable at this point?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We think it's going to be pretty stable because, again, we've got growth coming out of our foundries in terms of wafer outs, and I don't think it's going to necessarily spike in any month. And I think that we can keep it stable throughout the quarter. And
componenttext: We think it's going to be pretty stable because, again, we've got growth coming out of our foundries in terms of wafer outs, and I don't think it's going to necessarily spike in any month. And I think that we can keep it stable throughout the quarter. And again, someone -- we're late shipping to somebody, we shipped to them three or four weeks late or two weeks late. But then other companies increased their orders that we can't fulfill, so then that delinquencies kind of mount a little bit. But it's typically different customers and different devices that are delinquent at the end of one quarter versus the end of the next quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the ASICs displacement team, for those of us who are trying to kind of scope it and figure out what's happening versus end-market growth, versus supply-chain replenishment et cetera, you talked about it was in the high 80s whatever. At your An
componenttext: And then on the ASICs displacement team, for those of us who are trying to kind of scope it and figure out what's happening versus end-market growth, versus supply-chain replenishment et cetera, you talked about it was in the high 80s whatever. At your Analyst Day, it grew 50% in March and then it was up over 50% in Q2. So let's say that the number, the incremental increase in the June quarter was, let's say 75 to 100 new design wins that were ASIC displacements, how many design wins does that represent as a percentage of the total design wins you've got during the June quarter?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't have that number...
componenttext: I don't have that number...

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It [indiscernible] to that number because so many of the design wins are smaller ones, which happened through the channel. But these old ones that attract by our direct sales force and are significant, so it's very difficult to quantify where they are. I
componenttext: It [indiscernible] to that number because so many of the design wins are smaller ones, which happened through the channel. But these old ones that attract by our direct sales force and are significant, so it's very difficult to quantify where they are. I think the value is in the relative number. It is now twice what it was six months ago when you compare apples to apples, and it will absolutely generate tremendous growth in the future as ASICs and ASSP is shrinking to very high volume applications and more and more applications are serviced by FPGA. That is why we're so intent toward driving the technology forward because we can afford to do that and give our customers very competitive product, the bleeding-edge nodes and now the GAAP between the FPGA nodes to the mainstream of the ASIC market, where most of the revenue is over three generations of technology. I mean they're sort of still at the 90 to 130. And we're going to be providing them 28-nanometer solution a year from now, right? That's going to be -- that will enable us to address a lot of market, hence you see the number of design wins grow. It's difficult to sort of compare it plus these tend to be higher revenue design wins, hence they have a bigger weight.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010

componenttext: Jon, do you have an update on what you expect your CapEx will be this year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I still think we're going to be in the $50 million range, plus or minus. We had quite a bit of CapEx in the front end of this year because of some new tests. Test equipment relative to new generations coming out has actually cost-reduced tests over time f
componenttext: I still think we're going to be in the $50 million range, plus or minus. We had quite a bit of CapEx in the front end of this year because of some new tests. Test equipment relative to new generations coming out has actually cost-reduced tests over time for us as we move to cheaper testers as well. So there was quite a bit of capital built up. Also there was some pop in our IT spending because we've been really tight in terms of infrastructure in the IT area, so we spent a little more in the front end of this year. So even though with $18 million this quarter, we still think we'll be in the 50-ish, $50 million to $60 million range for the year, cumulative.

componenttextpreview: No, we're not. And that's why I was emphasizing that we think we've been able to meet all the customers' critical needs. In fact, we continue to get quality, and which in quality it includes delivery scores. Very high scores from our customers because eve
componenttext: No, we're not. And that's why I was emphasizing that we think we've been able to meet all the customers' critical needs. In fact, we continue to get quality, and which in quality it includes delivery scores. Very high scores from our customers because even though we were kind of early with the delinquencies relative to the other semiconductor companies and the other suppliers, we turned out to be the bright spot. And that we are, in most cases, we may not even be on the list that they're worried about, quite frankly. So we are very confident that we're not losing business because of the supply situation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Moshe, you talked about 28-nanometers and you gave a lot of details about what are the characteristics that's going to differentiate this platform versus the other platforms. But talking to your large customers, when you're finalizing the architecture, is
componenttext: Moshe, you talked about 28-nanometers and you gave a lot of details about what are the characteristics that's going to differentiate this platform versus the other platforms. But talking to your large customers, when you're finalizing the architecture, is there something that characteristic or architecture or function done that you're seeing from customers that means to be added? Or did the architecture seem to be intact?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we cover -- the 28-nanometer solution is a very, very broad solution, and it's credibly scalable so it stresses a lot of markets. If you look at each of those markets with broad brush strokes, then at the high end, they're looking for capacity and t
componenttext: Well, we cover -- the 28-nanometer solution is a very, very broad solution, and it's credibly scalable so it stresses a lot of markets. If you look at each of those markets with broad brush strokes, then at the high end, they're looking for capacity and that's where having, by far, the largest FPGA solution enables us to address markets. And in the past, it could only be addressed by the more complex ASIC. So this really enables us to address that market with the 2 million logic cells that you can hit nearly all of the ASIC market, and there's very little in terms of capacity that we can't hit there. Then the next issue becomes -- now you have the capacity to do that, can you do this without the device becoming a frying pan? And that's why the power is so important. So that's, at the high end, the sort of thought that powers only important at the low end. That's categorically not true, it's actually essential at the high end. That's an example of markets that we can address that we have not been able to address before. Now as you move across the product offering, then you can see other markets where it becomes a little more attractive. And when you move to the high volume side of the market, just achieving or enabling the level of performance at the cost point, which is very critical at the low end, that sort of expands and will enable us to address a whole new host of applications. One market we've seen this is in the Communication space as we can now enable our infrastructure customers to address the whole breadth of their product line with the solution, and hence the scalability is very important. So we're incredibly excited about this new product, and we see tremendous benefits there. And this will enable us to expand the market, and hence we're very confident in growing the market to at least 2x where it has been, and we've put a stake in the ground that we expect this to be at least a $6 billion market by 2015, if anything. It looks like it's happening faster than it has before and it could be that, that's the conservative estimate.

componenttext: Well, because the selections in India, the selections of the providers, the OEMs going to the providers having been selected, it's hard to talk about what content change is going to be. I would assume that when India goes to 3G, it will be at the same relative level of content that we have today. And depending on which manufacturer wins, what percentage of their business, it could have some impact on it, but I wouldn't expect it to be substantially different for us as India grows and as other countries decline either in 3G or 4G generation.

componenttext: Again, it will depend on which manufacturers win. So we have our customers where we have stronger market share than our competitor and vice versa, so it depends. And since we don't know who the winners are, I can't really comment on whether it is plus or minus for us.

componenttext:
Okay. Well, thank you all for joining us today. We have a playback of this call beginning at 5:00 p.m. Pacific, 8 p.m. Eastern. For a copy of our earnings release, please visit our IR website. 
Our next earnings release date for the second quarter of fiscal 2011 will be Wednesday, October 20, after the market close. This quarter, we'll be presenting at the Citi Technology Conference in New York. And thank you very much for your participation. This completes our call.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Kerry and I will be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. A
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Kerry and I will be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speaker’s remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) Please limit your questions to one to insure that management has adequate time to speak to everyone.
I would now like to turn the call over to [Rick Oshe]. Thank you. Mr. Oshe, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the September quarter and then we’ll open the call for questions.Let me remind everyone that during our confere
componenttext:
Well, thank you and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the September quarter and then we’ll open the call for questions.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.
This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations’ website. Let me now turn the call over to Jon Olson.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Before I begin my remarks about the quarter, I would like to formally introduce Rick Oshe, our new leader of Investor Relations. Rick has been with Xilinx for 10 years in a variety of financial management positions, most recently Corporat
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Before I begin my remarks about the quarter, I would like to formally introduce Rick Oshe, our new leader of Investor Relations. Rick has been with Xilinx for 10 years in a variety of financial management positions, most recently Corporate Planning. He has strong finance knowledge as well as a solid understanding of products and the industry.
I believe he will be a strong contributor to our Investor Relations group. And you can expect the same high quality of support that you are accustomed to from both Rick and Lori Owen who remains a key interface to you all.
During today’s commentary, I will review our September quarter business results. I will conclude my remarks by providing guidance for the December quarter. September quarter sales increased 4% sequentially to a record $620 million. The September quarter was a strong quarter setting records for both sales and operating income.
Turns business for the quarter was 48%, down from 53% in the prior quarter. The lower turns number was indicative of a strong backlog going into the quarter with the turns level resulting close to the level we had anticipated. Supply constraints ease during the quarter and Xilinx exited the quarter with reduced delinquencies and lower overall lead times.
Gross margin at 65.6% was slightly higher than guided primarily due to both yield improvement and mix towards more profitable products. This is up from 61.9% in the same quarter of the prior year.
Operating expenses of $184 million represented 30% of sales down from 42% of sales in the same quarter of the prior year. This resulted in record operating income of $223 million, an increase of 170% from the same quarter of the prior year. This compares to a 49% increase in sales during the same time period.
Operating margin of 36% was up from 20% a year ago and a new record for Xilinx. New product sales increased 17% sequentially in the September quarter, 34% of sales driven by exceptionally strong growth from the Virtex-6 and Spartan-6 families. Combined sales from these families nearly doubled sequentially. Virtex-5 sales -- excuse me -- more than doubled sequentially. Virtex-5 sales also increased during the quarter. Sales from mainstream and base products both declined sequentially.
Japan was our strongest geography during the quarter with sales increasing 22% sequentially, driven by consumer and wired communications. Asia-Pacific sales increased 7% sequentially due primarily to increases from communications and data processing.
European sales increased 4% sequentially, driven by wireless and industrial and other. North American sales decreased 3% sequentially with declines from defense and communications more than offsetting increases in audio/video broadcast and test and measurement.
From an end market perspective, communication sales increased 5% sequentially driven by increases in wireless sales. Wireline sales decreased sequentially during the quarter.
Industrial and other sales were essentially flat as decreases in defense offset were offset increases in test and measurement. Consumer and automotive sales were up 7% sequentially, driven by increases in consumer and audio/video broadcast and data processing. Sales increased 6% driven by computer and data processing applications.
Net income for the quarter was $171 million or $0.65 per diluted share. Other income and expense was a net expense of $3 million and included approximately $4 million of investment gains.
Operating cash flow for the September quarter was $42 million before $15 million in CapEx. Cash flow was impacted primarily by an increase in receivables and to a lesser extent an increase in inventories. As we reported in our last 10-Q filing, we are temporarily providing extended payment terms to our primary distribution partner in exchange for a significant increase in technical selling resources designed to broaden the reach to customers worldwide, consistent with the sales strategy of the company.
Given distributor compensation for creating new business lags the investment, our temporary credit arrangement was designed to help offset working capital at the distributor. The impact to Xilinx is timing of cash collections only as we gradually return to historic credit terms by mid calendar year 2011.
After factoring in the impact to cash flow of the temporary credit terms, we are expecting FY ‘11 operating cash flow to exceed $600 million.
During the quarter, Xilinx repurchased 1.3 million shares for $33 million. We also paid $42 million in cash dividends. The tax rate of the September quarter was 22%.
Let me now comment on the Balance Sheet. Cash and investments was essentially flat during the quarter at approximately $2.1 billion. We now have approximately 1.3 billion outstanding convertible debt. And our net cash position is approximately $800 million.
Day Sales Outstanding increased to 82 days in the September quarter. We expect DSOs to decline quarter-over-quarter consistent with the explanation on cash flow provided earlier. Combined inventory days in the September quarter were 89, up from 80 days in the prior quarter. We were able to build inventory during the quarter easing supply constraints for most devises.
In the December quarter, we expect inventory days to grow as we return to full safety stock models and we build for the ramp of 40-45-nanometer product families. We expect days of inventory to be towards the high end of our model of 90-100 days.
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the December quarter of fiscal year 11. Our backlog heading into the quarter is down slightly sequentially but at historic high levels. We are expecting to see continued strength from our Virtex-6 and Spartan-6 families.
From an end market perspective, we are expecting sales from communications to be approximately flat as increases in wired communication are offset by decreases from wireless communications. Industrial and other sales are expected to be approximately flat as increases in defense sales are offset by decreases in industrial, scientific and medical as well as test and measurement.
Consumer automotive sales are expected to be up, driven by increases in automotive and audio/video broadcast. And lastly data processing sales are expected to decrease. As a result, we are expecting total sales to be flat to down 4% sequentially in the December quarter with sales at North America expected to increase, sales in Europe expected to decrease and sales from Asia-Pacific and Japan expected to be approximately flat. In the mid point of our sales guidance is predicated on a terms rate of 48%.
Gross margin is expected to be 65% plus or minus a point. Operating expenses in the September quarter are expected to be approximately $190 million. This is higher than anticipated due primarily to our restructuring charge of $4 million covering a range of costs associated with continued realignment of resources and driving overall efficiency.
Other income and expenses expected to be an expense of approximately $9 million. The share count is expected to be 260 million shares. The tax rate for fiscal 2011 is expected to be approximately 22%. Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon and good afternoon to you all. We believe we’re experiencing stabilization in end-market demand. This is reflected in our lead time contraction which we expect to continue in the December quarter.Having said this, demand for our new pro
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon and good afternoon to you all. We believe we’re experiencing stabilization in end-market demand. This is reflected in our lead time contraction which we expect to continue in the December quarter.
Having said this, demand for our new products remains resilient but we’re able to deliver our fourth consecutive quarter of record revenues. There are three key long-term secular trends that are enabling the growth in our market. Explosive demand for attenuation bandwidth, driven by the expanding number of connected users and applications who in turn are driving huge amounts of data and video traffic that at increasing rates.
The programmable imperative with the need for lower cost and flexibility are making SPGAs a preferred alternative to ASICs and ASSPs and the broadening of the markets where the benefits can be derived from semiconductors including access to the internet are rapidly expanding to reach greater population.
These trends are pervasive in multiple vertical markets including our core communications businesses that provide us with a significant opportunity to increase our long-term growth. New product sales drove our growth during the quarter.
Sales from all product families increased sequentially with particularly strong incremental gains coming from our newest Virtex-6 and Spartan-6 families. Combined sales of these 40-45 nanometer products more than doubled sequentially driven by wireless communications and 3D TV. As a result of the strong sales growth design activity for these products, we now believe that we will exceed the $100 million in accumulated sales by the end of the current December quarter, one quarter earlier than anticipated.
Sales from our flagship 65-nanometer Virtex-5 family also increased during the quarter, representing more quarterly sales than any other PLD family in history. Sales from this family reached another milestone by surpassing $1 billion of accumulated sales during the quarter, a milestone reached by only the most successful FPGA families in the past.
Xilinx leads the industry in transceiver shipments. We continue to have the industries only 45-nanometer high volume FPGA family with embedded transceivers. These devises are experiencing tremendous design win success for the little-to-no competition. 40-nanometer, 11.3 gigabit per second Virtex-6 HXT devices are also gaining significant customer traction.
These devises are the only FPGA’s on the market today that meet optical (inaudible) compliance providing Xilinx with a significant competitive advantage in servicing the increased requirements of the Next Generation optical deployment. These devises have recently won major design wins at a number of Tier 1 communications customers both in optical networking and packet optical transport systems.
Increasingly, our competitive advantages and focus extend beyond current PLD competition enabling us to also win key designs against ASIC and ASSP providers. We continue to win hundreds of designs against ASIC and ASSPs Next Generation customer programs providing further evidence of the programmable imperative is gaining momentum.
I’d like to provide you with an update on our 28-nanometer progress. We continue to execute a plan and our technology partnership with TSMC is progressing exceedingly well. In terms of early customer design activity, this family is ramping significantly faster than both Virtex-6 and Spartan-6. These seven series FPGA’s will offer the industries lowest power, highest density devices on the market.
They will also provide customers with the ultimate scalability from low cost to ultra high-end made possible through our unified architecture. Ultimately, this will extend the range of applications, we can address by solving customer challenges for lower power and costs without compromising on higher capacity and increased performance.
In addition, with our arm-based extensible processing architecture 28-nanometer, we believe we will have significant market leadership position enabling us to capitalize on incremental market opportunities. Look forward to providing you with further updates very soon.
In summary, I am very pleased with our financial performance for the quarter. We are experiencing exceptionally strong customer adoption for our new product families and we remain on track to deliver samples 28-nanometer products by the First Calendar quarter of 2011.
Let me turn - let me now turn the call back to the Operator to open it up for the Q&A session.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from the line of James Schneider of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from the line of James Schneider of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my question. I was wondering, if you could comment on the customer order patterns that you saw as you progressed through the September quarter and what you seen so far in the December quarter. And I guess specifically wit
componenttext: Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my question. I was wondering, if you could comment on the customer order patterns that you saw as you progressed through the September quarter and what you seen so far in the December quarter. And I guess specifically with respect to the communications vertical, any color you can provide on wireless, wireline and networking would be great?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim. Let me take that. So the pattern throughout the quarter was pretty much as we expected. We were very well booked going into the quarter. And so we felt it was more a mid-to-end of quarter turns kind of environment for us and while there was cer
componenttext:
Sure, Jim. Let me take that. So the pattern throughout the quarter was pretty much as we expected. We were very well booked going into the quarter. And so we felt it was more a mid-to-end of quarter turns kind of environment for us and while there was certainly better weeks than some weeks and worst weeks -- other weeks along the way in the second half of the quarter, it was actually a little more back-end loaded as we had anticipated.
That being said, if you think about another way to look at it is do we have lots of rescheduling cancellations, rebalancing of inventory, I would say we had a modest amount greater than we normally have and it does start. We are certainly seeing signs of stabilization along customers in terms of their demand, not us. So the demand is still very solid. It’s still at the higher level but the growth rates are certainly have mitigated to some degree.
And so the sense is generally across communications that where things are starting to get a little bit more balanced. Wireless is very strong for us this quarter. I’d say enterprise was flattish kind of thing and Telecom was a little bit down for us. And I’d characterize the wireless business as still being very, very good. And we’re still very bullish on wireless over the long-term and the enterprise business still is quite solid for us.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jon. That’s helpful. And then as a follow-up, I guess one can’t help but kind of notice the divergence between the rates in terms of a sequential growth that you’re seeing relative to your largest competitor. So I was wondering if you could
componenttext: Thanks, Jon. That’s helpful. And then as a follow-up, I guess one can’t help but kind of notice the divergence between the rates in terms of a sequential growth that you’re seeing relative to your largest competitor. So I was wondering if you could give us any kind of sense for what you’d chalk that up to. Is it the fact that your lead times have come down to faster than your competitor? Is it end market or customer exposure or some kind of competitive thing?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me take a [path at] it. I know, it’s kind of all of the above. I think you cut all, all of the best. If you look at just as best as we can tell about the 40-45 nanometer share between the two, we shipped significantly more product this particu
componenttext:
Well, let me take a [path at] it. I know, it’s kind of all of the above. I think you cut all, all of the best. If you look at just as best as we can tell about the 40-45 nanometer share between the two, we shipped significantly more product this particular quarter. And our estimates based on what Altera said yesterday, we’re in the neighborhood of 40% share at this point in time acknowledging that we started later than they did in terms of shipping production worthy products.
And Moshe talked in his commentary about the strong high speed transceiver uptake in the optical area and other areas for us. And so I think we’re starting to gain lots of traction across-the-board in design wins and beginning to equalize that. And again, we have the only high-volume product out there on the market and that’s really doing very, very well particularly with the device of transceivers.
So all that feels really good. But having said that, you do look at their numbers and our numbers and clearly, there’s some elevated growth. And that I think is attributed to the different profiles of inventory. We have a lot of consigned inventory locations across and so any inventory - might there is any inventory adjustment that could be coming downstream, might be a little more muted with us.
Again this is a theory because I can only see what our business is doing. And we do play in different parts of some of these end markets. For example, we’re very strong in 3D TV. And they have strengths in other areas. So it’s a bit of a timing thing going on here, I would suspect as well between us relative to end markets and customers.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s very helpful. Thanks very much.
componenttext: That’s very helpful. Thanks very much.
