headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim. Let me take that. The pattern throughout the quarter was pretty much as we expected. We were very well booked going into the quarter, and so we felt it was more a mid- to end-of-quarter turns kind of environment for us. And while there was cert
componenttext: Sure, Jim. Let me take that. The pattern throughout the quarter was pretty much as we expected. We were very well booked going into the quarter, and so we felt it was more a mid- to end-of-quarter turns kind of environment for us. And while there was certainly better weeks and some weeks than worst weeks, other weeks along the way in the second half of the quarter, it was actually a little more back-end loaded as we had anticipated. That being said, if you think about the -- another way to look at it is, if we have lots of rescheduling, cancellations, rebalancing of inventory, I would say we had a modest amount greater than we normally have. And we are certainly seeing signs of stabilization along our customers in terms of their demand on us. So the demand is still very solid. It's still at its higher level. But the growth rates are certainly have mitigated to some degree. And so, the sense is, generally across communications, that things are starting to get a little bit more balanced. Wireless is very strong for us this quarter. I'd say Enterprise was flattish kind of thing, and telecom was a little bit down for us. And I'd characterize the Wireless business as still being very, very good. And we're still very bullish on Wireless over the long-term, and the Enterprise business still is still quite solid for us.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, I guess one can't help but kind of notice the divergence between the rates in terms of a sequential growth that you're seeing relative to your largest competitors. So I was wondering if you could give us kind of any sense for what you chal
componenttext: As a follow-up, I guess one can't help but kind of notice the divergence between the rates in terms of a sequential growth that you're seeing relative to your largest competitors. So I was wondering if you could give us kind of any sense for what you chalked that up to? Is that your lead times have come down faster than your competitor? Is it end market or customer exposure or some kind of competitive thing?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take a pass at that, and maybe Moshe might want to make a comment as well. I think it's kind of all of all of the above. If you look at just -- as best as we can tell about the 40-, 45-nanometer share between the two, we ship significantly more pro
componenttext: Let me take a pass at that, and maybe Moshe might want to make a comment as well. I think it's kind of all of all of the above. If you look at just -- as best as we can tell about the 40-, 45-nanometer share between the two, we ship significantly more products, just so speak, per quarter, and our estimates based on what Altera said yesterday. We're in the neighborhood of 40% share at this point in time, acknowledging that we started later than they did in terms of shipping production or the products. And Moshe talked in his commentary about the strong high-speed transceiver uptake in the optical area and other areas for us. And so I think we're starting to gain lots of traction across the board in design wins and beginning to equalize that. And again, we have the only high-volume product out there on the market, and that's really doing very, very well, particularly with the device with transceivers. So all that feels really, really good. But having said that, you look at their numbers and our numbers, and clearly there is some elevated growth. And that, I think is attributed to the different profiles and inventory. We have a lot of consigned inventory locations across. And so any inventory -– my theory is any inventory adjustment that could be coming downstream might be a little bit more muted with us. Again, this is a theory because I can only see what our business is doing. And we do play in different parts of some of these end markets. For example, we're very strong in 3D TV. They have strings in other areas, so it's a bit of a timing thing going on here, I would suspect, as well between us, relative to end markets and customers.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Uche Orji of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Uche Orji of UBS.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I just ask you to explain a little bit more about the lead time contraction you're talking about. Anyway you can quantify that? And also if you can talk about what's available to you now from the foundries as you talk about stabilization? Is it -- wit
componenttext: Can I just ask you to explain a little bit more about the lead time contraction you're talking about. Anyway you can quantify that? And also if you can talk about what's available to you now from the foundries as you talk about stabilization? Is it -- without the delinquencies going forward, what should we be thinking about as to the long-term growth rate for Xilinx now?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: From a purely time -- leaving last quarter, we had also talked average lead times about 12 -- the last quarter and even the June quarter, average lead times of about 12 weeks. And then leaving this quarter, we're more on the nine week on average. And by t
componenttext: From a purely time -- leaving last quarter, we had also talked average lead times about 12 -- the last quarter and even the June quarter, average lead times of about 12 weeks. And then leaving this quarter, we're more on the nine week on average. And by the time we get to December, we think we will be pretty much fully across-the-board back to our normal four-week lead times. So that should characterize for you that we are getting more wafers quarter-after-quarter, and then, that should also say we've been able to manage through our delinquencies better than we anticipated and our level of delinquencies leading this quarter were significantly smaller than they were. So certainly ahead of schedule. We talked about the stabilization of our customers demand and some reshuffling of inventory and orders, I think what you're seeing is the beginning of fleshing out some of that, the inventory that our customers are holding and getting themselves a little more back in balance. I think we're seeing that happening right now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I look at the communications area, any more detail as to what's really going on within Wireless? How should we expect -- one of the key things that will driving Wireless growth, the interim over the next year? And Specifically, if you can talk abou
componenttext: And if I look at the communications area, any more detail as to what's really going on within Wireless? How should we expect -- one of the key things that will driving Wireless growth, the interim over the next year? And Specifically, if you can talk about the different results, what's happening in China, as well as India and also any comments on LC at this stages? And then on Wireline also, when you talk about investor correction needs, this is really weighs almost of the investor correction being a contract base and just for me to understand why Wireline is going to be down in your guidance for Q4?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about a little bit about Wireless versus then we go to Wireline. The Wireless piece -- China is still very, very strong for us and we're doing very, very well there, shipping into the phase four, and the view there is that if there is always k
componenttext: Let me talk about a little bit about Wireless versus then we go to Wireline. The Wireless piece -- China is still very, very strong for us and we're doing very, very well there, shipping into the phase four, and the view there is that if there is always kind of hump around these stages. But there's also other providers and other technologies that are being deployed in China, so this isn't like all-or-nothing thing and it ends and goes to zero for us all along, at the end of the cycle, over the next quarter or so. There is a base business there. And I think there will still be an underlying strength that's going on relative to the Wireless business there. We are shipping products to customers that we do believe are ending up in India. I don't believe there's been a strong uptake relative to deployment yet from the new licenses, but there is a beginning of things going on there, and we're definitely participating in that area. In the LTE rollout and HSTPA expansion in the United States, those are going quite well. And I do believe those will continue to ship in high volumes over the next several quarters as well. So we are still very positive about the Wireless environment going forward. And we've had a very significant growth rate year-over-year on Wireless, and we do believe we'll be able to keep that going, if you will, based on all those data points I just talked about. On the Wireline, I believe I heard you say that we're forecasting Wireline to be down. Actually, we were forecasting it to be up, and the strength of that is both from the telecom players that we see and then broadly, with customers that we have and then broadly, from an enterprise perspective that also is a positive going in this quarter. So both of those areas for us we think will be up.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Glen Yeung of Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Glen Yeung of Citi.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You know we're in a trade now where, I should say, lead times are coming down, and just mathematically, your terms requirements this quarter are a little less. And John, I think, when we talked in September, you'd mentioned cancellations were a little hig
componenttext: You know we're in a trade now where, I should say, lead times are coming down, and just mathematically, your terms requirements this quarter are a little less. And John, I think, when we talked in September, you'd mentioned cancellations were a little higher than normal. These things cyclically point to risk, and yet the sense is that there's some degree of orderliness, if that's a word, in the demand environment or in your customer demand environment. I wonder if you could just look back in past cycles, either John or Moshe, and give us a sense, if that's an accurate statement, because it seems more orderly despite the fact that it ought to be more chaotic?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. My view, Glen, your statements are accurate, I believe, in terms of what you and I have talked about. And I do believe, at least at this point in time, things still feel very orderly and not frantic from our customers in either direction, meaning, pe
componenttext: Yes. My view, Glen, your statements are accurate, I believe, in terms of what you and I have talked about. And I do believe, at least at this point in time, things still feel very orderly and not frantic from our customers in either direction, meaning, people are so frantic to get more inventory, they'll do anything. And the other side of this is just so frantic that they're canceling everything across the board. Neither of those things are happening. It feels very, as you say, orderly, non-chaotic and who knows what the environment will be another quarter from now, but it doesn't feel like we're in some sort of a -- were just about to have some horrible cycle out of this. But again, it does feel slightly different than previous cycles, but it may be also could be early. You never know.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, second question is really just a clarification. Did I hear you say that the level -- I know you said that level of cancellations and the rescheduling were a little higher than normal in the September quarter. Did I hear you characterize as sort
componenttext: And then, second question is really just a clarification. Did I hear you say that the level -- I know you said that level of cancellations and the rescheduling were a little higher than normal in the September quarter. Did I hear you characterize as sort of to stabilized that, that has to come back to normal or is it still relatively high this point?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't want to characterize it. In the beginning, it was high absolutely. I've said the level increased a little bit from normal, so it was a little above normal. I wouldn't call that high because I don't want to project that things are really fran
componenttext: Well, I don't want to characterize it. In the beginning, it was high absolutely. I've said the level increased a little bit from normal, so it was a little above normal. I wouldn't call that high because I don't want to project that things are really frantic because they really aren't. But the stabilization comment was more about our customers changing their orders, to swapping this part for that part, oversupply, undersupply, those things they're going on. When you start seeing those things happen, it changes some of the environment. I'll take whatever you can give me of all this parts because I'm going to need them to, now I'm rebalancing my supply, my supply chain. To be either consistent with what I need from an end-market perspective or be consistent with what I'm getting from other semiconductor companies because we're still hearing that some built-in communications, some builds are being held up because of other semiconductor companies not being able to provide parts. So there is still in the sense that there is some pent up demand out there from some of our customers but there've been not as frantic as they have been in the past and they're rebalancing supply.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mahesh Sanganeria of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mahesh Sanganeria of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, quick question on the segment for the December quarter you gave. I just want to make sure that I got it right. You said communication, flat; industrial, that one flat; and data processing, down; and consumer, up. And if that is correct, if I enter t
componenttext: John, quick question on the segment for the December quarter you gave. I just want to make sure that I got it right. You said communication, flat; industrial, that one flat; and data processing, down; and consumer, up. And if that is correct, if I enter that number, I guess data processing will be down something like 40%. Is that accurate and if that is, is that a program ending? What's going on in that segment?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's as we didn't give you the degree of up and down. I guess it's a little hard to extrapolate that number, but no, data processing is definitely not. We're not expecting that to go down 40%, because I'm not really sure how you got all that.
componenttext: No, it's as we didn't give you the degree of up and down. I guess it's a little hard to extrapolate that number, but no, data processing is definitely not. We're not expecting that to go down 40%, because I'm not really sure how you got all that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you have two segments flat, one up, and there is only one small segment down. And to have the overall revenue down 2%, that segment has to be down a lot.
componenttext: Well, you have two segments flat, one up, and there is only one small segment down. And to have the overall revenue down 2%, that segment has to be down a lot.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I hear what you're saying. Yes, so the fact that the midpoint of our range is down 2%, that might indicate that maybe Communications is -- when we say, flat, I mean, flat could be plus or minus 1% or 2%. So I think I'm ascribing flat to be within, maybe,
componenttext: I hear what you're saying. Yes, so the fact that the midpoint of our range is down 2%, that might indicate that maybe Communications is -- when we say, flat, I mean, flat could be plus or minus 1% or 2%. So I think I'm ascribing flat to be within, maybe, a slightly broader range than absolutely zero is what you are. So I think there's a little bit, I would say, potential rounding kinds of things going on between the two of us in this dialogue. If I edit now, anyway...

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And again if you look at your sub-segments, where would you think that there is most risk often inventory correction, I assume that is because that's more broad-based, or can you point to a sub-segment?
componenttext: And again if you look at your sub-segments, where would you think that there is most risk often inventory correction, I assume that is because that's more broad-based, or can you point to a sub-segment?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say -- history would say where there's a concentration of high-volume, before its customers there's more risk than if it's broadly distributed, because if it's broadly distributed, then some customer's designs could be more successful than o
componenttext: Well, I would say -- history would say where there's a concentration of high-volume, before its customers there's more risk than if it's broadly distributed, because if it's broadly distributed, then some customer's designs could be more successful than others. So I have to, normally, say, would be something in the communications line where the biggest risk could be. If there was a slowdown in telecom, capital spending or somehow wireless orders started getting canceled or something like that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Webster of Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Webster of Macquarie.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on the days of sales, you said you expect it to normalize as we get in to the middle of 2011. Does that mean it goes back down to the 40 to 50 range, or is there a new range given the new programs you have in place?
componenttext: So on the days of sales, you said you expect it to normalize as we get in to the middle of 2011. Does that mean it goes back down to the 40 to 50 range, or is there a new range given the new programs you have in place?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the answer to your question is, yes, by the middle of the year, we'll get back to more of our historic range. And I think if you look back in history, we're always somewhere into the, I'd say, 45- to 55-day range, somewhere in that range. It can bounce
componenttext: So the answer to your question is, yes, by the middle of the year, we'll get back to more of our historic range. And I think if you look back in history, we're always somewhere into the, I'd say, 45- to 55-day range, somewhere in that range. It can bounce around depending on how back-end loaded the shipments are in any given quarter. But no, they were not setting a new model for DSO. We truly will get back to our historic range.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the operating expense as we get into the March quarter, maybe beyond, can you give us a sense of how you expect your operating expenses to evolve, recognizing you might have had some restructuring charges, I guess, in December?
componenttext: And then on the operating expense as we get into the March quarter, maybe beyond, can you give us a sense of how you expect your operating expenses to evolve, recognizing you might have had some restructuring charges, I guess, in December?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The March quarter, we will start to have some tape-out activity relative to 28-nanometer, so mask cost could move up a little bit in R&D. And there'll be a little bit of additional restructuring, we believe, in the March quarter as well. So they'll be a l
componenttext: The March quarter, we will start to have some tape-out activity relative to 28-nanometer, so mask cost could move up a little bit in R&D. And there'll be a little bit of additional restructuring, we believe, in the March quarter as well. So they'll be a little bit of, again, the same kind of a little bit of upward bias, but not to a great deal. And at this point in time, we're really not talking about the next fiscal year. But I will make the statement that we do believe masks and wafer costs will go up just -- will cause Engineering to go up next year because we will be taping out a large number of 28-nanometer products and those masks cost significantly more than the last generation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, two more things if I may. On the 28-nanometer, do you expect they'll still be shipping to your customers in Q1? And then also can you give us -- on the programmable logic displacement team, you've been talking about unique design wins. Last quar
componenttext: And then, two more things if I may. On the 28-nanometer, do you expect they'll still be shipping to your customers in Q1? And then also can you give us -- on the programmable logic displacement team, you've been talking about unique design wins. Last quarter, they grew 50% sequentially. Can you give us an update on that for the September quarter?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so we definitely expect to be sampling devices to our key customers in the first quarter of 2011. And that program is on schedule to deliver. And with regards to ASIC and ASSP displacement, I believe the growth was about 15% to 20%, something like t
componenttext: Okay, so we definitely expect to be sampling devices to our key customers in the first quarter of 2011. And that program is on schedule to deliver. And with regards to ASIC and ASSP displacement, I believe the growth was about 15% to 20%, something like that vis-a-vis the previous quarter. So it's in the hundred, and it didn't grow by 50%, but it continued to grow in absolute numbers significantly. This is something we're tracking, and this trend is just continuing to gather steam. And with 40, 45 and then 28, it becomes much more prevalent, whereas with 90 and 65, it was just the tip of the iceberg.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Luke of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Luke of Barclays Capital.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jon, were you saying that your inventory was going to be higher as you exited the quarter? Could you just clarify what you were saying there? Could you also just clarify with this $200 million rise in accounts receivable, what is it that your distributors
componenttext: Jon, were you saying that your inventory was going to be higher as you exited the quarter? Could you just clarify what you were saying there? Could you also just clarify with this $200 million rise in accounts receivable, what is it that your distributors are doing for you to prompt that and what is going on there?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on inventory growth -- so inventory did grow a little bit. Net inventory was up like $18 million this quarter. We expected it will drop some next quarter, and it’s really a function that we do have this higher revenue level rate. So we do need invent
componenttext: So on inventory growth -- so inventory did grow a little bit. Net inventory was up like $18 million this quarter. We expected it will drop some next quarter, and it’s really a function that we do have this higher revenue level rate. So we do need inventory to support it to get it back to, I'll say, full safety stock. But also in the beginning of a -- what happens in the beginning of a ramp for new product introductions, if the products always cost more in the beginning and, therefore, it becomes a -- for a few quarters it becomes a very significant part of the inventory balances because of the cost content. And that's causing inventory to rise. And I would expect then, the inventory to start declining after that towards the end of our fiscal year and into the next fiscal year. So I'm really not too concerned about inventory dollars going up right now. From that perspective, I think we have a pretty good handle on things right now, and we are getting caught up with all the wafers we need for foundries and we'll adjust our wafer request as appropriate in order to keep our inventory in balance. We think we have a pretty good shot at doing that, understanding how to do that on the increase in accounts receivable and therefore, the impact to our cash flow and the question, "What's the distributor doing for us?" That's so important. As I said in our remarks, they're putting on a significant number of technical resources. And I think we talked about in our analysts meetings and some other conversations around how much focus and important it is for us to get the growth from our largest customers, and so that doesn't mean we're forsaking all the other customers by any means, but there is some level of redistribution of where the focus is going to be from Xilinx sales initiatives and doing accretion and where the distributor is going to focus on it. And in order to do that, we have to stay very tightly coupled with our distribution partner, and we together have made the decision of where we want them and which customers and how will all that -- those technical resources are deployed. And it's a basic win-win for both of us along the way because we can focus in what we think are the right things for high growth from our sales force and making an opportunity to bring in a variety of new business for us in some areas and develop customers that we were beginning to develop on our own through our own sales force. As we talked about in previous calls, we have ended our relationship with another distributor and given all our business to Avnet as one of the worldwide distributor. There's always the lag in when the compensation flows of the old guy and when it comes to the new person. And in order for us to really get this moving faster, it needed some of our help, in any way we can in order to do that. And it seemed like a reasonable way to do it was to help them through improving or offsetting their working capital penalty for investing earlier and faster like we asked them to do.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: But it normalizes by the middle of next year?
componenttext: But it normalizes by the middle of next year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, totally normalizes by the middle of next year.
componenttext: Yes, totally normalizes by the middle of next year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On your interest expense it seems that jumped from negative $3.5 million to $9 million. What's the dynamic there? What should we think about going forward?
componenttext: On your interest expense it seems that jumped from negative $3.5 million to $9 million. What's the dynamic there? What should we think about going forward?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in the $3 million that we had, there was a $4 million gain. So if you normalize for that, the number would be like a $7 million number. And we always have some positives and negatives that drag in addition to just interest expense and interest income.
componenttext: So in the $3 million that we had, there was a $4 million gain. So if you normalize for that, the number would be like a $7 million number. And we always have some positives and negatives that drag in addition to just interest expense and interest income. In the forecast that we have is $9 million, is kind of vanilla, if you will. It ends up being about $13.5 million of quarterly interest expense offset by the interest income that we have, which by the way you know how low the interest rates are, so the offset is not as big as it was years ago. And so the negative $9 million is, for the most part, the pure interest expense offset by our income from our portfolio.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly, in March, having stabilized, as you would put it in terms of the lead times and the availability of products, the beginning of the year has historically been a firmer period for you. Given the rate of momentum in the market seems to be slowing, do
componenttext: Lastly, in March, having stabilized, as you would put it in terms of the lead times and the availability of products, the beginning of the year has historically been a firmer period for you. Given the rate of momentum in the market seems to be slowing, do you have any kind of broad color in terms of how you'd expect that to be now?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we're really not going to forecast that quarter today, Tim. Our visibility still integrates in the world on what's going on. And certainly, we feel like we can manage through any inventory adjustment, et cetera, appropriately. But I think it's prematur
componenttext: So we're really not going to forecast that quarter today, Tim. Our visibility still integrates in the world on what's going on. And certainly, we feel like we can manage through any inventory adjustment, et cetera, appropriately. But I think it's premature to kind of pin an estimate or too much color on March at this point in time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Benjamin of Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Benjamin of Jefferies & Company.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First is on wireless, I know it was asked a little bit, but if you look at your business versus your main competitor, there is a divergence here. And I was just curious if you can maybe elaborate. Is it in terms of your specific customers that you think t
componenttext: First is on wireless, I know it was asked a little bit, but if you look at your business versus your main competitor, there is a divergence here. And I was just curious if you can maybe elaborate. Is it in terms of your specific customers that you think that you penetrated in? Or is there some other specific share loss that you think is explaining that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I think from an actual, from this last September quarter, I don't know that I see the divergence the same way. We grew our Wireless business double-digits. So we have a very strong Wireless business performance, I think, this quarter. With respect to t
componenttext: So I think from an actual, from this last September quarter, I don't know that I see the divergence the same way. We grew our Wireless business double-digits. So we have a very strong Wireless business performance, I think, this quarter. With respect to the forecasting quarter, December quarter, I think that what we're seeing is that the lead time issues that we were experiencing were heavily weighted towards our Virtex-5 family, and that is a very, very strong performer in our overall Wireless business. It over-weighted part, if you will, by a long shot in terms of our wireless suppliers. And as lead times are shifting and changing, I think, the order patterns from our customers are changing a little bit and this is probably, I'd say, rest of the world taking China out. And it's just -- I think that's just a matter of rebalancing the inventory flow. It's not a long-term pattern that you'd see that much divergence between the two.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then as it relates to the turns rates that you guided to, can you just give a little more detail as to typically how you look at that and why you came up with 48% this quarter. I think historically, that's right around where it is, but it's been lower
componenttext: And then as it relates to the turns rates that you guided to, can you just give a little more detail as to typically how you look at that and why you came up with 48% this quarter. I think historically, that's right around where it is, but it's been lower over the last several quarters, so just curious if you can give some more color as to how you get the 48% this quarter?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, the turns rate for us is really a function of how this lead time and how low a book are you going in the quarter. And we had, even though we're down slightly in our backlog, we're not down very much. We just had a few couple of percentage points. So
componenttext: Sure, the turns rate for us is really a function of how this lead time and how low a book are you going in the quarter. And we had, even though we're down slightly in our backlog, we're not down very much. We just had a few couple of percentage points. So it's really isn't much of an adjustment down. And so we still continue to be very, very well booked. And we kind of feel that if anybody was out there trying to take inventory early because of lead times and trying to scroll some things away, if they are actually doing that out there, then they're not going to be doing that as their lead times come back to four weeks by the end of the quarter. And when, we look at all of those patterns and say, "You know December quarter with all its strength or the historical pattern, looks quite a bit like the September quarter in terms of a good strong backlog in that turns level to deliver a number." That's the thought process we went through.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra of Robert W. Baird.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You started the year more supply constraint than your competitor, and now your supply constraint are diminishing seemingly faster. Is this related to fundamental shift in market share, or is it due to timing as mentioned earlier? And also if you could exp
componenttext: You started the year more supply constraint than your competitor, and now your supply constraint are diminishing seemingly faster. Is this related to fundamental shift in market share, or is it due to timing as mentioned earlier? And also if you could expand on the consigning inventory arrangement that you have and perhaps quantify that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the supply constraints are related to our supply chain, which isn't -- we don't have the two companies under the same supply chain, they're different suppliers. So I can't really comment on their supply chain versus ours. I can only comment on our
componenttext: Yes, so the supply constraints are related to our supply chain, which isn't -- we don't have the two companies under the same supply chain, they're different suppliers. So I can't really comment on their supply chain versus ours. I can only comment on ours. And we discussed a lot of time with our foundry partners, which is where the primary shortage has been, working through this with them. And certainly as they've gotten freer, they've allocated more and more wafers our way because we still really need them. So I think from that perspective, the supply side, our objective was to get well, and we're getting well by December. On the demand side relative to delinquencies, and again, there is some timing going on. And I just point to the fact that we have supply models that we think are helping us mitigate any gigantic adjustment pending some macroeconomic setback going on in the world. But we think we're pretty confident in that. And the reference to supply chain models like consigned inventory, we really don't disclose the percentage of what we have, but they certainly have been growing in their favor with our large customers. And we've been shipping more and more directly to them, to these very large customers and less and less using distribution models, in order to do that, because they want a lot more of a just-in-time model. And given the fact that our top communications customers are very large for us and most of them have moved to some variation of that model. Within our top 10, there's quite a bit of that revenue is supplied that way.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, since your the delinquency rate is falling, should that translate into higher gross margin? Because I think you had a comment earlier this year that this was putting a sitting on your gross margin as a result?
componenttext: And finally, since your the delinquency rate is falling, should that translate into higher gross margin? Because I think you had a comment earlier this year that this was putting a sitting on your gross margin as a result?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think delinquency, the only thing that's related to supply chain and the gross margin, was the delinquencies is that the foundries have been very, very full. The rate of cost declines that we've been getting has been more difficult to achieve. And at th
componenttext: I think delinquency, the only thing that's related to supply chain and the gross margin, was the delinquencies is that the foundries have been very, very full. The rate of cost declines that we've been getting has been more difficult to achieve. And at this point in time, I'm not changing that statement because the foundry still are full, and we've been doing everything we can to expedite things for our customers. And that's been cost pressure as a result of that.

So by the end of December, we should be in that date and which should be -- well it won't be -- everything will be -- won't be -- all products won't be a safety stock, full safety stock levels, a majority of them will be.

componenttext: So you guys laid out your 28-nanometer ramp and ship schedule. headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think our approach is very different. We have product which is targeted at scalability, low power with the highest capacity possible. They have somewhat of a different approach, they're targeting the very high end of the product offering. They haven't y
componenttext: I think our approach is very different. We have product which is targeted at scalability, low power with the highest capacity possible. They have somewhat of a different approach, they're targeting the very high end of the product offering. They haven't yet revealed the rest of their product line, which I'm sure they will. I'm very confident in our ability to deliver this in the dates that we have committed to and the way that the family has been defined, designed, and in particular, the unified architecture should enable us to roll it out very efficiently during the year. And that's sort of the core of what we're doing. We feel very comfortable with that approach. And again, I can't understate -- sorry, I can't overstate how important the low power is. It is, even at the high end, it is by far the biggest issue. And as a result, that's why we have -- we can enable a part, which is close to 2x larger than the competitors' largest part, because we focused on power and it's actually thermal envelope that precludes reaching these levels of density and the low power enables us to get there. So I like our strategy, and we're going to focus on the execution and deliver it to these programs.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one more longer-term question. In terms of foundry supply, if we're looking out, let's call it a year to two years, what would be your ideal mix of supply between UMC, TSMC and everybody else?
componenttext: Just one more longer-term question. In terms of foundry supply, if we're looking out, let's call it a year to two years, what would be your ideal mix of supply between UMC, TSMC and everybody else?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, TSMC is the key foundry that we're using for 28-nanometer, and the FPGA business takes time until you get to very, very high volume. UMC has been a fabulous partner for us, and they will continue to carry the majority of our shipments for a very, ve
componenttext: Well, TSMC is the key foundry that we're using for 28-nanometer, and the FPGA business takes time until you get to very, very high volume. UMC has been a fabulous partner for us, and they will continue to carry the majority of our shipments for a very, very long time. And if anything, since the 40-nanometer now is just starting to ramp up, there's room for huge growth with our business with UMC. So overall, the balance should remain that way until the 28-nanometer becomes the largest shipping family. And that's going to take quite a few years.

componenttext: A question on the Industrial segment, I'm just wondering how we should think about the growth there. It looks like you're shipping now about sort of 20% above prior peak in industrial. And just wondering how we think about the long-term growth in terms of increased adoption of FPGA? Or would I expect that to kind of normalize or flatten out a little bit?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, when you look at in industrial, it's really an umbrella for a lot of small fragmented market. Those small fragmented markets, you just can't justify ASSPs and/or ASICs. So if anything that transition in industrial away from the historic, old ASICs a
componenttext: Well, when you look at in industrial, it's really an umbrella for a lot of small fragmented market. Those small fragmented markets, you just can't justify ASSPs and/or ASICs. So if anything that transition in industrial away from the historic, old ASICs and away from standard products to FPGA should continue to gather steam. It's somewhat similar to the trend that happened in the Mil [ph] aerospace a few years ago where the volumes there were low. They used to do ASICs. They stopped doing ASICs almost across the board at any level and they've moved primarily to FPGAs. That's happening now in the industrial market, and we expect that trend to continue. Then of course the industrial market does depend on world economy and GDPs and things of that sort because that's the nature of that. It's very broad and very diversified. So it will have fluctuations driven by that, but I have no doubt about the secular trend in industrials.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And with the new product offering, the ARM-based processor, I mean, that's going to also be, I think, a very popular alternative to those that are using ASSPs in industrial, scientific and medical areas, certainly a target market for that product family a
componenttext: And with the new product offering, the ARM-based processor, I mean, that's going to also be, I think, a very popular alternative to those that are using ASSPs in industrial, scientific and medical areas, certainly a target market for that product family as it rolls out. So our commitment there is very, very strong, and we think that's a growth area for us.

componenttext: Well, I can't really provide you a steady-state number because there's a cycle here. Every other year we have this big increase, and then it goes back down to a more normal rate. We aren't counting -- the underlying R&D headcount, we aren't in expense, we aren't counting on large, some large growth rate out in time in the next year or so. And that's not what we're planning on doing. What we -- some significant like a 20% headcount increase in R&D and those kinds of things that's -- we're not planning that right now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the 2011 will be the design win, massive design win year for 28-nanometer. And that's a very, very big family, and we're introducing it as quickly as we can across the entire product offering. And then and there's a derivative product, which John ha
componenttext: Well, the 2011 will be the design win, massive design win year for 28-nanometer. And that's a very, very big family, and we're introducing it as quickly as we can across the entire product offering. And then and there's a derivative product, which John had mentioned, which is the one we announced several months ago, which is the embedded arm solution, which will enable significant design wins in new markets that we have not had the same level of penetration. And that's the design win year. It translates into revenue in the following year and the year after that. So that's when the full impact of this great new product, which not only is it a market share changer, but it actually is a market expander and enables us to win more business against ASICs and ASSPs, which we already have been winning. That's when that new generation has the impact. So it's not 2011, it's the result of 28-nanometer moving into revenue post of the major design win phase.

componenttext: David, the growth rate has been very, very rapid. I think we said more than doubled from last quarter. And we really don't forecast market share. componenttext: So certainly, we go into any relationship with any foundry with a joint understanding of what the yield curve looks like, and the rate with which our experience has typically demonstrated self on previous generations. And will that end up having a positive impact? As Moshe said, it's a while before revenue become significant enough, but downstream, I think it very well could have some positive impact, but way too early to tell.
